name: President. –
text: The next item is the report by Mr Carlos Zorrinho, on behalf of the Committee on Industry, Research and Energy, on the promotion of Internet connectivity in local communities (COM(2016)0589 – C8-0378/2016 – 2016/0287(COD)) (A8-0181/2017).

name: Carlos Zorrinho
text: reporter. - Madam President, Commissioner - welcome to Parliament -, Representative of the European Council, ladies and gentlemen, people, all over the world, are increasingly turning to digital technologies and services. Today, digital transformation is an absolutely unstoppable process and history teaches us that letting technology decide the future of societies has never been successful. We have to decide the future of technology and, above all, we have to determine what with this technology we can make happen in order to have a more decent, fairer, safer, more sustainable society, with more opportunities and with higher quality of life. life for people and that choice is a challenge that we can involve, we must involve, European citizens. This is an opportunity to motivate these citizens to participate in the re-foundation of European society. It is an opportunity to reconnect them with the European project. The WIFI4EU Initiative is an important step towards achieving this reconnection goal and to realize this vision. Providing all Europeans with free and unrestricted access to high-quality Internet on public sites is a measure of great symbolism that has a lot of political strength and has great transformative potential. It is, moreover, a measure with such force that the President of the European Commission used it, last year, in the State of the Union speech as one of the anchors of his intervention. From the challenge launched at that time, the most noble moment of the Commission's accountability to Europeans, we did a stimulating work of mobilization and negotiation that allowed us to get here. Networking with regions, companies, civil society, institutions and governments, which allowed us to reach the legislative act that we are discussing today. The proposal under consideration guarantees neutrality in Internet access. It also ensures the selection of the best technology to be applied in each case. It guarantees access, regardless of geographic location and also users' income. It does not discriminate against anyone or any territory. It has a simple application system and a unique validation and, therefore, WIFI4EU is the embryo of a competitive and inclusive European Gigabits Society. It is, moreover, the embryo of a European digital identity that will result from the inclusion of our common values ​​in the new digital society. I therefore thank all those who worked with me on this draft report. I am grateful to the Economic and Social Committee and the Committee of the Regions, which from the outset have worked in concert with the European Parliament and the Commission and the Council. I thank the European Commission and the Council for their convergence in the constant search for good political, economic, technical and financial solutions. I am particularly grateful to all my colleagues in the European Parliament, and particularly to the shadow rapporteurs, for the strength and enthusiasm they have put in their active contribution. I am grateful to the technical and political secretariats, who are always available for a job that was not easy, but that brought us to a successful conclusion, opening up new opportunities for people. I therefore call for the adoption of the legislative act under discussion. It is important that this year the first applications take place and the roots of WIFI4EU start to spread throughout the Union. In conclusion, WIFI4EU is a small step. It is a small step for us, but it is a big step for the European Union to have a leading role in the development of an inclusive, open, transparent, creative and people-friendly digital society. Let us connect with this idea, for a better future for the European Union and the world.

name: Mariya Gabriel
text: member of the Commission. - Madam President, indeed, this is my first plenary debate in my new role as Commissioner for the Digital Economy and Society. The emotion is all the greater since it is once again the citizens who are at the heart of this debate and who constitute the priority common to all of us. Ladies and gentlemen, first of all I would like to thank the rapporteur, Mr Zorrinho. I would also like to thank the shadow rapporteurs as well as the rapporteurs of the BUDG, TRAN and REGI committees for their work. In general, the Commission would like to thank the European Parliament for the political agreement obtained following a single trialogue last May. To begin with, let me quote President Juncker, one year to the day after his State of the Union address: “Everyone should benefit from connectivity in public spaces all over Europe, regardless of their location. where she lives or how much she earns ”. The WiFi4EU initiative is a concrete and decisive step in this direction. Over the next three years, it will provide Internet access to residents and visitors of 6,000 to 8,000 local communities across the European Union. Over the next three years, I would also like to say that the European Commission welcomes the European Parliament's agreement on the importance of providing high quality internet access to our citizens. The Council, the Committee of the Regions and the Economic and Social Committee also share this approach. I would like to refer to three main elements of the initiative, which have been debated and for which Parliament's contribution has been decisive. Firstly, funding will be allocated ensuring a geographical balance in the countries of the Union and, in principle, on a "first come, first served" basis. When the vouchers are distributed, the principle of subsidiarity applies in its entirety. Municipalities will thus be free to choose what they consider to be the main centers of their community: a public library, town hall, local health centers, a square, parks, etc., while doing so by doing so. so as not to distort competition with private operators. It is therefore excluded, within the scope of the initiative, to duplicate existing networks with similar characteristics. We will also ensure that user connections remain free and without discriminatory conditions. Second, access to broadband connectivity will be easy. After a one-time registration, users will be able to automatically connect to all WiFi4EU hotspots in Europe. In addition, thanks to a very useful amendment introduced by Parliament, the initiative will also be open to existing public networks, so that any local authority in Europe will be invited to join the WiFi4EU network. Finally, this initiative also covers content. We want to promote the development of more and better digital services by local players. I am thinking here of e-tourism, e-health and e-government. Once again, I would like to thank the European Parliament for the work done on this WiFi4EU initiative. Thank you for your attention and look forward to the discussions to come.

name: Claudia Țapardel
text: Committee on Transport and Tourism. - Launched a year ago in this plenary, WIFI4EU is a project that demonstrates that the European Union has a visible, direct and positive impact on the lives of citizens. In line with the vision set out in the Digital Single Market Strategy, access to the Internet and, consequently, to information are becoming essential conditions for ensuring Europe's long-term competitiveness. The digitalisation of each economic sector represents the future of Europe, ensuring the development of each community, including from a social point of view, if we are to focus only on the impact on education or the functioning of local public administration. From a transport and tourism perspective, the integration of digital services is becoming vital for meeting connectivity objectives and improving the quality of European services, which we have also emphasized in the opinion of the Committee on Transport. The installation of free wireless hotspots will help to better contextualize mobility patterns, as the data collected can be used to evaluate public transport policies. Public authorities will be able to create safer routes and reduce the inconvenience caused by traffic by optimizing and making transport routes more flexible. At the same time, for tourists, the possibility to be able to connect to the internet when visiting a city will mean extra security and a more pleasant tourist experience. But how can we maximize the impact of WIFI4EU and ensure that it does not remain a success on paper alone? First, by making sure that there is indeed a fair geographical distribution of financial support. European funds must be used where they are really needed and where they will really make a difference in people's lives. Secondly, the European Commission needs to launch an information campaign on the availability of this support and the benefits. Last but not least, financial support is extremely important.The WIFI4EU project must be compatible with other regional and national programs, and possible synergies will be identified with them.

name: Anne Sander
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. - Madam President, dear Commissioner, I am happy to meet you for your first debate in this Chamber, there will be more. We always wonder what Europe is actually doing for its citizens. By funding the deployment of free wifi networks in public spaces, the WiFi4EU initiative, which we will vote on tomorrow, is precisely an example of a Europe that is visible and useful in the daily life of Europeans. For me, all citizens should have access to the Internet, whatever they earn and wherever they live. Still too many rural villages do not have a good connection. Worse, almost half of the population of the European Union does not have sufficient digital skills. The aim of the text is therefore to favor rural areas and those which need it most. While the allocation method will be on the basis of the "first come, first served" principle, we wanted a balanced distribution according to the regions. The system must be as simple as possible to avoid the red tape often associated with European funds and allow small municipalities to participate. The financing will therefore be through vouchers of 20,000 euros, with lighter control conditions. The budget negotiation was difficult. We have secured 120 million euros, but we know that this is not enough to cover the needs of hundreds of thousands of European municipalities. However, with the creation of a single sign-on system for each user, WiFi4EU can become the catalyst for the deployment of free European wifi in all public places. Internet connectivity is not an end in itself. It is the prerequisite for the digital transformation of our economy and our society. With WiFi4EU, we promote this connectivity to allow everyone to fully benefit from the digital revolution.

name: Dan Nica
text: on behalf of the S & D group. - The digital single market can also be achieved by reducing the digital divide between Member States, between different regions, categories of European citizens and various industrial sectors. Investment and digital innovation will ensure the growth of the digital economy and provide opportunities for development of new industrial sectors. I congratulate our rapporteur, Carlos Zorrinho, on his work and on the agreement he has reached on this regulation, which will ensure access to high-quality wireless connectivity throughout the Union. The WIFI4EU initiative will have a strong impact on around 6,000-8,000 municipalities in all Member States for which € 120 million will be allocated to fund equipment for free WI-FI services. I emphasize that the available budget should be allocated to projects in a geographically balanced manner between Member States, including allowing for a more active participation of applicants from Member States where the use of grants or other forms of financial assistance has been comparatively low. The WIFI4EU initiative contributes to overcoming the digital divide and complies with EU rules on data protection, network neutrality, supports state-of-the-art equipment and ensures IT security. Importantly, the commercial use of data obtained through the initiative is prohibited. Improving access to high and very high speed broadband internet and therefore to online services, especially in rural areas and remote areas, will increase the quality of life by facilitating access to services such as e-health, e-government. , and could promote the development of local small and medium-sized enterprises. I believe that an important commitment is also the joint statement of the three institutions that, if the increase in the amount earmarked for the package for the implementation of the Mechanism for the Interconnection of Europe in the Telecommunications Sector from EUR 25 million to EUR 50 million cannot be fully secured, the Commission could propose reallocations to facilitate the full financing of the EUR 120 millionOf euro.

name: Anneleen Van Bossuyt
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. - Today is a sad day, I think, for all hard-working Europeans. Today they are going to suffer from the wastefulness of the European institutions. A year ago President Juncker was indeed here, as has already been mentioned, and in his State of the Union he launched the idea of ​​free Wi-Fi for the citizens. Now EUR 120 million in tax money will be released to give a free Wi-Fi station to about 7,000 municipalities. I have three specific objections to this. Firstly, I think it is naive to think that we will start a digital revolution with this project. I think we can invest the money much better in crucial new technologies, such as 5G, and in superfast internet. Secondly, the seniors and the average tourist, two target groups that are explicitly targeted, will hardly use a free hotspot. I don't see any seniors, who are not very mobile, suddenly go to the market square to check their e-mail. Now that we have free roaming, tourists won't leave their spot on the beach to check their Facebook. Third, the plan will also lead to the extension of the transfer union, as well-performing regions will be punished. That is why I say: Europe should not focus on handing out expensive gifts, but on jobs, security and migration.

name: Pavel Telička
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Madam President, we have heard very positive words about the initiative. We have also heard now somewhat reluctant words. I would say the truth is somewhere in between. It is an opportunity: the programme itself has certain elements which are relatively new. I think they definitely cut the administrative burden, which is already a precedent for, let us say, other initiatives in the future.  Secondly, it is a carrot in the telecom package. I think it is a carrot which can create impetus, and that is important. Of course, whether it be four, six or eight thousand communities, it will not be a revolution. But we all know that in a number of Member States, in some remote areas, the culture is relatively low in this respect in terms of developing in this field, and that is what I understand the initiative to be: to create an impetus that would really make a difference. If I were a mayor of a village which has not applied, and I see that in the next community they have applied and they have received their contribution and WiFi is being engaged, I might see people from my community suddenly leaving for the next village in the evening for entertainment or something else, but that is an added value. What I am looking for is a spillover effect, and that is why the Commission should be very careful and very pragmatic in terms of evaluation of the effect that will have.  Promotion will be absolutely key, so if we really want to achieve what we are aiming at – and I see a number of positives: single authentication, low administrative burden and a relatively speedy approach – then I think that gradual implementation and the permanent engagement of the Commission is crucial. A final remark on the budget: I find the horse trading, whether it is EUR 95 million or 120 million, a bit of a disgrace bearing in mind what the objective is, what the money concerned is, and what we are really looking forward to. I hope that we will comply with the statement that is existing on the table and that we will increase the budget.

name: Νεοκλής Συλικιώτης
text: on behalf of the GUE / NGL Group. - Mr President, first of all I would like to thank Mr Zorrinho for the good cooperation we have had. The initiative to promote free WiFi in local communities is very important, but we must ensure that it works for the benefit of citizens from all walks of life, achieving the maximum possible public benefit. We also need to ensure that it is free and there will be no charge. Our priority must also be to take advantage of wireless connectivity, especially in less developed countries and regions, islands and mountainous remote and inaccessible areas. We welcome these positive reports included in the final text, improving on the Commission proposal. Equally important is the addition we have made that the available budget must be distributed in a geographically balanced way. The Commission's proposal to submit the budget to the Member States, usually in the order of receipt of the proposals, 'fist come, first served', is in our opinion wrong: instead, a comprehensive action plan should be submitted which ensure that all states benefit according to their needs. In closing, we call on the Commission to take immediate action to ensure that all states and local authorities are adequately informed of the relevant terms of the proposal, but also to have sufficient support to begin the preparations for the applications immediately.

name: Michel Reimon
text: on behalf of the Verts / ALE Group. - Madam President! I would like to thank the rapporteurs and the other shadow rapporteurs for the good cooperation and I am pleased that the Commissioner is taking part in the discussion today, because she will be responsible for the implementation of this project. Even if the decision is very good, there are several points that can now be done very well or very badly in the implementation. If 6,000 to 7,000 European municipalities can apply for free WiFi and access is regulated via applications and the order of applications, then this can mean that large municipalities, efficient municipalities apply first and this money does not go there, where we actually wanted it, namely in small, structurally weak regions. It will be the task of the commission to motivate the small and weak municipalities in particular to apply as quickly as possible so that they too can get a chance. Unfortunately, this is now a question of implementation; we couldn't put it in law. There is also a second thing that we will have to expand over the next few years: We can only offer powerful free WiFi where there is already powerful Internet. Therefore, there is no point in offering WLAN in a public place if there is no powerful network behind it. We will also need a program so that there is an efficient Internet in structurally weak regions in the first place, otherwise we will have a bottleneck here. Unfortunately, that was not discussed. That may cost a lot more than EUR 120 million in the next period. One last point: a tremendous amount of importance must be attached to data protection. Much is said here about the democratic value that this program has. This is only possible with data protection if we grant real anonymity.

name: Jonathan Bullock
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. – Madam President, I must say that promotion of the internet connectivity in local communities is of course absolutely vital, but why are we doing it at some EU level? This is something which can be done perfectly well at nation-state level. Indeed, EUR 120 million – where is the money going to go? Is it going to be properly audited, what is going to happen to it? I think my constituency will be very concerned about EUR 120 million being spent on this. And why are we looking at it in a European perspective? It is of course the World Wide Web, invented by Britain, I might add. And of course we always do this, we sort of think that Europe can tackle something, well let’s think wider: would Mr Juncker restrict himself to European wine? I think not. There is good wine in Australia and South Africa. So let’s look at this at nation-state or worldwide level, not at European level.

name: Barbara Kappel
text: on behalf of the ENF Group. - Madam President, Commissioner! Of course we will not trigger an internet revolution with EUR 120 million, as was said today. But I think this report by Carlos Zorrinho is important because it has a very high symbolic power - a symbolic power for the fact that the small communities in the rural region in particular are being involved and awareness in the parish offices that digital networking, that the digital society is important and a concrete incentive is created for this. I would therefore also like to thank the rapporteur for bringing us all together well - I was the shadow rapporteur - and for achieving this result, which I believe will be highly symbolic. After all, up to 8,000 municipalities are to be equipped with free WiFi in the next three years. This benefits both a growing need for connectivity and digital networking. The pilot project is intended to help accelerate the development of an inclusive digital society so that all Europeans can enter the gigabit society. 120 million euros - this has already been said - will be made available from the Connecting Europe Facility. The EU finance ministers have already agreed on this, and the first funds are due to be distributed later this year. The WiFi4EU initiative bears the costs for the equipment and installation, and the requesting public body, i.e. the municipality, pays for the network connection and maintenance for a period of three years. The municipalities should also be encouraged - and I think this is particularly important - to offer more digital services such as electronic health services or government services and also to develop corresponding apps. The granting of funding is unbureaucratic, which is a major advantage, is based on a voucher system based on the model first come, first served.I think the initiative is important.Geographical balance and sustainability must be guaranteed so that all Europeans can join the gigabit society.

name: Jerzy Buzek (PPE).
text: – Madam President, I would like to congratulate the Commissioner on a very good initiative, and also the rapporteur for his great work, all the shadow rapporteurs, and the Committee on Industry, Research and Energy (ITRE) members. Thanks to the Maltese Presidency, the negotiations were not very complicated because there was great political support for the idea. Even if there are some doubts, listening to our colleagues, if we think of a more inclusive Europe, of course we should start with such an idea. It is quite obvious. It is a big step towards our digital union. WiFi4EU, with free hotspots in thousands of towns and villages, may be a real game-changer in some areas – better education, local business, tourism, citizens’ daily lives – but we need to go beyond that. In the ITRE Committee we are committed to developing better connectivity throughout Europe, better coordination of the radio spectrum, for example, which is very important, and to stimulate investments in the high-capacity networks across the continent. So if you would like to fight for a more inclusive Europe, let us go forward. Even if it is a great success, we should not stop now. Digital union is a very important idea in front of us.

name: Josef Weidenholzer (S&D).
text: - Madam President! In these times there are also success stories at the European level. In general terms, these are efforts to make the digital single market a reality. This is progressing quickly and we hope that we will work well with the new Commissioner. WiFi4EU is a very special success story in this context. The ordinance was implemented within a year. Parliament has demonstrated its ability to act in an impressive manner, and Carlos Zorrinho deserves our special thanks. The regulation is an important impetus for supplying public spaces with WiFi and it shows that the public sector cannot remain inactive in the supply of services of general interest. People have been waiting for this for a long time and it is worth listening to the citizens. Last week we had an information event on the new regulation in the House of the EU in Vienna and were surprised by the great interest shown by community representatives from all over the republic. This shows us that we are on the right track.

name: James Nicholson (ECR).
text: – Madam President, the news that new funding will be available for free wifi hotspots across the EU will be welcomed by local authorities and citizens who are able to avail of the scheme. As with the elimination of roaming charges, this has the potential to benefit tourists, residents and businesses alike. However, it is also clear that we have some way to go in terms of our broadband infrastructure, particularly in rural areas. In the modern era, access to the internet has become almost as important as utilities such as electricity. It is deeply concerning that there is a level of inequality in the terms of access to broadband connections. For instance, broadband provision in my own constituency of Northern Ireland lags behind the rest of the United Kingdom as a whole and, within Northern Ireland, there is a divide between urban and rural areas. I want to see our rural communities flourish and local businesses grow and remain competitive in an increasingly digitised marketplace. We need to support businesses and consumers with high-quality broadband infrastructure and equality in terms of access.

name: Marisa Matias (GUE/NGL).
text: - Madam President, welcome, Commissioner, I want to begin by thanking the rapporteur for his work. I believe that this report is important for several reasons, but above all because it places a very strong social dimension in what, I believe, is a daily necessity. The access to wireless Internet in public spaces for free and free is a project of this House of which I am proud and say it without any problem. We must, however, ensure that, for this investment to be effective, technical support, information and resources must, above all, go to the most remote areas, to rural areas, to populations and communities that they do not have access to it and I believe that, in this dimension, we will have to continue doing work. It is important to ensure that access can be financed for everyone, and therefore, once again, I welcome the work that has been done. But we have to continue evaluating so that this money, this resource, this technical support, this information does not reach the same as always, because the digital divide is a reality. I believe that this report is an important step towards combating the digital divide and we must continue to work towards that.

name: Christelle Lechevalier (ENF).
text: - Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, the project presented today aims to make very high speed internet a free service in a few privileged public areas of the Union for a budget of 120 million euros. Let’s ask ourselves, dear colleagues, what we could have done with these 120 million euros in the Internet domain. We should have used these 120 million to reduce the digital divide, at a time when only 18% of households in rural areas of the Union are connected. We should dedicate this public money to private access for businesses, for whom the internet is essential to maintain employment, and for individuals in isolated areas, because what they need is not '' a free wifi near their home, but a possibility of connection at their place of work and life. Moreover, this text is symptomatic of the excesses of the European Union. The system claims to put forward to users the "values ​​and advantages of the Union" and will therefore convey ultra-Europeanist propaganda. Likewise, it gives full decision-making power to the Union and to local communities, regardless of national interests. For these reasons, the French delegation of the ENF group will not support this initiative.

name: Angelika Niebler (PPE).
text: - Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen! I think the proposal is very good and I would like to thank the Commission and also our rapporteur and colleagues for having improved this proposal a little here. 6,000 to 8,000 municipalities are to be financed by WLAN connections. Indeed, one can say: This is a drop in the ocean. What shoud that? Why are we doing this To provide EUR 120 million for this is not the world. But I think it is very important and right, because it is an important political signal that we need nationwide internet - throughout Europe, not only in the metropolitan areas, but especially in smaller regions, in smaller municipalities and municipalities. That is why I support the proposal. But today I would also like to address a second topic and not concentrate on the 6,000 to 8,000 parishes: We have hundreds of thousands of other parishes that are not getting any funding. Above all, I would also like to say to the Commission that there are initiatives in many governments at home - including myself, in the Free State of Bavaria. We also support the expansion of broadband in our country, but then time and again we see that state aid law is applied so rigidly in Europe - also by the Commission - that it takes forever before we can ensure the expansion with our own funds. So today I would like to ask you too, Commissioner, to ensure that the state aid rules are simply applied when they are applied, so that even more can be done locally without red tape and not everything has to be financed through the European coffers.

name: Martina Werner (S&D).
text: - Madam President, Commissioner! Vouchers for setting up free WiFi in up to 8,000 municipalities in Europe - very specific and completely unbureaucratic: WiFi4EU is a great example of how Europe is also giving more people access to high-speed internet. A future-proof WLAN in rural areas can only exist if the communities themselves are connected to the broadband network and that is also a prerequisite for industrial companies to remain or for modern public services. And it is precisely then that I am worried when I look at Germany, because a measly 6.6% of households are connected to fiber optic lines. With the new EU communication code, we are now creating the conditions for investments in networks of the future. If this template is not used and instead a lot of money is poured into old transition technologies, numerous regions will be left behind. I hope that WiFi4EU is a building block that will help to finally awaken this awareness across Europe. From the end of 2017 / beginning of 2018, project proposals can be submitted and I would be very happy if a large number of municipalities were involved.

name: Seán Kelly (PPE).
text: – Madam President, let me start by saying that this is a genuinely excellent initiative and is yet another example of the value of the EU. I congratulate colleagues Zorrinho and Sander for the work they have put into bringing this forward. Internet access for all citizens is crucially important and this means that nobody should be excluded, particularly because they happen to live in rural areas. Rural growth is dependent on increased connectivity, and WiFi4EU will help in this regard and perhaps be a blueprint for similar bigger initiatives.  With this initiative, we take one of the needed steps to reduce the digital divide by putting wifi terminals in public spaces. This simple and fast financing mechanism can deliver high-quality internet quite quickly and I welcome its potential to revitalise rural communities.  As a representative of the Ireland South constituency, this is particularly relevant to me. Parts of my constituency still see some of the lowest broadband speeds in Ireland, with our average speeds being around half of those found in Dublin. Examples can be seen in places like Murroe in Limerick, Dromahane in Cork, Clonmore in Carlow and Cahir in Tipperary, all of which have to put up with internet speeds that are way below what is acceptable. While the WiFi4EU is not the ultimate solution for such areas, it would at least be a help.  I hereby invite Irish communities with poor connectivity to get their applications in for this great new initiative and reap the benefits of this excellent EU initiative, and thus make their areas more attractive to live in, more attractive for investors, and stem the tide of rural decline.

name: Patrizia Toia (S&D).
text: - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, first of all a greeting to the Commissioner for her first appearance in the Chamber, even though our committee is already working intensively with her. The initiative we are discussing today is an absolutely timely and excellent initiative, and I think it was also very much completed, compared to the initial proposal, by the precious work of my colleague Zorrinho. It is an initiative of which I just want to highlight two aspects, as other colleagues have also done. The first is that in this way Europe affirms that the Internet must be in some way democratic, that is, it must be potentially accessible to all: it must not be a further discriminant in our society but, if anything, help to break down, to reduce the differences between the opportunities it can offer to those who cannot get there alone. So this aspect, let's say, symbolic, as well as concrete, I consider it very important and I also consider it important - and I recommend to the Commissioner and to those who will concretely follow this initiative - that the image of Europe is not lost: Europe does many things but when the citizens arrive at the municipalities, Europe disappears. Here we must make it clear that Europe has made a symbolic and concrete gesture to get closer to people and communities and to offer them something useful. So let the logo remain, let the image remain, in short, this desire of Europe to be close to the citizens remains.

name: Henna Virkkunen (PPE).
text: - Mr President, high-speed telecommunications is one of the most important destinations for investment in Europe. We have set the goal that by 2020, all Europeans will have a comprehensive broadband connection and half of them will have an ultra-fast connection. At present, we know that only 70% of EU citizens have access to high-speed internet, and that this is much lower in rural areas. In order to achieve those common goals, it is estimated that we will need to invest around EUR 500 billion in the coming years, specifically in high-speed connections throughout Europe. It is an important precondition for us to be able to create a digital economy and digital services in Europe. The WiFi network initiative now being presented is an important part of this. In particular, the aim is to bring WiFi networks to rural areas, public places, for the use of residents. That is welcome and important. At the same time, however, it must be remembered that, above all, we need private investment to accelerate Europe's development into a digital union, and it is important for us to create a market-based environment that encourages companies to invest in connectivity. A good example of this is my own country, Finland, which has invested very heavily in mobile technology, and Finns use ten times more mobile data than the European average, because we have very good mobile connections and the prices are low thanks to competition. Therefore, it is also important to remember that we need to have a technology-neutral approach. Different Member States may already have very different ways of organizing internet connections, high-speed connections, and care must also be taken to ensure that these work well together.

name: Miroslav Poche (S&D).
text: - Madam President, of course I welcome the fact that a compromise has been reached on the parameters and funding of the WiFi4EU project.From my point of view, in addition to roaming in the digital field, this is one of the most tangible results in this election period, which will be quite obvious to our citizens.But I would point out two aspects that can be risky.The first is, of course, the need to maintain a geographical balance in funding and to correctly define the really relevant applicants for financial support.I am convinced that meaningful projects will be funded that will lead to the fulfillment of the original intention, but it will be necessary to strengthen control mechanisms not only at European level but also at Member State level and some synergy with European funds or alternative co-financing so that the result is fullytangible.Transparency of project financing is, in my view, crucial.

name: Pascal Arimont (PPE).
text: - Madam President, Commissioner - I would also like to welcome you to the other side of the table and I wish us all good cooperation - ladies and gentlemen! Free internet in 6,000 to 8,000 hospitals and parks, public libraries, town halls - I think that's an excellent idea! We are in a parliament here. Some say it's bad and others say it's good. Without exception, I think what we're doing here is good. Because, on the one hand, it means that Europe is becoming very concrete, and on the other hand - Mrs Niebler has just said it - it is also a signal. What is it a signal for? It is a signal that a hotspot only works where there is really internet and where there is fast internet. For us, this means that we have to work extremely hard so that there will be this fast Internet throughout Europe. There are still so-called white spots - especially in rural areas. There is no internet there at all. What used to be streets and electricity, where the public sector has invested a lot of money, is now called the Internet, and we have to spend a lot of money on it. This WiFi4EU is a signal to do this. We have to make these efforts so that the digital agenda, which we have made a big difference, is realized. I strongly advised the municipalities in my constituency to apply for this initiative. It's a good initiative. The bottom line is: let's do it and let's do it unbureaucratically. Then everyone benefits from it.

name: Luděk Niedermayer (PPE).
text: – Madam President, in the 21st century, high-quality internet connection, not just in large cities but also in small, remote villages, is key for the successful development of our society. We all know the reasons: internet access gives people access to information and the ability to get entertainment. It is key for government to provide online services to serve citizens better at lower cost and it is also essential for job creation and support for tourism that is very vital for these small communities. There are hundreds and hundreds of companies that provide internet connections, but their focus is on large communities. In small places, for economic reasons, they do not do it because the investments are not matched by the revenues and, as a result, people there do not have access to services and this will undermine development of their communities. This is exactly the moment when the governments should step in and some of them do, but some of them do not. As a consequence, people will be at a big disadvantage. We should assign importance to that because these people are Europeans, they should have at least the chance, and this is where the project can play a very important role if it is implemented properly. We are not talking about huge amounts of money and a huge impact, but we are talking about good things, about an important message and example, an example that I believe will be followed, that is why it has my full support.

name: Fernando Ruas (PPE).
text: - Madam President, Commissioner, it is a pleasure to see you in these new roles. I just wanted to leave two brief notes here: firstly, to congratulate myself, and to congratulate the Commission, on presenting this proposal. It has a system of vouchers and simplified applications totally innovative, capable of ensuring the financing of free Wi-Fi equipment in several public spaces. This measure will cover areas located in at least 6,000 municipalities in all Member States - a number that may rise to 8,000 municipalities if there are sufficient applications. And a second note to greet the work of this House, the rapporteur Carlos Zorrinho, who was able to make considerable improvements in the initial document in a very fruitful joint work led by the ITRE Commission, but which involved three other commissions through opinions. At the REGI Committee, of which I was the shadow rapporteur, I proposed several changes to the Commission's initial proposal, which I welcome in this report, and I refer specifically to the importance of removing language barriers on the access page and the inclusion of the principles of economic, social and territorial cohesion in the text of this regulation, moreover in accordance with Article 174 of the Lisbon Treaty. I will end by asking the Commission only for a quick implementation of these constant ideas, therefore, of this regulation, within the territory of the Union.

name: Λευτέρης Χριστοφόρου (PPE).
text: - Madam President, I consider this a happy occasion and we are delighted that Mariya Gabriel is at the helm and head of the digital economy, who has both strong will and determination, but also the vision to achieve the great and ambitious goals of the digital revolution and the digital economy. of the European Union. And this is a small but very big leap in the process of achieving great ambitious goals for the digital revolution in the European Union and no one can defy it. Having "WiFi for you" today essentially gives communities access to free WiFi access is a step we welcome and support. At the same time, however, there must be other steps to strengthen free access and access for other citizens, both vulnerable groups and retirees, as well as in isolated areas.

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D).
text: - Madam President, Commissioner, congratulations to you for the initiative and congratulations also to Mr Zorrinho for his report because indeed, the digital divide in the rural world has increased considerably because the liberalization of the sector has everything simply because the investments of the private companies were initially centered on the cities. It is obviously an excellent initiative that public authorities, and in particular in Europe, come to help reduce this digital divide. Why? Because rural territories - and it is more the local elected representative who speaks today in front of you - are also living areas where people have to work. I am thinking of doctors, I am thinking of an orthopedic surgeon in my town in Anthisnes who does not have access to his patients' protocols. I think of architects, graphic designers or students who find it hard to study today when they receive documents over the Internet and they don't have broadband. This initiative is therefore going in the right direction - as long as it calls for others - and this is why I obviously also call on many rural municipalities to join this process and to ensure, with the Union European Union, that this digital divide be reduced.

name: Ruža Tomašić (ECR).
text: - Madam President, promoting internet connectivity on islands and in rural areas in general is extremely important for countries like Croatia. Local communities in these areas are rapidly losing population, especially young people, which of course seriously endangers their survival. Today, when a good portion of new business depends on the internet, strengthening internet connectivity in rural areas can very well help retain residents. Digital literacy of the elderly population can also have positive effects and make life easier for people away from administrative centers. Giving preference to local companies in the procurement, installation and maintenance of local wireless connectivity equipment is another quality proposal. But I wish this initiative didn’t just stick to WiFi hotspots because it looks like a cosmetic solution in the context of the actual state of infrastructure in rural areas. We need capital investment in internet infrastructure, and publicly available hotspots can then be a welcome addition.

name: Davor Škrlec (Verts/ALE).
text: - Madam President, I consider this to be a very important topic and I fully support the Commission's initiative to free up funding to enable these internet access points in remote areas.I think this is a good move to show how the European Union is approaching the local level, how it is approaching its citizens, and I think that the results of the referendum in the UK show that these areas were not the ones that were not for the rest of the UK.Britain in the European Union.The role is of course very important to establish the initiatives launched by the European Commission, namely Smart Island and Smart Village.So, how to bring the internet closer, how to bring new technologies closer to remote communities.Also, that this is a very good message for Member States that with certain investments, which can be and, of course, affordable, can enable citizens to actively participate in local government.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (NI).
text: - Madam President, high-speed public accessibility is an indicator of the effectiveness of e-government services with free and unrestricted easy access, a geographical balance that ensures coherence, a fair distribution of capacity between users and the adoption of optimal and adaptive technologies. . The non-commercial nature of targeted intervention, the limited financial resources and the administrative burden of local public services require the fight against bureaucracy. However, the promoted use of the "coupon" system and the sampling control practically do not ensure sound financial management. The rules for effective public funding are ensured through long-term sustainable and sustainable actions, with a view to maximizing interoperability.

name: Marijana Petir (PPE).
text: - Madam President, I congratulate my colleague Zorrinha on this report and I am also extremely happy that our former colleague, Mrs Mariya Gabriel, is in charge of this sector. She understands the needs of rural areas well and knows that over 41% of people living in rural areas have never used the internet. Therefore, it is important that this initiative is aimed precisely at rural areas and all those areas where there is a risk of depopulation and abandonment. In order for people to remain living in the countryside, we must provide them with adequate social and communal infrastructure, and the exchange of communication and information is important because it enables faster use of public services, faster job opening, competitiveness of rural sectors such as agriculture and forestry. Since I personally live in the countryside, I can testify to how difficult it is to work and function if you have bad internet and if your system crashes. Not all Member States have equal opportunities and starting points, so I commend and support this initiative.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D).
text: - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, the Internet and digital connectivity are now having a decisive impact on our private and professional life. Access to free local wireless connectivity in busy places can represent considerable added value and transform idle and transit times into productive, relaxing and informative moments. The regulation that we will approve today provides for a simple financing mechanism for the installation of local wireless access points, and is aimed at bodies with public service responsibilities. Given the limited funding available for each project and the large number of potential applications, an administrative system must be ensured that guarantees rapid and effective decisions. The principle of geographical balance between the different Member States - and within the Member States - must be guaranteed as regards access to the initiative's resources. To ensure the targeted nature of the intervention and realize the maximum public benefit, funding should be limited to cases where no free access point, public or private, providing broadband connectivity is available.

name: Mariya Gabriel
text: member of the Commission. - Madam President, first of all, once again, Mr Zorrinho, congratulations on your work. I would also like to thank the Members of the European Parliament for their opinions, suggestions and remarks. I would like to conclude by distinguishing two aspects. On the one hand, the Commission considers that the approved text strikes a good balance and that it provides for more clarity on several important issues that you have raised. Yes, an information campaign is planned. Data protection is important and it is intended. We haven't neglected the importance of small towns, nor seniors. As regards the budget, the Commission welcomes the joint declaration of the three institutions to maintain a global budget for the initiative of 120 million euros. I am also counting on Parliament to ensure that the impact of this initiative will be significant and that this initiative will have its extension and added value. I would also like to clarify a point that was raised by several members. We have added value in terms of European Union action. I remind you that the identification will be unique for the whole European Union. To answer Ms. Toia's question, a logo is also planned. Then, what about the next steps? Once this new legislation enters into force, we will proceed with the modification of the work program of the Interconnection Mechanism in Europe and, immediately after, we will open the portal for registrations and providers of wifi services. We are also starting a dialogue with the Member States, who have an important role to play in the implementation of this initiative for it to be successful. We are working hard to make the entire application process extremely easy, which you also raised. The absence of red tape will avoid the use of intermediaries or consultants, and we know how important this is for small towns.Municipalities will register directly through an online portal.I am aware that the initiative has created a lot of expectations and we hope to be able to award the first 1,000 vouchers to municipalities across Europe at the start of 2018. Dear Members of the European Parliament,aspects that you considered important did not escape me: continuous assessment, social dimension, rural areas, links with the objectives of the digital single market, code, spectrum, connectivity.I thank Mr Buzek, Mrs Werner, Mrs Niebler.I simply suggest that you continue to work on it together.

name: Carlos Zorrinho
text: reporter. - I would like to thank you again for the constructive support of all my colleagues and the European Commission. After the success that was Roam like at home, we now have a new challenge: High Quality, Free Wi-Fi near home. It is the type of programs that link the European project to the concrete needs of citizens and, as the Commissioner said, we now have enormous potential to provide innovative services. The contents are very important for the success of this project and, at the same time, also another challenge that is to disseminate digital skills. This program solves almost everything, except the lack of digital skills of many Europeans, but it challenges us to respond in relation to that. This is a path that we have to travel. This is just a first step - I have two minutes, Madam President - in a long way, but I am convinced that, having managed to mobilize, in a complex technical negotiation 120 million euros to start, we will be able to gather structural funds, national funds , public and private, to have a very robust, very strong and very important process for the future of Europe.

name: President. –
text: The debate is closed. The vote will take place shortly. Written statements (Rule 162)

name: Daniel Buda (PPE)
text: signed up. - Investing in high-capacity networks and ensuring internet access for all citizens throughout the European Union, including in rural and remote areas, are absolutely necessary to stimulate innovation, social inclusion and increase competitiveness. Having the opportunity to provide internet access to tourists, local small and medium-sized enterprises, especially oriented towards tourism, will have the opportunity to grow, becoming more attractive to citizens everywhere. Also, in agriculture, access to high-speed networks and information and communication technology services would be an extremely important step in achieving the goal of setting up young farmers. The total number of farmers in the EU has fallen rapidly over the last decade, from 14.5 million in 2005 to 10.7 million in 2013. Over the same period, the number of young farmers has fallen from 3.3 million to 2.3 million. However, if we want agriculture to be sustainable for generations, it is vital that young farmers receive effective support, both in financial support from the EU and in the provision of the internet. Let's not forget, internet connectivity is not a luxury, but an urgent need of the modern world without which we will not make the desired progress.

name: Tamás Deutsch (PPE)
text: in writing. - With the support of the WiFi4EU initiative, free WiFi hotspots will be set up in local communities (public spaces, parks, hospitals, libraries and other public places) throughout the Union by 2020. WiFi4EU is a very forward-looking initiative, as free wireless internet access in public areas benefits all citizens. The Union will provide € 120 million to implement the initiative, which will provide funding for equipment needed for public WiFi services in 6-8000 municipalities. Public administrations (local governments, municipal associations) that want to provide free WiFi access with such a service in public areas not covered by public or private companies can apply for the program. I welcome the fact that the negotiations between the EU institutions have succeeded in strengthening the geographical balance between the Member States in terms of access to resources. The WiFi4EU initiative is in line with the goal of the Digital Welfare Program to make the Internet accessible to everyone, so I support as many Hungarian public administrations as possible to apply for the program.

name: András Gyürk (PPE)
text: in writing.- I welcome the first reading agreement.WIFI4EU is an initiative that will help us achieve our main goal, which is to make the Internet accessible to all European citizens.Of course, we don’t have to think about a revolutionary change now, but I trust that some small, local communities can be greatly helped by the initiative and make everyday life easier.It is included in the proposal that the distribution of financial support will be geographically balanced.This is also important because the quality of coverage in rural areas is still significantly worse than in urban areas.I am particularly pleased that the regulation emphasizes the priority of local small and medium-sized enterprises in implementation.

name: Elżbieta Katarzyna Łukacijewska (PPE)
text: in writing. - The WIFI4EU initiative is a proposal that will contribute to strengthening the development of a more inclusive European information society. President Juncker proposed that by 2020 the main centers of social life in every European village and city should be equipped with free wireless internet access. This will be carried out in accordance with the plan, the assumption of which is equal access to Internet connectivity regardless of place of residence or income level. The proposed amendments are intended to better regulate the principles on which the entire project is based. The issue of the development of telecommunications infrastructure, and in this case Internet connections, is extremely important nowadays. This affects the development of each institution, but also the quality of life of its residents. I live in the Bieszczady Mountains, in south-eastern Poland, where even access to the mobile network is limited in places, not to mention the internet connection. As a representative of this region, I believe that the initiative to provide better telecommunications connectivity in areas without it will benefit overall social and economic development. It is hard to imagine that some European citizens today do not have access to such a common way of communicating with their surroundings as the Internet. Development is largely digital, for which we will not be ready until we increase the availability of internet connections.

name: Ева Майдел (PPE)
text: In written form. - Today we are not just voting for a program for 120 million euros. I want to believe that today we are doing much more - another step in two transformations that the EU needs so much. The first is Europe's digital transformation, which allows us to catch up with our global competitors in the digital economy and innovation. The second transformation is that of citizens' perception of Europe. With programs like WiFi4EU, we are changing the image of the EU, which no longer submits a form, but is useful to people. So WIFI4EU is largely Transformation4EU. Beyond these perspectives, however, we must realize that we are in the middle of the road to achieving wireless internet coverage. From now on, we as MEPs must work together with local authorities to make sure that WIFI4EU does not reach only those who already know what broadband is. It is important that he gets to where he can create more chances for knowledge, for new endeavors and ideas.

name: Csaba Molnár (S&D)
text: in writing. - States that recognize the importance of disseminating digital technology in all areas of life are successful. And not only in the capitals, but also in the micro-regions. That is why it is painful that according to the latest measurements, in 2017, one fifth of Hungarians have never used the Internet before. The situation is even worse if we look only at the rural regions: in the Great Plain and Southern Transdanubia, three out of 10 people do not have an internet connection. And only a third of the poorest Hungarians can go online. This means that 2.5 million people have no chance of participating in the digital world. The spread of the Internet and digital technologies is not an end in itself, at the end of which more computers or larger monitors will be sent to households and schools. Digital tools make it possible to increase opportunities, broaden job opportunities, lifelong learning and create equal opportunities. Whoever has an internet can find a job more easily, work from home, and learn a foreign language easily. In the 21st century, the Internet is an indispensable fundamental right to participate in the information society, to eliminate inequalities, and to promote personal development. That is why we have long supported guaranteeing the fundamental right of access to the Internet at EU level.

name: Laurenţiu Rebega (ENF)
text: signed up. - As I said before, I wholeheartedly support the idea that any increase in internet connectivity is a step in the direction of economic development. We are in a position to provide a free service to European citizens. A service that means, first and foremost, technology. Like it or not, the smartphone, tablet or laptop have become indispensable accessories for modern man. The program I voted for today leads to a democratization of access to the infosphere and, through it, to an increase in social inclusion. But there are also criticizable aspects. The deployment of this program under the centralized umbrella of the Union makes this inclusion a reality in a virtual world rather than in the physical reality of the community in which any user lives. In this way, a deep cleavage could be reached. Some areas will have free internet access, while remaining without access to drinking water or sewage. I would therefore like to warn of the danger that, for many citizens in less developed areas, this program will become a source of alienation and not one of progress. This program alone does not solve the problems of disadvantaged communities. At the same time, investment is needed in the classical economy.

name: Theodor Dumitru Stolojan (PPE)
text: signed up.- I welcome the European Commission's initiative to allocate € 120 million to some 6,000 municipalities to improve internet access.This initiative will have to be fully exploited, especially by the municipalities of the Member States with a lower level of economic development.The Internet and, more broadly, the digital economy are a sure way to increase productivity and achieve greater convergence with economically developed Member States.

name: Claudiu Ciprian Tănăsescu (S&D)
text: signed up. - The WiFi4EU initiative, announced by President Juncker in September 2016, is part of the telecommunications package and aims to promote free Wi-Fi connectivity for citizens and visitors in public spaces such as parks, squares, public buildings, libraries, shopping centers. health and museums everywhere in the EU through a free common Wi-Fi portal: WiFi4EU. Obviously, we agree that every European citizen should have Wi-Fi connectivity, no matter where they live or how much they earn, but WiFi4EU must comply with EU data protection rules, as well as neutrality. network and IT security. Ensuring free access to high-speed broadband services is essential to building a digital union that leaves no one behind. Moreover, free, non-discriminatory local wireless connectivity could help reduce the digital divide, especially in lagging communities in terms of digital literacy, including in rural and remote areas, and increase quality. life by facilitating access to electronic services (e-health and e-government). The importance of this initiative also stems from improving digital skills and promoting the development of local small and medium-sized enterprises.

name: President. –
text: The next item is the report by Jerzy Buzek, on behalf of the Committee on Industry, Research and Energy, on measures to safeguard the security of gas supply (COM(2016)0052 – C8-0035/2016 – 2016/0030(COD)) (A8-0310/2016).

name: Jerzy Buzek
text: rapporteur. - Madam President! Hello, Commissioner Cañete, and I would like to thank you immediately for your very intensive participation in our negotiations. They lasted several dozen hours. We finished the last round in the morning. There was something unusual about these negotiations. We have decided to make some concessions flexibly with regard to the many countries that expressed reservations about the original solutions given by the Commission. I would not like to list all the countries, but they were certainly Italian, German, French, Polish, Austrian, Hungarian and so on, and although we made such moves, we managed to end the negotiations with a very good regulation that ensures gas supplies to our homes, other protected recipients, hospitals, emergency services, nursing homes, hospices always, even in situations of the greatest crisis, which took place in the European Union. This is also a clue for negotiating the next elements of our energy package. If we want to get a good or very good result, we also have to be flexible, because our citizens may not understand geopolitics, but they feel when their homes are turned off gas in winter. One country can cause such a crisis, but one country will definitely not solve it, hence this regulation is so important. I will tell you about three things that have been dealt with thanks to the flexibility we have shown. First, the legally binding solidarity mechanism in the event of serious gas supply problems and the list of protected customers. This is the first time we have reached such an agreement. Secondly, regional cooperation that did not exist before, i.e. risk assessment, preparation of preventive actions, emergency plans, the introduction by Parliament of so-called emergency supply corridors - this was a response to the concerns of several countries about mandatory regional cooperation, which remained together with those emergency corridors. And finally, more transparency gas contracts. Please remember that in this regulation we are talking about external supplies, which constitute definitely more than 50% of the European Union's gas needs, so it is these external contracts that determine our security within the European Union. The most important contracts will be available for inspection by the European Commission and national institutions, and in justified cases, the European Commission may also see other gas supply contracts. This is important if we are to feel really good on the European Union scale. I would like to mention once again that we have had help in this regard, in principle, from the entire European Commission, and not only from certain specialized services. We are also accompanied by Director Ristori, who was in the hall during all the negotiations, for which we would like to thank you. I would also like to mention the Maltese Presidency, which is now over, but its contribution to a good solution has really been solid, and these are our conclusions for the future.

name: Miguel Arias Cañete
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, I warmly welcome the ambitious and well-balanced agreement reached between the European Parliament, the Council and the Commission at the last trilogue in April on the review of the Regulation on Security of Gas Supply. It is a major political success on which we have worked hard together in record time. This is also thanks to you, Mr Buzek, and I congratulate you on your excellent work and thank you and all shadow-rapporteurs for your commitment in this file. The review of the Regulation on Security of Gas Supply is an important milestone in rolling out the Energy Union Strategy. This agreement now completes the Energy Security package proposed by the Commission just last year, in February 2016. One of the Energy Union objectives is to ensure secure, sustainable, competitive and affordable energy supplies for European consumers – for households and for businesses. Europe’s energy market is changing rapidly and significantly. While the current Regulation on Security of Gas Supply of 2010 has already significantly improved Member States’ preparedness for a gas disruption, it was clear from the stress tests conducted in 2014 that the instruments available under that Regulation needed substantial improvements. The new Regulation that is subject to a vote today brings a step change, enhancing and making operational the necessary instruments to prepare for and mitigate potential gas disruption: regional cooperation becomes real and operational;  better transparency on gas supply contracts will help improve the risk assessment; the spirit of solidarity is for the first time translated into concrete action and cooperation between Member States so that no household in any Member State remains in the cold during a gas supply crisis. I am very happy that the most important elements of the Commission proposals have been preserved or even strengthened during the negotiations. Let me just highlight some of these elements, starting with regional cooperation. The current Regulation includes only an optional cooperation between neighbours. In the new Regulation, regional cooperation becomes mandatory and will take place in the risk groups created on the basis of the assessment of major transnational risks, drawing also on insights from European Union-wide simulations done by ENTSOG (the European Network of Transmission System Operators for Gas). The regional and national risk assessments will provide a sound basis for the national plans, with regional chapters containing meaningful cross-border measures. The spirit of solidarity is a cornerstone of the new Regulation, ensuring that all households will receive gas supplies even during a crisis. With the new processes laid down in the Regulation, for the first time, solidarity is not only a political declaration but an obligation and a concrete way to help. Finally, transparency. Information exchange and the transparency of gas supply contracts is also significantly strengthened and will allow for a more complete and in-depth assessment of risk to security of supply. First, the companies will provide contractual information to their national authorities. If the national authority has doubts about possible risks for security of supply related with the contract, it will notify the contract to the Commission. The notification threshold of 28% for all gas supply contracts – existing and new – is well balanced. It is important to note that at any time the Commission retains the power to ask for any contracts if it is concerned that a given contract is relevant for the assessment of the security of supply. And confidentiality will be guaranteed. The information on gas supply contracts will be sent to the Commission in a non-aggregated but anonymised form. Energy efficiency will be taken into account throughout the Regulation, in particular when designing preventive measures. With the new Regulation, cooperation on gas security of supply with the Contracting Parties of the Energy Community will become much closer and stronger. All the instruments provided through this new Regulation will make the Member States, and the European Union as a whole, better prepared for a gas crisis and better equipped to mitigate a gas crisis should it arise. On this basis, I am confident that the vote in plenary today will give a strong backing to the important agreement that we have achieved together.

name: Ruža Tomašić
text: rapporteur for the opinion of the REGI Committee. - Madam President, the gas supply crises we have witnessed several times in the last 15 years have hinted that the European Union, if it wants energy security and long-term stability, will have to change its energy policy, but also the rules of conduct in a crisis. This proposal is an important step in the right direction. Any kind of crisis in the Union causes the same pattern of behavior in the member states, and that is self-closure. In the event of a future energy crisis, it is important to ensure that cross-border gas distribution is not interrupted, and this is well addressed in this proposal. The report strongly promotes the diversity of energy sources and renewables. I would agree with that, but with the remark that our energy goals must be aligned with the fiscal reality. We should invest the most in those sources that offer the most value for money and create the least damage, and these are often not the sources that certain lobbies push hard.

name: Krišjānis Kariņš
text: On behalf of the PPE Group. - Madam President. Commissioner! In any market, a level playing field is important for everyone. The gas market is no exception. It is very important that if we want to increase security of gas supply, we must also strengthen the market. What is important in this regulation is that we have not only found out how the Member States will help each other, but we are also significantly increasing the so-called transparency - what is happening with gas contracts between a European consumer and a third country supplier. Specifically, what is it about? We have a huge asymmetry in Europe. We buy a third of our gas from one supplier, Russia, but there is one monopoly export company, Gazprom, on the Russian side. One company. On the European side, we are divided: 28 Member States and many more gas companies. They have all the information, not on the European side. They have price control, not the European side. With this regulation, it will now also give the European Commission the right to look at these gas supply contracts, these important contracts, to ensure that European laws are complied with and, above all, that European consumers have a high level of gas security, but that we do not overpay for this natural resource.

name: Dan Nica
text: on behalf of the S & D group. - Madam President, Commissioner, unfortunately, in 2015, more than half of the EU-28's gross domestic energy consumption came from imported sources. This Regulation is extremely important because it lays down provisions aimed at ensuring the security of gas supply by ensuring the proper and continuous functioning of the internal market in natural gas, allowing exceptional measures to be applied when the market is no longer able to supply the necessary quantities of gas, including a measure of last resort solidarity. Responsibilities between natural gas undertakings, Member States and the Union are clearly set out, both in terms of preventive action and the response to actual supply disruptions. This Regulation also establishes transparent mechanisms, in a spirit of solidarity, for coordinating the planning of measures and responses to emergencies at national, regional and Union level. Parliament has succeeded in improving the text - and we congratulate Mr Buzek and the shadow rapporteurs here - so that it better reflects the principle of solidarity, while protecting fair compensation for natural gas companies. This is an important step towards strengthening the European Union's energy security and, in the event of a serious gas supply crisis, EU countries will have to help their neighbors, without neglecting their protected consumers, in order to prevent European citizens from remaining without heating in cold weather. We must emphasize that solidarity only applies to citizens and to services such as hospitals, schools and so on. The principle of transparency is a key element, as Member States will have to notify new contracts or changes immediately after their conclusion. To ensure transparency, reliability, existing contracts should also be notified.I emphasize: and existing contracts.The notification obligation should also include all trade agreements relevant to the execution of the gas supply contract, including relevant agreements that could be related to infrastructure, storage and any other matter important for the security of gas supply.

name: Edward Czesak
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. - Madam President, Thank you for giving the floor. I also thank the rapporteur and the shadow rapporteurs for their cooperation, and I congratulate the rapporteurs. The situation on our eastern border is changing rapidly and is becoming more and more worrying. This regulation, which aims to ensure the security of gas supply, is therefore a good step in good time. The essential elements of this regulation are the facilitation of two-way gas flows, increased exchange of important security of supply information with the European Commission and national authorities, and enhanced cooperation with the energy community. This will enable a more coordinated response to future threats. While I believe the adoption of this regulation is a step in the right direction, the European Union and its security of gas supply are facing a new challenge, namely Nord Stream II. This geopolitical project undermines European solidarity and is against the spirit of this regulation and one of the main goals of the Energy Union, namely the diversification of gas supplies. In the spirit of this regulation, we must therefore act consistently in order to deal effectively with this problem. The discussion on the Commission's statement on Nord Stream II will take place on Thursday and I hope it will confirm the need for uniform measures to guarantee the security of gas supplies to all European Union countries.

name: Pavel Telička
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Madam President, this is a very important file and marks real progress: it was politically difficult, politically sensitive and also very demanding technically. We have already spoken today about regional cooperation, solidarity among Member States, protected customers, and transparency of contracts. I would also add – something that has not been mentioned – that we have also included fair compensation, so we are still primarily market—based, and we are of course talking about last resort. All that is key because from now on our citizens, my compatriots, should feel that there is more energy security and that contracts are not being concluded somewhere by someone where we do not know exactly what is in them and whether it will affect us or not. We should be in a position where the Commission will eventually be assessing the implications of that. So major progress has been made and I think that all that you have said today, all the positive elements, are absolutely legitimate and valid.  On the background to that, I would like to draw attention to one important element. We have been speaking for a couple of years now about energy union and a functioning energy market – all those elements that I have mentioned and that you have mentioned – but those of us who participated in the negotiations know how difficult it was and that it was quite often horse trading about the percentage, about real transparency and about solidarity. To those who spoke quite often two years ago about the crucial importance of the energy union, I must say that in the Council those were quite often the bottlenecks of these negotiations. I do not think that it is coincidental that we had a very difficult round of talks on transparency, because some Member States still feel that they would do it better, and that, if they had the possibly to negotiate on their own, they would be better off. So let us remind ourselves that Parliament has played an important and crucial role with good interaction with the Commission, but the idea and the objectives of the energy union are not yet deeply rooted in the Member States. So let us make sure that we implement thoroughly what we have managed to negotiate.  (Applause)

name: Xabier Benito Ziluaga
text: on behalf of the GUE / NGL Group. - Madam President, another step forward in the Energy Union's gas strategy; another European regulation to perpetuate dependence on this fossil fuel that is tried to disguise as clean or non-polluting. Natural gas has, the truth, little natural. Rather we should refer to it as dirty gas or fossil gas. According to scientific studies, this gas has a global warming capacity eighty-six times greater than carbon dioxide, making it actually a strange way to fight climate change. With the argument of the risk of new cuts in the supply of Russian gas, the European Commission takes the opportunity to extend new infrastructures and new connections to third countries, despite the fact that the existing infrastructures for imports are used at 58% of their capacity, despite that gas consumption declines year by year and despite the fact that the Commission inflates its gas consumption predictions year by year. The only way to avoid gas risks is to reduce gas consumption, and now we have a fantastic opportunity with the revision of the Directives on renewable energy and energy efficiency. However, the European Commission has only proposed a 30% target, knowing that an additional 1% would reduce gas imports by 4% annually, up to a possible target of 40%.
