All this without increasing methane emissions and without building expensive infrastructures that citizens pay out of their pockets, as is the case of Castor, which the commissioner will know very well. Gas is better under the ground.

name: Claude Turmes
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Madam President, we should be extremely proud of what we have achieved with this legislation, under the leadership of Jerzy Buzek, with a good negotiation team where some of us had to play the bad guys at certain moments to move the show forward, and very good cooperation with the Commission. I am happy to see Mr Arias Cañete, but also Mr Ristori, whose services helped us a lot.  What did we achieve here? This is concrete solidarity. We now have a solution for one of the biggest divides in Europe, which was that Gazprom and Russia could abuse not only markets, but also gas, to put political pressure on eastern Europe. With this legislation I think we have a real weapon against this and it is important that we got it. It was a bit shameful that we had an uphill fight against Germany, France, Austria, the Netherlands, a bit of Belgium; western European governments not understanding why it is so important for eastern Europe to have this solidarity.  I am so proud that in this House this divide between western Europe and eastern Europe did not play a role, and that I and Theresa Griffin, we stood with eastern Europe in fighting Germany and France to get this legislation.  The second thing we should be proud of is that this is the first piece of energy legislation where we go beyond our dilemma, which is everything only at one national level or everything only at EU level. This is the first piece of EU legislation in which regional cooperation along the pipelines has been enshrined and where Member States, before considering national politics, have to sit together and share openly information about where they are in a crisis situation. This should also now be the basis of our electricity legislation: on security of supply, on markets, I would even say in the future, on renewable developments. We should do more at regional level. So I want to thank colleagues very much for this brilliant exercise of parliamentary pressure to get things done.

name: Christelle Lechevalier
text: on behalf of the ENF group. - Madam President, officially, the two main objectives of this text are to improve transparency in the European gas sector and to strengthen solidarity between Member States in order to prevent and alleviate supply crises. In reality, the project that is proposed to us today seems to us to have as a priority an entirely different objective, which is to further liberalize and federate the European gas market. This new regulation seeks to require Member States to obtain Commission approval to enter into intergovernmental agreements in an area where it is natural for them to defend their economic and possibly geopolitical interests. Moreover, if we validate this project, it will enter into force in just twenty days, without even the national parliaments having been consulted. The objective of the Commission also seems to be to impose its geopolitical choices on the States by imposing Qatar and the United States where certain States have embarked on large-scale projects to obtain Russian gas. Two Member States - Austria and Bulgaria - have already issued unfavorable opinions on this project, denouncing the violation of the principle of subsidiarity and national sovereignties. Our group shares this position. (The speaker refused a "blue card" question from Claude Turmes (Rule 162 (8) of the Rules of Procedure))

name: Zoltán Balczó (NI).
text: - Madam President, the regulation on security of gas supply clarifies a number of important useful technical cooperation issues. At the same time, it is quite clear that the basis of security is whether there are sufficient energy sources and whether there are enough interchangeable transport routes. It is quite clear that Russian natural gas cannot be abandoned by the European Union, so safety would be provided by alternative routes, so it is incomprehensible that South Stream has been thwarted by the European Union due to different competition rules, while North Stream 2 is not a new alternative. allows. The current regulation infringes the principle of subsidiarity in several respects, the regions to be set up in the event of supply disruptions would be drawn up by the Commission on a delegated basis, and the Commission has virtually a veto over cooperation with third countries, which violates Member States' autonomy and interests.

name: András Gyürk (PPE).
text: - Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, allow me first and foremost to thank Jerzy Buzek for his work, he had plenty to do, because the first proposal that the Commission put on the table unfortunately had several wounds. Examples are the ill-considered list of regions, the double standard of accountability and the weak definition of solidarity actions. The report shows a significant improvement on all these points. Instead of pre-fixed regional groups, regions are formed along the risks. The compromise figure reached on the reporting threshold dispels the appearance of any difference between old and new Member States. With regard to solidarity actions, we find a much more detailed description of the conditions under which and how the Member States should help each other. Ladies and gentlemen, I believe that guaranteeing the security of Europe's gas supply is an issue that we must constantly address. With more and more experience, the revision of the security of supply regulation will therefore, we accept, be a constant task. However, we can safely say that this report will further strengthen regional cooperation and solidarity, which is essential in the energy sector, especially in the countries of Central and Eastern Europe.

name: Martina Werner (S&D).
text: - Madam President, Commissioner! The new European regulation to guarantee a secure gas supply makes us fit in Europe for coming gas crises. Experience from recent crises and the European Commission's stress tests have clearly shown that national measures are no longer sufficient. From now on the solidarity principle applies. From now on, neighboring member states must support each other in crises to secure gas supplies for households and social institutions. In addition, for the first time, Member States' prevention and emergency plans must include regional chapters. In concrete terms, this means that even before a possible crisis, member states have to think carefully about how they will work together in an emergency. Energy efficiency is recognized as a measure that reduces our dependence on energy supplies from third countries. From now on, energy efficiency must be taken into account when drawing up national prevention plans. The safest and cheapest energy is always only that which does not have to be produced in the first place.

name: Jaromír Kohlíček (GUE/NGL).
text: - Madam President, the European Union has experienced several crises in the field of energy supply in the past. The supply of gas after the crisis that occurred after the interruption before 2010 was to be ensured by the directive on strategic stocks of this medium. Each state is obliged to have a sufficient supply corresponding to 90 days of consumption in the winter. In addition to this measure, it was decided to build a north-south gas pipeline connection as a matter of urgency. At present, new possibilities related to the supply of liquefied natural gas have appeared on the European Union natural gas market. The market is thus gradually diversifying and, regardless of the preparation of the new regulation, security of supply is increasing. Efforts to significantly influence the situation and slow down the preparation of the North-South gas pipeline connections by Poland are currently the greatest potential threat to gas supplies to the countries of the European Union. It is completely incomprehensible to me that this is a hard, negative attitude towards the construction of alternative gas pipelines supplying the European Union from the south, specifically South Stream. Because Jerzy Buzek's report contains a number of positive moments, it has my support.

name: Tim Aker (EFDD).
text: – Mr President, it is quite something when Scottish Power has its head office in Bilbao, Spain. Many constituents will be surprised to find that a majority of power companies operating in the United Kingdom are either owned by foreign companies or foreign governments. In 2011, these companies were exposed by a national newspaper as hiking prices in the UK way above and beyond prices in their own countries. Prices are hiked in the UK to subsidise lower prices at home. As always, it is the UK that pays, and pay we do!  Millions of Brits face the tough choice each winter between heating and eating. We suffered tens of thousands of excess winter deaths. In plain English, that is folk who would otherwise be alive if they could afford decent heating. This debate is about security of gas supply. The surest way to do that is to ensure energy is readily available to those that need it most – our elderly and vulnerable. If it means bringing British energy back under British control to reduce prices, then so be it.  (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Michael Theurer (ALDE)
text: Ask about the “blue card” procedure.- Colleague!You have complained that in the UK energy companies are foreign-owned or even owned by foreign governments.Are you seriously of the opinion that the European Union prevented the UK from having shares in or ownership of energy companies?And what are you proposing to the UK government to get their own energy companies back?In any case, I don't think the EU stopped Britain from running its own energy companies.

name: Tim Aker (EFDD)
text: blue-card answer. – In some ways the rules of this place and the single market prevent the British Government from taking an active role in the economy, and Mr Corbyn will not be able to fulfil his programme if we are still part of the single market or part of the European Union.  Outside of it, we have new opportunities where the government, if it wishes to take a golden share or own energy companies, will be free to do so. I think that when we have got tens of thousands of people dying every year because they cannot afford to heat their homes, then everything – every option – should be on the table.

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (NI).
text: - Mr President, gas is the most important factor, not only for the European Union economy but also for the survival of people in large areas with difficult weather conditions. For this reason, security of gas supply is a key objective of the European Union 's energy strategy. Currently 50% of the consumed natural gas is produced from natural sources. The rest is provided by third countries and mainly by Russia. In order for the European Union to avoid the consequences of a possible disruption of this gas supply, it must rely on gas production from domestic sources. Based on the current data, the European Union has a first-class opportunity to exploit the large reserves of natural gas that exist in the plots of the Aphrodite field in Cyprus, as well as in the Herodotus basin south of Crete, but also in other areas of Greece. If it succeeds, and with proper design of supply routes, it will be able to achieve energy security in gas.

name: Theodor Dumitru Stolojan (PPE).
text: - Mr President, I would like to thank Mr Buzek, rapporteur, and my colleagues who have worked and negotiated this important report with the Council.I fully support the measures provided to ensure the security of natural gas supply - both the measures concerning the efforts that each Member State must make and the necessary solidarity between Member States when a country is facing a natural gas crisis.I think it is an important step in what we all want, that single European energy market.However, I would like to emphasize that we cannot talk about a real security of natural gas supply in Europe as long as we do not have pipelines connecting the Caspian Sea basin, the Black Sea basin, where explorations are currently being made, and deposits have been discovered.of important natural gas in southern and central Europe.Unfortunately, I believe that the European Union's efforts in this direction are still insufficient.

name: Miapetra Kumpula-Natri (S&D).
text: - This report is an important part of the EU's changing and intensifying energy policy. I would like to thank my committee for a good report that promotes cooperation between countries to ensure security of gas supply. In addition, the report contains excellent ways of improving energy security. For example, my own country, Finland, relies on one import pipeline from Russia, but is in a better position than Central Europe because gas does not heat individual houses much. District heating can make diverse use of different energy sources, and extending its use to other parts of Europe would reduce the risk of a single fuel. The same is true for decentralized production of renewables. In addition to connections between countries, the report lists energy efficiency, virtual gas reserves, storage and liquefied natural gas terminals as preventive measures. Security should be seen as part of other energy issues under discussion. The directive on the energy performance of buildings, which we are reforming with the rapporteur, Mr Bendtsen, seeks to speed up energy efficiency renovations. In addition to falling demand, we hope to be able to offer European homes the opportunity to break away from just one fuel. (The speaker promised to answer a blue card question under Rule 162 (8))

name: Paul Rübig (PPE)
text: Ask about the “blue card” procedure.- Mister President!I would like to ask Mrs Kumpula-Natri whether she believes that Russia's accession to the Energy Charter could lead to a significant improvement in relations.

name: Miapetra Kumpula-Natri (S&D)
text: blue-card answer. – I think that every time we can agree on something politically it will be an improvement for all sectors of society. But we know that in relations with Russia it is not only energy we are looking at; unfortunately, the country is using multi-targeted politics towards the European Union. We have to remain coherent, but not to forget that energy is one of a vital part.  Talking about climate change, talking about coal in the Arctic, on the ice, we need Russia on board to prevent really fast, rapid climate change that the black coal is causing in the Arctic, and that is why we need to find a broad political understanding.  (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Bill Etheridge (EFDD)
text: blue-card question. – Thank you for accepting the card. I noticed that in your speech you spoke about diversity of energy supplies, and during this whole debate people have been speaking about the concern about keeping control of energy supplies flowing. Would it not be sensible, in that case, for this place not to have ruled out in so many cases further research into nuclear energy or into fracking – which are, after all, the sources of energy of the future, far cheaper, and things we can develop here without having to rely on Russia, for example?

name: Miapetra Kumpula-Natri (S&D)
text: blue-card answer. – I am very happy to work in this Parliament in the ITRE Committee, because we clearly understand that the European Union working together can improve the energy supply and energy security. It does not limit us taking national decisions in Member States on whether you want to use nuclear or not, or whether you want to use more renewables than the quotas set by the Union. The energy mix is decided in every Member State. The European Union can only improve the security of energy, and there we have a concrete result now on the table, with many more to come.

name: Dariusz Rosati (PPE).
text: – Mr President, I very much welcome the conclusion of the trilogue negotiations on security of gas supply and I would like to congratulate our colleague, Jerzy Buzek, for this successful achievement. With the new rules, based on the principle of real solidarity and closer regional cooperation, the EU will be better prepared to face any potential disruption of gas supplies. This is good news. The document we are discussing today again shows that the European Union and closer cooperation among Member States benefit European citizens.  I would like to raise one specific point: the priority for gas supplies goes to households and essential social services, so we know that we are protecting our citizens against any unforeseen and sudden disruption of gas supply.  I congratulate the Council, the Commission and the Parliament negotiation team on this compromise agreement. Remember that gas is a strategic commodity and ensuring security of gas supplies is one of our utmost and most paramount tasks here in this Parliament.

name: Patrizia Toia (S&D).
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the regulation we are approving certainly represents a step forward, a new step in the energy approach of the European Union. And I want to thank President Buzek in a non-formal way for the great work he has done, but also because, as he himself said in the introduction, citing the reality of some countries, he was able to reconcile clarity of objectives with flexibility and listening. however, the needs of the various Member States which, while believing in cooperation between States, must naturally find reasons for coherence and practicality in zoning and aggregations. So I think it was a good job, which resulted in a result of consultation with all the parties. We know the contents of this plan, so I just want to briefly make a reference, speaking with the Commissioner and colleagues. We all know that the common energy policy was born precisely in the face of a supply risk: crisis at the beginning of the 2000s, Ukraine and Russia, coincidentally, even then ... And therefore Europe found itself discovered, it has understood that addiction was a risk and that addiction without solidarity was a double mortal risk. And this also gave rise to this need not only to address the issue of supply but also to create, even before the legal bases of Lisbon, a union, a common energy policy. So, I hope this push is just one step towards really moving towards an Energy Union. I am thinking of the work of Notre Europe, of many far-sighted characters, of what Delors did, etc. Here, let's move forward, Commissioner, as we are working well towards a true Energy Union.

name: Λευτέρης Χριστοφόρου (PPE).
text: - Mr President, we really congratulate my dear colleague, Mr Buzek, on the very important report he has prepared, which is a useful guide and guide for the coming years on energy issues. But I firmly believe that if we really want a good strong Energy Union and energy security, we must first and foremost rely on our own strengths. It has been rightly said before that it does not mean that a third country is actually a supplier of 1/3 of the gas of the 28 Member States of the European Union. This is also offensive to the European Union itself. We must use our own strengths. I, from my own experience, suggest that we take advantage of the Eastern Mediterranean. Cyprus with Israel and Greece, as well as Cyprus with Egypt and Greece, have concluded tripartite agreements on energy issues that can be exploited by the European Union. The European Union can also take advantage of the opportunity that Cyprus has to invest in a liquefied natural gas terminal, which, due to its economic potential, Cyprus is unable to do so. To invest, Commissioner, with EU funds of 10 billion so that not only Cyprus and the region, but also the whole of the European Union can have energy security and self-sufficiency, not only for the Eastern Mediterranean but for all areas where the European Union has the potential to invest directly in its energy security.

name: Csaba Molnár (S&D).
text: - Mr President, we are discussing a very, very important piece of European legislation today. This debate here in the Chamber of the European Parliament is about how we can provide gas to people in Europe in a cheap and safe way. The price of natural gas in Europe has fallen by almost half in recent years, but the Hungarian people are still paying the same price as three years ago. The difference between the two prices went to Swiss off-shore accounts. Under the heading of overhead lies, Fidesz pays a HUF 23,000 surcharge for gas to each Hungarian family each year. If it were not for this corrupt pricing in Hungary, every Hungarian family could save a monthly heating bill every year. The reality, however, is that this cannot be done in Hungary. Fidesz businessmen and their Russian friends have made HUF 50 billion in extra profit last year alone due to corrupt gas pricing. It is unacceptable that due to such unfavorable gas price contracts, the price of gas in Hungary is much higher than it could be in reality. If we really joined the European Energy Union, we would not have to turn off the gas in the homes of hundreds of thousands of Hungarians every year. That is why we are choosing Europe and the European Energy Union over corrupt gas pricing in Orban.

name: Seán Kelly (PPE).
text: – Mr President, I welcome this very important piece of legislation which we are voting on today. Without a doubt, energy security is vital for Europe, for industrial competitiveness, and for investment. I think that as a result of this legislation we will see greater cooperation between Member States, which is part and parcel of what the European Union is all about. I also welcome the regional approach taken here, but I am concerned about my own country, Ireland, because by the mid-2020s – when the United Kingdom is out of the EU – we will be dependent on them for 95% of our gas. This will mean we will be geographically cut off from the EU system and exposed to United Kingdom price shocks. However, there are projects in the pipeline such as Shannon LNG, which I am very familiar with. Others are mentioned as well, but Shannon LNG has the potential to help us have energy security. It has been a number of years in the pipeline, it has PCA (Pipeline Construction Authorisation) status, and by giving funding to it I think we can help it progress and ensure that post-Brexit Ireland will have security of supply.

name: Zdzisław Krasnodębski (ECR).
text: - Mr Chairman! At the outset, I, too, would like to congratulate Prime Minister Buzek on the successful completion of negotiations on this very difficult issue to such an excellent end. I would also like to say that this draft new regulation on the security of gas supply complements the provisions adopted by the European Parliament in March on intergovernmental agreements in the field of energy, mainly gas, which introduced a mandatory verification mechanism for these agreements before signing them, and both of these regulations will undoubtedly increase security energy of Europeans. However, I would also like to point out that a certain gap remains. Well, these new rules will not be fully effective as long as the so-called non-binding instruments, such as cooperation memoranda and hybrid agreements concluded between Member States and third-country companies, or between EU companies and third countries, are also not subject to control, or concerns controlled by third countries, the best example of which is Gazprom.

name: Krzysztof Hetman (PPE).
text: - Mr Chairman! First of all, big congratulations to Prime Minister Buzek for the work he has done. Secondly, I am glad that our legislative work is coming to an end and we will soon have a new and better regulation on the security of gas supply. I am convinced that thanks to better regional cooperation, solidarity between countries and transparency of gas contracts, the European Union will be a strong and united partner for external suppliers. However, I hope that all these very positive changes and the great work done here in Parliament will not just turn out to be a dead piece on paper. The construction of the Nord Stream II gas pipeline is a threat to the security of gas supplies, as for our European strength of unity. Unfortunately, it means the concentration of supply routes, bypassing Central and Eastern Europe and undermining the position of Ukraine, which are all the issues that we have been fighting together for years. Commissioner! I am convinced that it is crucial that we are united to projects like Nord Stream II and subject them to European energy rules.

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D).
text: – Mr President, taking into account that the European Union is highly dependent on gas imports, mainly from Russia, I strongly believe that the proposal gives much—needed impetus to our efforts to secure gas supply and ensure a well—interconnected and well—functioning internal gas market.  While efforts have been made, uncertainty over gas supply and regional disparities continue to raise big concerns. Therefore, I welcome the introduction of the solidarity principle and I strongly believe that the latter paves the way towards the achievement of a genuine energy union by making one of its cornerstones, which is energy security for all, more effective.  With this objective in mind, I consider that it is absolutely necessary that Member States engage in stronger regional cooperation at the level above both preventive action and reaction to disruptions of supply. Indeed, safeguarding the security of gas supply demands more cooperation, more coordination and more transparency in the common energy union.

name: Gesine Meissner (ALDE).
text: - Mister President! In this case, I would like to extend my warmest thanks not only to Jerzy Buzek, who was the rapporteur on this subject, but also to the entire negotiating team. It has clearly been a good cooperation between Parliament and I think we have achieved a breakthrough here in that it is a real step towards an energy union. We don't have them for a long time, but we need them. The fact that Russia cut the gas a few years ago to punish Ukraine and hit some Eastern European countries, where people were left in the cold - something like that shouldn't happen again. That is why we really have to see that together we can manage the gas supply as securely as possible without being too dependent on any third countries that may not be particularly politically favored. Of course, biogas also plays a role, as the Finnish colleague said, but we want to focus on renewable energy. If we can do that regionally — decentrally, that's good too. Regional cooperation in gas supply is very important - especially for the transport sector, which I represent, for LNG and CNG. For that we need good cooperation, and I think we can achieve that quickly now.

name: Davor Škrlec (Verts/ALE).
text: - Mr. President, first of all I would like to congratulate Mr. Buzek on his excellent work.I believe that this Regulation has made great progress in achieving a good foundation for one of the pillars of the Energy Union, which is solidarity and security of energy supply in the European Union;Finally, the importance of regional cooperation is recognizable, not only because it is also provided for in the Energy Union documents, but also because the Member States will no longer invest individually in capacity but will do so at regional level, which ultimately means cheaper energy prices.for our economy and for our citizens, which is one of the basic goals of the Energy Union.Also, our esteemed Commissioner Cañete was given a powerful tool, which is to ensure that climate goals are achieved, because the natural gas that will be used in this way will help this transition by 2050 towards our planned paths.

name: Jean-Luc Schaffhauser (ENF).
text: - Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, we have to come back to reality.All the studies show that Europe will still depend on Russian gas for the next twenty or thirty years, and it is not American gas or gas from Qatar that will change anything.Second point, only long-term contracts allow the energy security of states.They are the links in the energy security chain.By weakening long-term contracts, by weakening states in their negotiating power, by promoting the spot market to the benefit of speculation, the Commission and this Parliament are not ensuring Europe's energy security but its insecurity.energetic.We must get out of this Europe.

name: Maria Grapini (S&D).
text: - Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I do not think we need to question the importance of ensuring gas supply and energy security. After all, these things are about people's lives. I congratulate the team and the committees that worked under the co-rapporteur, and I think we need to pay attention now, Commissioner, to how the Commission works with the national authorities, because I believe in coordinating the work and I believe a lot in the report's proposals on energy efficiency. Here we have to correlate with other reports and other measures. Energy efficiency is extremely important for energy saving, investments in technologies also a measure that can help efficiency. The report also contains other proposals that it supports, such as the diversification of energy sources, but all must be read in one key: solidarity, solidarity read as stated in the contract. Without cooperation and solidarity, no single state will be able to cope and we need to have solutions for emergencies. Commissioner, it is vital that you coordinate this.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D).
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, energy security in gas supply is a strategic priority for the European Union, aimed at reducing the cyclical disturbances in natural gas supplies and their impact on the economies of the Member States. Excessive dependence on a limited number of supply sources, the bilateral nature of the agreements, the poor coordination of national policies and the complexity of geopolitical dynamics have historically represented the most complex elements in the construction of a single internal energy market. Already the regulation n. 994/2010 took an important step towards greater integration and security in the supply of gas, but maintained a pre-eminently national approach. I believe the proposal is a significant evolution in the European regulatory framework for energy security, in line with the need for diversification of sources and the objectives of transparency, solidarity and trust between Member States. Finally, we must not underestimate the behavioral approach of both companies and individuals, of European policies to reduce dependence on fossil fuels to the advantage of alternative and renewable energy sources, especially in terms of environmental sustainability.

name: Miguel Arias Cañete
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, I wish to thank again our rapporteur Mr Buzek for his very constructive approach to this proposal. Following fruitful cooperation between the three institutions, we have reached an ambitious but balanced agreement. With this regulation we have completed the energy security package tabled by the Commission in February 2016. The agreement on this politically so important dossier was reached in only 14 months – a real record, Mr Buzek, and thank you for your support. With this, we will significantly improve security of gas supply not only in the European Union, but also beyond in close cooperation with Energy Community countries. It demonstrates that when there is political commitment and we share the same objectives, we are able to take rapid action that addresses the needs of European citizens and businesses. Let us maintain this positive spirit in the negotiations on the ‘Clean Energy for All Europeans’ package that is now on the table of this Parliament and the Council. Statement of the Commission as regards Article 15 of the Proposal for a revised Gas Security of Supply Regulation The Commission welcomes the co-cooperation mechanisms set out in Article 15 of the proposed Regulation as submitted to Coreper as an important tool for ensuring consistency of preventive action and emergency plans with Energy Community Contracting Parties. The Commission stresses the importance of effectively ensuring that no measures are put in place by Energy Community Contracting Parties that may negatively affect the security of supply situation in the EU and its Member State and vice versa. In this respect, the Commission will, without prejudice to its initial Commission proposal of 16 February 2016, consider proposing to the Council in due course a recommendation under Art. 218 TFEU for negotiations on amendments of the Energy Community Treaty with a view to establishing an appropriate legal framework and mechanisms to allow applicability of selected provisions of the Regulation and other relevant parts of the acquis communautaire in the field of energy between the EU and its Member States on the one hand, and Contracting Parties of the Energy Community on the other, so as to ensure effective implementation of a reinforced security of gas supply framework.

name: Jerzy Buzek
text: rapporteur. - Mr Chairman! I would like to refer to what Commissioner Cañete said. Indeed, these negotiations were very long, but the preparation and entry into force of the regulation itself were extremely short. In the negotiations, we achieved an unusual agreement in the European Parliament and we formed a tight team. Then, I admit that the European Commission joined this team (thank you very much for the great cooperation and direct participation in the negotiations of both gentlemen present here) and finally we were able to draw the Maltese Presidency into our team. We have to admit that the Maltese Presidency has made a lot of efforts to convince individual Member States. We too. Individual members of Parliament spoke with the representations of the various Member States. The Commission also performed such activities. I am saying this because we have the entire energy package ahead of us, eight regulations, directives that are lying on the table. All will have to be negotiated. On the one hand, it's a way of keeping your main line open and opening up to yourself. Very short closing points. We said: the market first of all. Please remember that. Only in difficult situations do we use other solutions. Information exchange is very important. Also prior contracts and contracts for infrastructure. Another issue that we paid great attention to is the confidentiality of commercial contracts. And finally - the energy union we are creating. We would like to create it together with the countries to the east of the European Union, i.e. the Western Balkans, Moldova, Ukraine and Georgia, and this is what is happening today, and we are going in this direction. Of course, we should mention intergovernmental agreements, because this is also a common element of our regulation, the author of which was Mr. Krasnodębski. All this together created the conditions for us to get a really good regulation, but this is only the first stage of our work. There is a lot of work ahead of us on the union energy.

name: Przewodniczący. –
text: I close the debate.The vote will take place on Tuesday 12 September 2017. Written statements (Rule 162)

name: Cristian-Silviu Buşoi (PPE)
text: in writing. – Security of gas supply is a crucial factor in the European Union’s sovereignty. Unstable international cooperation encourages the EU to secure the energy system and protect consumers in case of the disruption of foreign gas supply. This security can be achieved only by maximising local production, completing the interconnection of Member States’ gas grids, developing liquefied natural gas hubs and finalising the gas corridors. Furthermore, considering that a considerable part of the imported gas is transformed into electricity, the Union should continue to boost the diversification of electricity resources and, perhaps, take into consideration more and more the massive wind resources available in the European sea basins that, through the rapid progress of technology, can fill the gap in the electricity market.

name: Tunne Kelam (PPE)
text: in writing. – This regulation is among the most crucial ones to ensuring the EU’s resilience towards hostile policy from outside the EU. It is important to understand that the regulation is basically a legally-binding solidarity mechanism, aimed at protecting states and citizens against blackmail and political pressure. The EU needs to complete its own instruments to make sure that gas supplies cannot be used against any Member State as a political weapon. It leaves Member States enough leverage to design their own prevention and crisis mitigation plans. At the same time, the regulation makes it obligatory to take into account regional concerns by including a common regional chapter in every national plan. The 13 EU regions are defined as risk-based groups in order to meet their particular regional needs flexibly. The solidarity clause, which is triggered automatically whenever one of the Member States is affected by a very serious cut in gas supply, is a crucial step towards completing the Energy Union. Lastly, increased transparency in the gas sector is advantageous for the energy security of the EU as a whole. This aspect sets out that all gas contracts crucial for European energy security and that exceed a certain threshold of energy consumption need to be notified. This will significantly increase accountability.

name: Adam Szejnfeld (PPE)
text: in writing. - The regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on measures to ensure the security of natural gas supply proves that the Energy Union does not remain an empty slogan, but becomes a real and effective support mechanism for Member States in the event of a gas supply interruption. It should be remembered that 90% of the gas that flows through Europe crosses at least one state border. The associated risk of the spill-over of the effects of supply disruptions on an international scale requires the widest possible cooperation at European level. In the past, the possibility of "turning off the gas tap" was used by Russia as an instrument of political pressure or even blackmail against the countries dependent on Russian gas, which particularly concerned the countries of Central and Eastern Europe, including Poland. Thanks to measures such as the adopted regulation on measures to ensure the security of natural gas supplies, my faith in the sense of a united Europe defends itself against the disappointment caused by the proliferation of protectionism and particularism in Europe. At the same time, however, I hope that the implementation of the Nord Stream 2 gas pipeline project, which directly affects Europe's energy security and the idea of ​​the energy union itself, will be blocked as quickly and effectively.

name: Владимир Уручев (PPE)
text: In written form. - The gas crisis in January 2009 on the Russia-Ukraine-EU route made it clear how vulnerable the countries of Central and Eastern Europe are and that they cannot cope alone in such a situation. The agreed new regulation on security of gas supply guarantees a working mechanism for adequate response to such crisis scenarios through binding regional cooperation, based on a joint risk assessment for the given country and region. The new legislation imposes a new behavior of solidarity and interaction between neighboring countries in the event of interruptions in gas supplies and turns the spirit of solidarity in Europe from a political declaration into a concrete legally binding action. The new legal framework establishes the introduction of a list of protected customers, including public buildings, hospitals and schools, which must be supplied as a matter of priority in the event of an emergency supply disruption. The regulation also creates unprecedented openness in the contracts of gas supply companies from third countries, which must be provided to national regulators and the EC to assess whether they affect security of supply. Thus, today's regulation, together with the already adopted mechanism for the prior exchange of information on intergovernmental agreements with third countries, completes the legislative package on security of energy supply, an important step towards the Energy Union.

name: Przewodniczący. –
text: The next item is the Council and Commission statements on the fipronil scandal: how to improve the EU rapid alert system for food and feed (2017/2825 (RSP)).

name: Matti Maasikas
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Mr President, it appears that on 20 July the Belgian authorities informed the other Member States and the Commission about their findings of residues of fipronil in eggs. Since then, the Commission and the Member States have been carrying out investigations and taking all necessary measures to protect consumers. It is now clear that the residues result from an illegal use of the product. While the overall responsibility for the investigations and protective measures remains with the Commission and the Member States, the Presidency of the Council has been following developments closely. On 5 September, at the informal meeting of the Agriculture Ministers held in Tallinn, Commissioner Andriukaitis provided the Ministers with an overview of the state of play and of the further actions planned. After this presentation, Ministers held a discussion including, among other things, the need to ensure an efficient circulation of information in such cases.  Indeed, since the first contamination cases were reported, concerns have been raised, including in Parliament, regarding possible weaknesses in the EU’s rapid alert system and the speed of information sharing. The question of how we can strengthen cooperation and the exchange of information between countries in order to deal more efficiently with such crisis situations will be further discussed at the High Level Ministerial Meeting organised by the Commission in Brussels on 26 September, and we are grateful to the Commission for taking this initiative.  The outcome of that meeting will be presented to Agriculture Ministers at the October Council session on 9—10 October this year. The ongoing investigations and follow—up discussions should give us a clear overall picture of what precisely happened and why, what went wrong and what can be improved. We will need this full clarity for our future debates.  The Council has consistently acknowledged the importance of food safety, high—level protection of public health and the prevention of food fraud. In its conclusions on the role of law enforcement cooperation in combating food crime adopted in 2014, the Council encouraged the Commission to continue its work on the fight against fraudulent and deceptive practices along the food supply chain and to develop any further action necessary for high-level protection of public health.  Furthermore, during the negotiations leading to the adoption of the new Official Controls Regulation that entered into force on 27 April this year, Parliament and the Council agreed to reinforce the legal provisions to fight such practices. Those reinforced provisions do not just include general rules. They also provide for the designation of European Union reference centres for the authenticity and integrity of the agri—food chain, reinforced administrative assistance and cooperation mechanisms between Member States, and enhanced coordinated assistance and follow—up by the Commission.  As I already mentioned, it seems clear that the present fipronil contamination is the result of fraudulent activity. There should be zero tolerance for such fraud. However, the infestation of hens by red mites is a real problem for many farms. Therefore, we must also make every effort to ensure that legal and efficient ways to prevent and treat that infestation remain available.  Let me conclude by calling on all of us to support and encourage the actions taken by the Commission and Member States to ensure the safety of our daily food, to avoid these types of fraud and to resolve them efficiently whenever they occur.

name: Vytenis Povilas Andriukaitis
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, let me start by thanking you for this possibility to provide the House with the latest update on the recent contamination of eggs and egg products with fipronil.  Let me begin by assuring you that public health and food safety are always considered a top priority for me and are treated as such by the Commission. Coherently with this approach, the Commission took immediately very seriously the fipronil issue. The situation continues to evolve, but I think it is important to clarify right from the beginning the succession of events. In November 2016, the Dutch Food Authority was informed of the illegal use of fipronil in poultry but since there were no analytical results indicating the presence of fipronil in eggs or chicken meat, and also no danger to public health, the source of the problem was not established. Tests on samples kept from September 2016 that revealed the presence of fipronil were done only recently and are under investigation by prosecutors from three countries – Germany, the Netherlands and Belgium – to check these historical samples to assess what was known, when and by whom. Prosecutors will help to answer these questions. On 2 June 2017, following self-controls by a Belgian food business operator, the Belgian authorities were notified of the presence of fipronil in eggs and started initiating an investigation to understand the source of the problem. As a consequence of this investigation, on 6 July the Belgian authorities initiated a request for information from the Netherlands in the Administrative Assistance and Cooperation System. This is a different system, related to RASFF.  This system allows Member States to liaise bilaterally or multilaterally to confirm rapidly suspected cases of fraud and is only actively monitored by the Commission when a ‘European Commission coordinated case’ is created. Belgium initiated a normal case, not a European Commission created case, which means that the Commission was not an addressee of the notification and no follow-up was expected by the Commission. Once the Belgian authorities had identified the source of fipronil in eggs and the possible extent of the problem, they notified the European Union Rapid Alert System for Food and Feed (RASFF) on 20 July 2017.  Therefore the Commission was only informed of the fipronil contamination on 20 July. But as soon as the issue was notified through the RASFF system, the Commission took control of the situation, focusing on managing and minimising the consequences of the contamination. Having said that, I want to start by stressing two points. Firstly, that the risk to human health remains very low and has been successfully contained thanks to the measures which have been taken at European Union level. And secondly, this incident is clearly the result of a criminal act resulting in food fraud. This is not to minimise the incident, as it relates to illegal use of an unauthorised substance, which is totally unacceptable, but this is not about a health risk issue. All contaminated eggs have been withdrawn from the market and the eggs from the few farms with acute risk levels have been recalled from consumers. So all in all, consumer safety has not been compromised. Nevertheless, it appals me that the criminal actions of a few could jeopardise the integrity and reputation of our entire food chain. Those criminals must be investigated and punished. So where are we now, today? The situation evolves every day, as you know; 26 Member States and 23 non-EU countries have been affected by the contamination. Since the very beginning of this criminal situation I have been systematically in contact with my counterparts in the Member States most concerned. I have also asked for certain gaps in information to be verified and for detailed analysis and common views to be presented to me. I spoke with ministers for Germany, the Netherlands, Belgium and Austria.  In response to the finding of fipronil the Commission requested that specific measures be taken at national level; in particular we have instructed via RASFF that the following measures be taken. First, on 31 July we shared information on applicable maximum residual levels and the measures to be taken as regards illegally treated farms. Second, on 7 August Member States were requested to be vigilant with respect to the possible use of other unauthorised substances used to control red mites in poultry establishments. Third, on 16 August we reminded all Member States that any past distribution of contaminated eggs, egg products or chicken meat had to be timely notified to RASFF in order to ensure the appropriate follow-up by the authorities of the country of destination. Apart from the immediate risk management actions, the Commission has also taken additional important steps.  On 21 August, a note on fipronil contamination was shared with our global partners to ensure transparency. The Commission has also been in direct contact with a number of non-EU countries in order to limit the impact on the EU’s export capacity. On 30 August, we organised a meeting of the Standing Committee on Plants, Animals, Food and Feed, which agreed on an EU-wide monitoring exercise to investigate the possible use of illegal substances, including amitraz, in egg producing farms. I personally informed the European Union ministers of the situation, collectively and bilaterally, in the context of the informal meeting of the Agricultural and Fisheries Ministers last week in Tallinn. Finally, to avoid any potential side effects on the food chain, we are asking the competent authorities to ensure that contaminated food or animal bypass products do not find their way into animal feed and thus back into the food chain. Let me assure you that my services are working hand in hand with those of Commissioners Malmström and Hogan to ensure that the Commission’s response remains coordinated, comprehensive and forward-looking. We also met with both the Committee on Agriculture and Rural Development and the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Food Safety, where I was yesterday, and their suggestions, alongside yours today, will inform the ongoing response.  Now however we need to collectively examine what lessons can be learned and how we communicate and exchange information. This issue will also be discussed by the Chief Veterinary Officers who will meet later this week, on 13 and 14 September. In addition the JRC will organise proficiency tests for official control laboratories in September. With this in mind, the Commission is organising fact-finding missions in early October to the four Member States where the original contamination occurred to gather information on the actions taken. This incident highlights the fact that we need to strengthen the way the European Union networks dealing with food safety and food fraud are used. It is precisely for the reason of providing follow-up at political level that I have taken the initiative to call a High-level Ministerial Meeting on 26 September where we can reflect and agree on, first, how best to strengthen the way the EU networks dealing with food safety and food fraud are used, and second, how to improve coordination between the Administrative Assistance and Cooperation System and the European Union Rapid Alert System for Food and Feed. Bear with me now a moment while I touch on the EU’s Rapid Alert System for Food and Feed which has been subjected to some misplaced criticism of late. The system was created in 1979 in response to the import of oranges contaminated with mercury. Since then, RASFF has ensured that the Commission and Member States were able to respond effectively to several crises, including crop contamination after Chernobyl in 1980s, mad cow disease in mid-1990s and the more recent detection of e-coli bacteria in sprouts in the summer of 2011. RASFF has identified hazards involving mycotoxins, heavy metals, allergens and pesticide residues. When it is used correctly and when it is fed with clear, rapid and reliable information by the control authorities of the Member States, this system works. In practice, the Rapid Alert System for Food and Feed is mobilised when a Member State notifies the system of a danger to public health. As the system’s manager, the Commission verifies the notification and immediately communicates it to the other Member States, and this is precisely what happened in the current situation. Indeed, the use of RASFF, in combination with food traceability provisions, has allowed us to quickly find and destroy the relevant food products in the EU. Affected farms have been blocked and will remain so until Member States are certain that their production is safe.  Let me be clear therefore, thanks to RASFF multiple food-safety risks have been averted before they could harm European citizens. In 2016 alone almost 3 000 original notifications were transmitted through the system. Many of these were alerts requiring and resulting in rapid actions. The original fipronil notification has led to nearly 600 follow—up alerts.  While it is true that every system can be improved, it is worth stressing here that our analysis should focus more on the efficient use of, and interaction between, RASFF and the Administrative Assistance and Cooperation System rather than on their reliability. With this goal in mind, the Commission is developing a common platform for these systems and exploring the possibility of a single network of Member State authorities. Now that we have a new official control law, I think this will help us to be more effective. Let me finish by emphasising once more that close coordination and the steady flow of information between all parties is essential, especially in this case. We have constructed the European Union’s food system and food fraud systems and networks together; now we must work collectively to maximise their potential and safeguard the highest standards of food safety for European citizens. Parliament will be important in this regard and I am keen to hear your views on the matter today.

name: Ivo Belet
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. - Thank you, Chairman, Commissioner, thank you for the explanation. I think that, as you said yourself, the Fipronil crisis has shown us one thing very clearly, namely that the exchange of information between the different national agencies is lacking. We agree on that. That information about food safety just needs to be automatically shared and shared quickly. I think we have now lost weeks, maybe months, for that information to move smoothly from one Member State to another, from one agency to another. That rapid alert system, to say the least, didn't work very quickly. At least that is the perception and it urgently needs to change. It is good that you pledged last night in our committee and here to come up with concrete measures to get rid of that. These national warning systems must be directly linked to the European Rapid Alert System. That should become one well-oiled machine. That is what you say and we count on it that you will and that we will roll it out concretely at the European Council on 26 September. One more thing, one more point: Member States also have different criteria and different timing to inform consumers. This leads to a lot of confusion among consumers and producers. I think we can do that much more efficiently and we count on you, Commissioner, that you will propose and implement concrete measures in this area too, very soon.

name: Mark Demesmaeker
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. - The Fipronil scandal is a matter of manifest fraud. It is, I think, important to emphasize that in the first place. As with the 2013 horse meat fraud scandal, we are dealing with criminals who, purely for profit, defraud consumers on the hood of the sector itself. We need to get those fraudsters in their wallets. Anyone who deliberately cheats has to pay for the costs. Second, we must learn the necessary lessons from this scandal. I am in favor of conducting this debate in a sober way, not responding like headless chickens. No one benefits from intent processes against food agencies. At European level, the main challenge remains fast and effective communication between Member States and, despite the alert systems, it appears that important information was too slow, too insufficiently shared. That can be done differently and that must be done differently. To restore consumer confidence, we must punish fraudsters, prevent and dissuade fraud, and adjust the use of the EU warning system where necessary.

name: Ulrike Müller
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. - Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen! The cause of this egg scandal was the illegal use of prohibited substances - criminal machinations which must be fought and punished with all severity. Even the best law does not seem to deter enough to actually stop this criminal energy and fraud. Nevertheless, we must not become incapacitated and we must come to terms with the fipronil scandal. The discussions in the Agriculture Committee, yesterday in the Environment Committee and today in the plenary show the seriousness of the subject. The Fipronil scandal has shown that the previous Rapid Alert System for Food and Feed - RASFF for short - is not fast enough and efficient. A European rapid alert system should, however, keep exactly what its name promises: it must warn immediately and across Europe. Commissioner, if I now listen to what you have said, you will see that in the end it was not the system that failed, but the stage before it: the notification of the Member States. It is frightening, however, that the responsible authorities in an EU country knew for more than six months that this insecticide was being used without permission and that the report was then made so late. The consequences would be consumer insecurity, deceived agriculture, which has suffered enormous economic damage, and a lot of negative press. All farms have to pay for and bear this loss of confidence. We really have to bring the system forward so far that we can keep an eye on the flow of goods within Europe and can actually guarantee food safety. (The speaker agreed to answer a question about the blue card procedure under Rule 162 (8) of the Rules of Procedure.)

name: Maria Grapini (S&D)
text: Question asked under the 'blue card' procedure.- I totally agree with what you said, because food security is vital.However, I want to ask you from another point of view: in recent years, many mistakes have been made regarding the guilt of those who put a dangerous food product on the market.Do you think that the current regulation clearly includes what happens to those who mislead?This has also happened in my country with a food product certified at European Union level.It was later found that it was not him, but the business of some entrepreneurs was destroyed.

name: Ulrike Müller (ALDE)
text: Answer to a question about the “blue card” procedure.- Yes, I do believe that of course we have to keep an eye on the differences between the Member States, and food safety is our top priority.I am also fully aware of what such a reporting system entails for a rat tail, we heard it: 600 follow-up warnings, as the Commissioner told us.However, I do believe that the Commission, as the highest authority from the Member States, must comply with information and then weigh up to what extent it will ultimately be implemented in the system.

name: Anja Hazekamp
text: on behalf of the GUE / NGL Group. - The Fiproni affair has again shown that there is something terribly wrong with the large-scale way in which we keep our animals in Europe. In the Netherlands alone, 2.5 million chickens have been gassed in recent weeks. They have become the victims of this sick and fraud-prone system. This crisis calls for a system change and not for technical measures and symptom control. Fipronil is not only harmful to humans and chickens, but it is also disastrous for bees and other insects. And yet fipronil is still permitted as a pesticide in European arable farming. The Commissioner said yesterday that a ban on fipronil is impossible and that it would spell disaster. But, Commissioner, do you really believe that a ban on fipronil is a bigger disaster than the one we are in now? I would therefore like to call on the Commissioner once again to propose to the ministers at the Fipronil summit to ban Fipronil completely from European agriculture in order to safeguard human and animal health for the future. I also believe that European agricultural subsidies should be abolished.

name: Bart Staes
text: on behalf of the Verts / ALE Group. - I thank the Estonian Presidency and the Commissioner for the introduction. One thing is clear: it is fraud. Criminals, unscrupulous criminals have willingly cheated the whole thing. They have endangered public health without any moral sense. That is the starting point and they have done it under covert names like Chickfriend, Poultry Vision; the more concealing the better. Second, the case has been going on for much longer than 20 July, when Belgium raised the matter with the rapid alert system. Commissioner, you said that there were already traces in September 2016. There are even invoices circulating that show that the Belgian criminal who is at the root of the whole case, already bought fipronil in May 2016, 3,000 liters; later another 5,000 liters; later another 10 000 liters. And then we come to that rapid alert system, which I think is a powerful tool, a good tool, something that we put in place after previous crises. But of course everything stands and falls with the input of information. If certain member states simply hesitate or refuse to submit certain information for too long, yes, then you will be faced with Piet Snot. If Belgium already knows on June 2 that there is a contamination in a company that is 240 times greater than the maximum residue limit, and already knows in mid-June that there is a link to the Netherlands, but still wait until July 20 to put the whole matter in place through the rapid alert system, then we have a problem. So, Commissioner, I expect you to come up with proposals on 26 September to amend the food regulation that governs the entire rapid alert system. According to that Food Regulation, Member States must act without delay. Well, there should be fines for those Member States that do not comply. That, I think, is the crux of the matter.

name: John Stuart Agnew
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. – Mr President, fipronil raises two key points which must be answered.  First, what is the reality of the threat to human health? The mere fact that something is prohibited tells us nothing about the severity of the threat. Nor did the discussion in the Committee on Agriculture and Rural Development. Are we talking about potential organ failure or would you have to consume such vast quantities that, in reality, there may be a technical hazard but the risk is minimal? We do need to know. Controlling red mite on chickens is a very big animal welfare issue and there must be a sound reason not to use the best materials.  Secondly, this is demonstrating a failure of the single market. Although used on British cats and dogs, this material cannot be used by British egg producers because it has not been allocated a Health and Safety Executive number. Meanwhile British consumers eat imported EU eggs whose producers benefit from the competitive advantage that fipronil brings. The scandal has resulted in British consumers losing confidence in eggs generically and the British producer is paying the price for the sins of other EU producers.

name: Mireille D’Ornano
text: on behalf of the ENF group. - Mr President, Commissioner, in recent months millions of eggs have been infected in several European countries. As I told the Commissioner yesterday, France now has 39 products, so far sold in supermarkets, in which the quantity of fipronil exceeds the maximum authorized. However, the World Health Organization classifies this insecticide as moderately toxic to humans. While consuming an isolated food containing traces of fipronil carries limited risks, regular consumption of these products can seriously damage your health. The fipronil scandal is all the more resounding since the identification and indication of the origin of countries concerning egg products is particularly ill-conceived. We know that the illegal use of fipronil dates back to November 2016. However, the European Commission justifies itself by asserting that Belgium only gave the alert on July 20. Brussels assures that it was not the recipient of the notification from Belgium to the Netherlands under the system of administrative assistance and cooperation. If it had any suspicion about activities which appeared to be in breach of the law, the Commission could always carry out inspections or ask the state concerned to intensify the checks. It is surprising to say the least that in eight months the Commission has not heard of any information on the fraudulent use of fipronil in several countries. Regarding the traces of a second insecticide - amitraz - found, again, in several European farms, the French authorities say they have not received any communication from the rapid alert system for food. This lack of warnings and recommendations from the European Union only reinforces citizens’s mistrust and unfortunately demonstrates Brussels’s inability to monitor health and food safety.

name: Diane James (NI).
text: – Mr President, it is a fact that fipronil is not permitted for use around animals destined for human consumption. This situation is yet though another example of why the European Union’s fundamental principle of the free movement of goods, services and people is in direct conflict with the protection of citizens of Member States, in this context in terms of public health.  The free movement of goods allowed these insecticide-contaminated goods into the human food chain in the same way that horse meat from eastern Europe turned up in supposedly beef products. Checks were simply not enforced. Furthermore, the fact that the Netherlands chose not to act upon the 2016 tip-off completely rubbishes the idea that the European Union enhances cooperation between Member States.  Whilst the European Union obsesses – and I mean obsesses – about regulation, its own inherent freedom of movement weakness creates a perfect breeding ground for dangerous products to slip into the food chain and endanger public health. Just last month, Bloomberg agreed with this point of view in an article entitled ‘Even European Union regulators can’t stamp out food scandals’.

name: Annie Schreijer-Pierik (PPE).
text: - On 9 August, Chairman, I asked the Commission about the reconstruction of all reports received through the food and feed alert system. In the future, the European Commission must assume a coordinating role so that all reports reach the correct authorities via the alert system. We have to work very hard on that. Fipronil has been used all over Europe. And then? What does the Commission think of the far-reaching public warnings from the Dutch Food and Consumer Product Safety Authority? Because they have clearly expressed different things in particular. The Dutch Food and Consumer Product Safety Authority, which has seriously damaged consumer confidence in the sector, with many financial consequences for the sector itself. Was that necessary if other Member States did not apply such extremely strict values? And then the cleaning of stables and the sale of manure: in the Netherlands, chicken manure with very low concentrations must be incinerated. There is insufficient combustion capacity for this, with high costs. Why should the manure not be applied directly and how does that actually work in other countries? I would like to know that. Many poultry farmers have been hit by this crisis through no fault of their own. How do we deal with this? And that is what it is all about here: how do we deal with family businesses in this sad situation and how do we lend them a helping hand? And it is, I look at Anja Hazekamp who is gone, not only the large intensive companies. In particular, many organic small businesses have been affected. And that is why, Mr President, I also ask you for financial support for these farmers in this difficult transition situation, because we do not think enough about that here. I also ask you, just like last night, to consult with Commissioner Hogan and Malmström for good solutions. I wish you the best of luck. (The speaker addressed a "blue card" question (Rule 162 (8))

name: Molly Scott Cato (Verts/ALE)
text: blue-card question. – Quite rightly, this debate is focused on the fraud and the failure of information. But there is a vital fundamental problem we are not addressing, and that is the nature of our industrialised farming system, which has been linked to a long list of previous animal diseases and diseases in animal products. When animals are kept in cramped, unsanitary and inhumane conditions, disease breaks out. So I would like to ask Mrs Schreijer-Pierik, whilst fipronil is obviously prohibited now, does she not recognise that link between the style of farming and these continuing problems that we are seeing?

name: Annie Schreijer-Pierik (PPE)
text: "blue card" answer.Thank you for this question.We have carried out research into this at the University of Wageningen and it shows that larger companies in particular also take good care of their animal husbandry.In particular, I speak very clearly about how we are very much on top of this in the Netherlands and are conducting this discussion.That is why I just said to colleague Hazekamp, she speaks about intensive livestock farming and says that it is the result of that.That is totally untrue.The organic sector is particularly affected now.We confuse a lot of things.(The speaker addressed a "blue card" question (Rule 162 (8))

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D)
text: Question "blue card".- Mrs Schreijer-Pierik, you said that the Netherlands produced a lot of chicken droppings and that they did not have enough capacity to incinerate it.They therefore rely on regions that are perhaps more environmentally friendly and have less intensive livestock farming to spread the droppings they have in excess.Don't you think your country would be better off investing in sufficient incineration capacity, so that it can deal with the overproduction of chicken droppings, rather than relying on neighboring regions?It may be a question of the responsibility of your Member State.

name: Annie Schreijer-Pierik (PPE)
text: "blue card" answer.- I am really happy with this question.In the Netherlands, we lead the way in the poultry farming sector with regard to the incineration capacity for poultry manure.Now we are dealing with it, because there is a slight concentration of fipronil in that manure.That is why everything has to be burned and that has to do with figures and how we in Europe have put it together.Then my concrete question is: with that small concentration, which is still there, may it not be spread over the Dutch fields, at the Dutch arable farms?Why am I asking this?Because with seed and seed potatoes, yes, we really sometimes mix up apples and pears here, fipronil is also used in small concentrations.Hence the question.(The speaker addressed a "blue card" question (Rule 162 (8))

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D)
text: blue-card question. – I am sorry we are asking our colleague so many questions but her speech was a very good one.  Colleague, do you accept that the worst thing about this situation is the fact that the competent authorities knew about this but unfortunately it took months and months before consumers were alerted, when 22 countries were affected? Do you not think the worst thing is that we should have to fight against this kind of a situation?

name: Annie Schreijer-Pierik (PPE)
text: "blue card" answer.- Thanks for this question.I totally agree with you.That is why I immediately put the question to the Commission.What is the basis for this?Why have we waited so long to inform each other?Also certainly in my country with the NVWA: when the pigs on our farm are moved abroad, to slaughterhouses, an NVWA member comes to visit.Then the first NVWA doctor comes and is checked by another vet.People are very much on top of it.Then I think that in this situation it has become crazy that it took so long.

name: Eric Andrieu (S&D).
text: - Mr President, Commissioner, it is like the story of this man who falls from a 50-story building. As he falls, he repeats, to reassure himself: so far all is well, so far all is well. This sentence is taken from a French film called "La haine" and it could apply excellently to the issue of fipronil. Pesticides banned or greater than the authorized doses, horse meat sold for beef, a weedkiller disputed and recognized by some scientists as a probable carcinogen but still available over the counter in supermarkets, from endocrine disruptors to bisphenol A, through nitrates or adulterated honey, there is not a month without a new health scandal breaking out. European citizens are rightly concerned about their food and therefore their agriculture and their environment. And now, the eggs contaminated with fipronil! They want to reassure us by telling us that these contaminated eggs were not dangerous for the health of consumers, but I ask the question: what would have been if these eggs had been toxic and had presented a threat to the health of consumers. our fellow citizens? Would we have waited a year, as is the case here? This new scandal is not acceptable, it demonstrates three things. Firstly, that our European rapid warning systems can be improved and that they must be improved very quickly, and that has been said. Secondly, that we must do everything possible to strengthen controls in order to protect consumers in the Union from these fraudulent practices. And finally, that it is fundamental to defend and support our sectors, which are destabilized and trapped by a few unscrupulous cheaters. The important thing is not the fall, Commissioner, it is the landing.

name: Zbigniew Kuźmiuk (ECR).
text: - Mr Chairman! Commissioner! Speaking about the scandal related to the contamination of eggs and poultry meat from farms in the Netherlands and Belgium with fipronil, I would like to point out that eight months have passed between the appearance of the first threat and the response of the relevant authorities of these countries. Well, in the Netherlands, as early as November 2016, an investigation was carried out regarding the illegal addition of fipronil to the Dega 16 preparation, and yet it was not decided then to control the content of this substance in eggs and chicken from poultry farms where this fipronil-assisted preparation was was used. It was the lack of reaction from the relevant authorities in the Netherlands and Belgium that caused the appearance of these products in almost all countries of the European Union at the very beginning of the threat of contamination of eggs and chicken meat. And it is precisely from this delay of many months that conclusions should be drawn for the functioning of the EU rapid alert system for food and feed RAS. (The speaker agreed to take a blue card question (Rule 162 (8))

name: Przewodniczący. –
text: Please state!We have very little time so I will give a blue card one last time.Please, Mrs Wiśniewska, if Mr Kuźmiuk accepts the blue card.

name: Jadwiga Wiśniewska (ECR)
text: question asked by picking up a blue card.–Mr President!Ladies and gentlemen!Food security is crucial.Unfortunately, food is becoming a real threat to the health of consumers.The threat notification system turned out to be a sham.I would like to ask you, Mr Timmermans, whether the Dutchman Frans Timmermans, vice-president of the European Commission, who is so militant about the fictitious problems in Poland, will start, or have already started, the procedure to punish the Netherlands for risking human health loss around the world?

name: Zbigniew Kuźmiuk (ECR)
text: answer to a question asked by raising a blue card.- MEP!Indeed, I said a moment ago that this eight-month delay was due to specific behavior by the Dutch and Belgian authorities.And I hope that Commissioner Andriukaitis has talked or will also talk to Commissioner Timmermans, who represents the Netherlands in the committee.And as we can see, this country is responsible for bringing about this situation.

name: Jan Huitema (ALDE).
text: - Entrepreneurs have been hit emotionally and financially by the Fipronil crisis, regardless of whether they are cage, free-range, free-range or organic farms. I really sympathize with them. In concrete terms, I therefore have the following question: poultry farms whose eggs, meat or manure have fipronil values ​​above the European MRL, do not receive an export certificate. However, no European MRL is known for manure. In practice, this means an absolute zero tolerance for fipronil in manure. It is very difficult for companies to comply with this. Poultry farms do not receive an export certificate for their eggs, animals and meat that are free of fipronil, because traces of fipronil are found in the manure. Manure that is incinerated by the way. The consequences for poultry farms with, for example, mother animals are major. A large part of the hatching eggs are exported from these companies. Without an export certificate, these companies run the risk of not having sales for the long term and therefore going bankrupt. Can the European Commission ensure that eggs can be exported if they are free of fipronil despite traces of fipronil in the manure?

name: Kateřina Konečná (GUE/NGL).
text: - Mr President, Commissioner, we are addressing here today that eggs that are described as toxic are spreading across Europe due to a lack of protection. At the same time, the Belgian authorities were aware of the suspicion of contaminated eggs with fipronil as early as the beginning of June, but did not report it for the first time until 20 July. So I ask you: Is this really the way we present ourselves to cooperation and consumer protection? A spokesman for the Belgian Government Office may be right, and the decision not to disclose information about the first suspicion was in line with European regulations. However, if this was the case, then regulations must change at European level. I call on you, Commissioner, to be the bearer of this change. However, what I consider to be completely scandalous and unacceptable and motivated simply by the effort to protect my businesses is what the Belgian Government has done. It was not about the health of European citizens, I consider it completely scandalous, it was only about the profit of its own businesses. And we should avoid that, and even there we must look for ways so that this can never happen again in any other country.

name: Martin Häusling (Verts/ALE).
text: - Mister President! Commissioner! There is a scandal in a scandal. Many have already said that it takes months for national authorities to react to suspicions.
