It is a scandal that it takes eight weeks for the public to be informed about the first findings! But the Commission's reaction has not been appropriate either. There must be an obligation that member countries report something immediately, especially when it comes to health threats. So why has the Commission not set up a task force on the dimension of the issue to look into it? Why is it only put on the agenda of the Council of Ministers weeks later? That is not an appropriate response. There must be clearer reactions from the Commission. And of course it is also about an agro-industrial system: no area of ​​agriculture is as industrial as egg production, and it is absolutely clear that there is more susceptibility to fraud. That is why these areas must be monitored more closely and more efficiently, and I agree with many colleagues that this product, fipronil, no longer belongs on the European market.

name: Beatrix von Storch (EFDD).
text: - Mister President!Dear voters, today we are discussing bad eggs in the EU - keyword fipronil.Trump and Putin are meanwhile discussing the escalating nuclear dispute with North Korea and are trying to avert it.Peace to our chicken coop - that is the political ambition of the European Union and of Juncker and Merkel.However, this new cross-border food scandal from Belgium shows us that the EU is not working - not at the front and not at the back either.The EU wants to regulate and harmonize everything, but the national and European food control authorities don't work, the information methods don't work, and neither do the early warning systems.And now it is also said that the limit values may not have been set correctly and the risk may be lower than assumed.“What now?” Asks the chicken.And we say: maybe we will mess around a little less and reform the EU from the ground up.

name: Christel Schaldemose (S&D).
text: - Sir.Chairman!Both the Commissioner and the Council of Ministers say that the egg scandal shows that our food warning system in the EU works.I think the egg scandal shows that our system is not working well enough.So we need to tighten up.24 Member States have been affected by this scandal.We will have to oblige our Member States to inform each other immediately when something happens.But orientation is simply not enough.We also need to demand from the Member States that they devote far more resources to controlling our food.Today, it is mainly the companies that control themselves.It is not good enough.Member States will therefore have to step up if this system is to work better in the future.I think we owe it to consumers, who have a right to know that their food is safe.Unfortunately, this is not the case today.

name: Bas Belder (ECR).
text: - In my country, the Netherlands, a large number of poultry farmers, between 200 and 250, have been seriously affected by the Fipronil crisis.The costs are enormous: destruction of eggs, cleaning of the stables, removal of manure.As a result, companies are in danger of falling.I have two questions for you, Commissioner.First of all, a question about manure: can the Commission clarify the maximum residue limit for manure?Member states appear to deal with this differently.At the moment, poultry farmers in my country have to burn manure, even if it does not contain fipronil.As a result, companies remain unnecessarily locked, with all the associated consequences.Another question about damage: Member States appear to have different approaches to granting compensation to affected poultry farmers.What room, Commissioner, exactly does a Member State have to grant compensation within the State aid rules?Please have more clarity on this from the Commission.

name: Izaskun Bilbao Barandica (ALDE).
text: - Mr President, Commissioner, the rapid alert system for food and feed and the traceability on which it is based is a great contribution of the European Union to food safety. In the Basque Country, for example, it was the Public Health Directorate of the Basque Government who, on August 12, in record time, immobilized a game allegedly affected by fipronil, proving the ability of the competent authorities to resolve the situation. But the fipronil crisis has also shown that the resistance of a specific state - in this case, apparently, the Netherlands - to admit that it is the origin of the problem, the temptation to overprotect our own, puts European consumers at risk and harms the good name of all European food production. The crisis that cucumbers suffered in 2011 - which turned out to have its origin in some bean sprouts - should have served us to learn a lesson that we cannot suspend again. That is why we need more honesty, collaboration, transparency and control to be demanded at the announced high-level meeting to improve the rapid alert system for food and feed.

name: Michèle Rivasi (Verts/ALE).
text: - Mr President, I see three questions. First, who raised the alarm? The commissioner said: the European rapid alert system. I think it's a very good tool, as you mentioned, but we need to make the Member States accountable. As has been said, it is abnormal that the Belgians took so long and the Dutch so long. This means that we must propose amendments at the level of the sanction, because we must use this example so that it does not happen again. Next, we have a second problem: who controls and how? Look at Member State level. Either they are agencies or they are operators. I looked at the example of France: out of 15 billion eggs, there are only 600 checks. So it's really a needle in a haystack. And, when I looked at the controls, there was no fipronil, because fipronil is moderately toxic, as the WHO says. So you can see that there is a big concern in terms of product control. Last thing, I find that there are two weights, two measures. When you say: "there is no health risk", what do you know, Commissioner? We know that fipronil is neurotoxic, that it can cause cancer in the thyroid and that in addition it accumulates in fat. So, as this situation has been such since September 2016, we absolutely do not know the risks.

name: Piernicola Pedicini (EFDD).
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I have brought these two eggs to the Chamber, which are practically identical: only one is contaminated with Fipronil and the other is uncontaminated.So how could an ordinary citizen do to distinguish these two eggs, to know which one to choose?Who was supposed to do the checks, Mr. President?And why does the Commission not carry out independent audits?Why was it that the Dutch and Belgian early warning systems were not really quick and allowed this?So we say that there are and always will be frauds: but if these are the control and rapid warning systems of the European Union - that is, practically sieves that are leaking from all sides - then we must understand what is thesolution: for us the solution is that these substances that are toxic to health should not even be authorized on the territory of the European Union.There is no other solution.

name: Gilles Pargneaux (S&D).
text: - Mr President, Commissioner, a new cross-border food scandal in Europe has erupted in recent months: eggs stuffed with the insecticide, fipronil. Nineteen European countries affected, tens of millions of eggs and processed products, such as waffles and children's cookies, have been withdrawn from sale. We need to fight food fraud by some within the European food industry. We therefore need more Europe to improve the rapid alert system for foodstuffs, which I have already helped to strengthen as our Parliament's rapporteur on serious cross-border threats to health in 2013 What should be done then? Make it compulsory for the Member States to alert the European bodies which exist and which have already demonstrated their effectiveness in recent years. Commissioner, it is therefore time for these policies to combat food fraud to be no longer within the competence of the Member States, but a genuine communitarized European policy. Our food security is at stake, and therefore our health.

name: Beata Gosiewska (ECR).
text: - Mr Chairman! Commissioner! Today we have a fipronil scandal. What a scandal will be tomorrow if the European Commission does not finally seriously tackle food safety control? Commissioner, you said that the criticism of the breed system is unfounded. I agree with you. This criticism is due to the European Commission for failing to ensure the safety of food production and for the past eight months of EU citizens, consumers, of consuming eggs and poultry with fipronil. Shouldn't the European Commission assess the risks and order checks in the European Union if there is a problem in Belgium? It is not difficult to predict. You downplay the problem of risk. Fipronil is especially harmful with long-term use, it damages the nervous system, damages the kidneys, liver and thyroid gland. Please do not underestimate this, European Union consumers have the right to be concerned about it and feel unsafe when buying products, and fraudsters, seeing that the European Union institutions do not work, use such scams.

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D).
text: - Mr President, Commissioner, thank you for relating the facts as they happened. You were right to insist on the fact that, indeed, the responsibility rests more, in the first place, with the criminals who should be punished, because the repetitive crises, that it is that of the mad cow, dioxin, of meat labeled "beef" when it is horse, fipronil, are all food crises that cast shame on an entire industry that does not deserve this, while it is only a few criminals who cheat. But it is also the responsibility of the Member States. It is true that the Belgian authorities dragged on a bit: seven weeks between the time they learned of the problem and the time they informed the Commission… What about the Dutch authorities? They had known about it for seven months. Since November 2016. Commissioner, shouldn't the national authorities be invited to communicate more quickly? Do not change the system, but rather make them accountable and, why not, apply sanctions to them, so as to encourage them to be more proactive in the future in similar cases of fraud.

name: Michaela Šojdrová (PPE).
text: - Mr President, as has already been said here, there is an early warning system, but its operation depends on the activities of the national supervisory authorities, in this case the Netherlands and Belgium.Citizens' confidence in the functioning of the internal market depends on consistency in monitoring and clarifying all doubts.In this context, I am pleased that poultry farming tests in the Czech Republic have had a negative impact on fipronil, and I expect the case of fipronil to be investigated and the perpetrators of contamination to be punished so as to restore consumer confidence in the European internal market.

name: Olga Sehnalová (S&D).
text: - Mr President, European consumers still remember the affairs with unlabelled horse meat in food or meat scandals from Brazil, and contaminated eggs have appeared on the internal market, which are also used as an ingredient in a number of other products. More than a month after the initial findings, it was only last week in the Czech Republic that the obligation to inspect imported eggs and egg products was placed before they were placed on the market. It is therefore entirely appropriate to ask whether the supervisory authorities have fulfilled in a timely and sufficient manner the obligation to exchange information under the Rapid Alert System and other obligations arising from market surveillance. Are sanctions for infringements of existing regulations sufficiently dissuasive to prevent the use of prohibited substances in the food industry? It is simply impossible to turn a blind eye to unfair practices and repeated fraud in the food chain in the internal market. Not only is the price of gambling with human health, as in the current fipronil case, far too high, but unfortunately consumer confidence in the internal market is once again shaking to its foundations.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (ECR).
text: - Mr President, this is a huge food scandal with millions of suspected fipronil-contaminated eggs circulating across Europe and it turns out that in both Belgium and the Netherlands the competent national authorities have been aware of this since at least the end of 2016. So the system did not work. . However, in relation to Greece, Mr Andriukaitis, after my constant interventions, it was revealed that the materials were imported into Greece from France, three hundred kilos of egg white powder contaminated with fipronil, and while I was requesting the withdrawal of the eggs and all this suspect In the end, the competent Greek authorities did not do so and informed in an announcement that the suspicious batch of three hundred kilos of egg white powder was used by a Greek company and mixtures were created in a ratio of one to one, a ratio in which the concentration of fipronil, says EFET , is not dangerous. Listen to things! So we ask who is this Greek company that did it? Do you, as the Commission, agree with this unacceptable action? What measures will you take? It is unacceptable what is happening in Greece and throughout Europe!

name: Bronis Ropė (Verts/ALE).
text: - Mr President, honorable Commissioner, colleagues.Speaking of the greater part of the European Union and even the fipronil egg scandal that has reached Hong Kong, I would like to emphasize the importance of having a system that responds in a timely and expeditious manner to similar scandals and prevents a serious threat.The European Union market is huge, and it is only natural that it is sometimes without scandals.However, I think we can welcome the response of the relevant authorities to this case.On the other hand, this scandal raises other examples, such as glyphosate residues in food.Maybe it’s a great opportunity to look back at user expectations and refresh the discussion about what products we expect on our table?

name: Esther Herranz García (PPE).
text: - Mr President, this scandal, that of fipronil, is not only a food safety problem, but it is fundamentally trustworthy: whether or not we have it in the alert mechanisms in force for four decades. And they do not work well and, therefore, this is one more scandal. In Spain we still remember how, a few years ago, the misuse by a Member State and its authorities led to the unjustified complaint against Spanish cucumber producers, which has resulted in millionaire compensation by court ruling a few days ago. Today, unfortunately, there is fraud, and for a delay of many months in a communication of contamination that should have been made immediately by the Member States concerned. But this denotes the ineffectiveness and poor performance of this instrument. You have to make sure that public opinion is calm. For this, nothing better than prevention. Nothing is more appropriate than having European legislation on food defense, which, as we have been warning the Commission for two years now, is an instrument that can give us the peace of mind that consumers need and the tools that producers need. It's called food defense. North America has it; Why don't we have it yet? It would also be necessary to clarify what exactly is the role played by the new food fraud network, created in 2013 as a result of horse meat. What is it for? We wanted to know your opinion.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D).
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, fipronil contamination shows all the vulnerability of our agri-food production. The scandal quickly spread like wildfire, affecting 24 states out of 28. Traceability must be total on all food products and a strong increase in penalties is needed for companies that commit abuses and for those Member States that do not they do preventive checks. It is essential to harmonize the rapid alert system for food and feed and the bilateral cooperation system on fraud, which Belgium used in early June to request information from the Netherlands. The deadlines for the notification of alerts in the European system and the consequent initiation of the withdrawal and recall procedures must be clearly specified, the procedures for managing animals and eggs in the farms affected by contamination and the concentration factors to be applied for the assessment must be established. compliance of egg products. In short, more transparency and faster, but also more Europe to protect our consumers.

name: Tibor Szanyi (S&D).
text: - Mr President, the well-known egg scandal has highlighted the need to improve poultry farming technology in addition to the development of an alert system, the need for pan-European action on waiting times for chemicals in the food industry, and the fact that poultry feeds.the lack of animal welfare support raises questions.The solution can only be at European level.It is time to support the common market with an even stronger common food and feed safety system.In the event of crisis situations such as the egg scandal, a multi-annual crisis fund system could be a solution instead of the practice of existing one-year crisis funds.

name: Vytenis Povilas Andriukaitis
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, I would like to say that I am very happy about those broad debates. Some of you made political statements. Of course, I agree that the Commission is responsible, as Ms Gosiewska said. I am responsible, I am personally responsible. It is a big test for me – and for you also, for all of us, because the situation is very delicate.  On the one hand, we know very well that we need to have facts, arguments, scientifically-based criteria and, of course, reality and fact-finding checks, not just talking generally. Because dissemination of mistrust, dissemination of fear, dissemination of misleading information also affects consumer perception. We need to understand balance and to see how to move forward together. This is not the time to name, blame and shame.  It was a big test for me on 20 July because I faced for the first time such a big challenge and we decided, on the one hand, to be very active, very precise, to communicate with governments, to discuss with ministers, and on the other hand, to manage information, to provide information for consumers.  You mentioned failures of the Rapid Alert System. No, this is not true. Only the Rapid Alert System allows us to understand where we are, how many countries are affected. The European Union produced 360 million eggs per day – please, calculate that per one week and then, can you imagine it, we withdrew 20, 40 million eggs from this big amount. It shows that our Rapid Alert System and tracking and tracing system is effective. That is true. Another question is: how are we using information, how are we acting, especially in using two different systems with different tasks. A criminal investigation in one hand, the food safety issue in the other. How to build a coherent approach? It is our task to move forward and to enforce our situation. Let me start with some concrete questions. Ms Dalli, Mr Agnew and Ms Rivasi raised questions on public health. As regards a possible risk to public health, eggs from only three farms exceeded the acute risk level. I would like to provide you with this real information. Only three farms exceeded the acute risk level. This means that the consumer would need to consume several eggs from these farms in a short period of time to exceed the acute reference dose.  As regards the chronic risk, long-term exposure to fipronil via eggs and egg products should not exceed the acceptable daily intake. From the analytical results available, the majority of the eggs are below that level. This is why we once again draw your attention to this. The risk to public health is really very low. This is not to minimise the incident, as it relates to the illegal use of unauthorised substances. So all in all, consumers are safe, as I mentioned. Talking about action in the future: Mr Belet, Ms Dalli and Mr Demesmaeker raised those questions. After managing the consequences of the incident and having taken the necessary risk management measures, we now have to move on and understand what lessons can be learned from this situation.  On 30 August, a meeting of the Standing Committee on Plants, Animals, Food and Feed discussed the situation at a technical level and I asked Member States – France, the Netherlands, Germany and Belgium – to provide a coherent approach and to present their views and, of course, a thorough assessment and also proposals on how to deal with those issues together.  This means that I will organise a high-level ministerial meeting on 26 September because we need to address all the issues and questions which were raised today. I will collect your questions and will see how to include your questions on manure, zero tolerance, compensation issues. We need to understand the situation and we will present our conclusions to the Agriculture and Fisheries Council in October, because this is a sequence of problems. Speaking of delays by the Member States, we have to look at this from two angles: the functioning of the system itself, and the use of the system. The system as such, as it was designed, is working well from my point of view. Once it has been put into the system, information has been flowing very well, but how to react quickly is another thing.  I fully understand the situation of the competent authorities because they have difficulties in deciding. First of all they must understand the source of the problems, then the extent of the problems, and then see how to react quickly because it was detected in a completely accidental way. This is very important once again. There are a lot of questions so perhaps I can collect those questions and answer them in written form, as I know we are pressed for time. Speaking about compensation, the priorities for these coming weeks is for producers, business operators and Member States to take the necessary measures to ensure a high level of consumer protection and for the Commission to ensure harmonised enforcement of European Union rules in Member States.  The economic impact of this situation needs to be assessed before starting talks on potential compensation because the situation is not yet at an end. We need to assess the situation considering both the impact on producers and consumption levels in the long term, as well as the ongoing criminal investigation. But we must be sure that our compensation is not going into the hands of criminals. This is clear; we will look at the real picture. We will compensate those who were not involved in criminal activities, but those who were involved in criminal activities should be punished, we should not allow them to use our compensation.  Speaking about animal welfare issues, I agree: we need to discuss animal welfare issues. It does not matter what kind of farming – organic, non-conventional, and so on – but I think we have a good opportunity to use the animal welfare platform and to debate those issues, speaking about those questions.  On manure, as I mentioned, we need to understand that zero tolerance is very important, but of course I will ask my services, my advisers, scientists, to see how we may discuss those issues in more detail because it is a very technical question.  I spoke earlier about the collective responsibility that we bear for safeguarding higher standards of food safety and public health. I am heartened therefore that this House has taken such an active interest in this issue and I have listened closely to the debate today. Let me reiterate: we are determined to improve the use of, and coordination between, the Rapid Alert System and the Administrative Assistance and Cooperation System. However, we cannot and should not place the responsibility for the situation exclusively on these systems. They simply cannot function if they are not used correctly.  I feel that our dialogue today demonstrates the value of effective and continuous communication and we will do our best and we will present to you later our outcomes after 26 September and after the Council conclusions.

name: Izaskun Bilbao Barandica (ALDE).
text: - Mr President, silence everyone, because we are making real efforts to listen to a commissioner who is trying to put solutions on the table - and in the face of a problem that greatly concerns us.To those who do not want to listen, please invite them to come out, but remain silent in this plenary session, because this is also part of the image of the European Parliament.

name: Matti Maasikas
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Mr President, honourable Members, I have listened to the debate with great attention – a debate that was carried by deep concern about public health in Europe. The protection of public health in the EU is extremely important. This is why, over the years, the EU has built a comprehensive and solid system to ensure safe food for all and to detect unsafe or adulterated food. The events this summer call for a renewed assessment of this system. At the same time, all actors involved have to remain vigilant and act to ensure that there are no flaws in the functioning of the current system in place. If the in-depth assessment of the fipronil crisis shows the need to review and to improve the system, we should all stand ready to do whatever is required. Commissioner Andriukaitis, besides answering all the questions of substance, also laid out the next steps. 26 September will be the next chance at a high-level meeting to discuss these issues.

name: Przewodniczący. –
text: I close the debate.Written declarations (Rule 162)

name: Clara Eugenia Aguilera García (S&D)
text: written. - We are facing a crisis caused by the fraudulent use of a prohibited substance in the deworming of farm animals intended for consumption. We already know that the risk to health that could arise is low and, since the rapid alert system was activated, the affected products have been destroyed, removed and immobilized. This demonstrates the good functioning of our product traceability system. The contamination starts in the Netherlands and Belgium and there are currently investigations open in several Member States. Prosecutors in these countries will verify the samples and help determine who knew what. On the part of the EC, research continues to draw lessons and improve our well-functioning early warning system. Not so the delay in notifying of some Member State. Apparently, the first cases were detected in late 2016 and until July 20, 2017, the EC did not receive the necessary notification to activate RASFF. The issue will be discussed at a high-level ministerial meeting called for September 26, the conclusions of which will be presented to the Council of Agriculture Ministers on October 10/11.

name: Soledad Cabezón Ruiz (S&D)
text: written. - We are facing a crisis caused by the fraudulent use of a prohibited substance in the deworming of farm animals intended for consumption. We already know that the risk to health that could arise is low and, since the rapid alert system was activated, the affected products have been destroyed, removed and immobilized. This demonstrates the good functioning of our product traceability system. The contamination starts in the Netherlands and Belgium and there are currently investigations open in several Member States. Prosecutors in these countries will verify the samples and help determine who knew what. On the part of the EC, research continues to draw lessons and improve our well-functioning early warning system. Not so the delay in notifying of some Member State. Apparently, the first cases were detected in late 2016 and until July 20, 2017, the EC did not receive the necessary notification to activate RASFF. The issue will be discussed at a high-level ministerial meeting called for September 26, the conclusions of which will be presented to the Council of Agriculture Ministers on October 10/11.

name: Емил Радев (PPE)
text: In written form. - The scandal this summer with eggs infected with fipronil is unforgiving. There are infected eggs and products in 26 Member States and probably dozens more around the world. My homeland Bulgaria is also among the victims. The whole sector is in shock, the market still cannot stabilize, and the losses for farmers, producers and end-users are likely to amount to hundreds of millions of euros. I would like to know from the EC whether the source countries of the problem have duly informed the relevant authorities through the Rapid Alert System for Food and Feed and, if so, within what timeframe? If the EC did not have timely information, what measures does it intend to take against these countries? Can we expect procedures for infringements of European legislation soon, or will a revision and change of notification procedures be sought? I expect citizens to receive timely and reliable information. News on the subject is at times contradictory, which confuses and frightens consumers, while creating additional uncertainty in the market. In this regard, I call on the competent authorities to be fully transparent about the presence of contaminated products and to take adequate action to withdraw them from the market. I am counting on swift and decisive action to prevent the problem and reduce the damage to European producers and consumers.

name: Daciana Octavia Sârbu (S&D)
text: signed up. - The Fipronil egg contamination scandal and its widespread impact raise two categories of issues, in addition to a mandatory improvement of the internal food safety alert system. The first priority is the clear need to investigate how insecticides and plant protection products are generally used in food production. To what extent can we be sure that such substances have not been used illegally in the EU and in the process of obtaining other essential foods such as meat, milk and dairy products, etc.? Controls on the use of these substances or measures such as stricter purchasing rules can prevent future cases of contamination of food with dangerous chemicals, making a major contribution to protecting the health of citizens. The other priority is the need to rebuild EU consumer confidence in food producers. Several cases of fraud have severely affected a sector of the food industry; we are talking about economic costs borne by innocent producers, as well as confusion and suspicion among consumers, who no longer know which products are safe. The Commission has a responsibility to help European food producers and farmers rebuild their relationship of trust with citizens. These two priorities are, of course, connected.

name: Le Président. –
text: Ladies and Gentlemen, Ladies and Gentlemen, Ladies and Gentlemen, Ladies and Gentlemen, it is customary for the newly elected President to address the Assembly when taking office. When I was elected in January, I thought it would be good to wait a bit before sharing my vision with you. It will be a brief speech. This has enabled me to better appreciate the weight of the responsibility which is mine, as President, but also of that which is ours, as an institution and as Members of Parliament. We have less than two years to go before the elections and we have some daunting challenges ahead: terrorism, illegal immigration, jobs, climate change and Brexit. Our fellow citizens ask us to meet their expectations. They come to us because, at European level, we are their only direct interlocutors. In March, I had the honor of signing the Rome Declaration on behalf of Parliament. Our commitment consists in constantly ensuring that the objectives that governments and the European institutions have set for themselves do not remain statements of principle, but translate into concrete responses for our fellow citizens. We adopted, in record time, important and complex files such as the EFSI, the European Fund for Sustainable Development (EEDD), the “data protection” package or the European body of border guards and guards. -cotes. Since the beginning of the year, we have already done a lot. We have stabilized the financial markets, strengthened European venture capital funds and European social entrepreneurship funds, approved the CETA agreement with different positions and eliminated roaming charges. We will vote in a few minutes on measures to ensure the security of the gas supply. Much remains to be done. We want results in the digital single market. We need to modernize our trade policy in order to protect our strategic industries. We need to strengthen the social dimension of the European Union. We need to find an agreement on reforming the emissions trading system and ensuring that the transition to clean energy becomes a reality. The new Terrorism Committee will soon consider how to improve the fight against this scourge. We must work on the "defense" package and further strengthen industrial policy. The most complex task that awaits us remains the “asylum” package. We know the delay is from the Council. However, this does not release us from our duty to do our best to conclude this package before the end of the mandate. Tomorrow we will have the opportunity to discuss all this with the President of the Commission, during the State of the Union debate. Colleagues, we are an extremely complex legislative machine and yet I must say that it works quite well. I am delighted that we can count on a competent, professional and dedicated administration to do this. I will do my best to preserve harmony and good collaboration between the different organs of the House, because on this ultimately depend our efficiency and our capacity for action. Our performance also depends on our working conditions. That is why I pay special attention to the latter. However, colleagues, we do not pass legislation just to be able to announce that "we have done something" in this or that area. We have an obligation to make the right decisions and to make the right choices, because the legislation we pass will affect the lives of 500 million citizens for decades to come. The legislator must be able to discuss in depth all aspects of the legislation under consideration and must take the time to listen first and foremost to our fellow citizens, but also to our conscience. Certainly we must also avoid this resulting in unnecessary lengths and unnecessary delays. I will ensure that the "dead times" in legislative procedures are reduced to the strict minimum. Parliament must contribute to the adoption of quality legislation which aims to solve the problems of our citizens and not to create new ones. But citizens also expect us to defend in Europe and in the world our values ​​and our principles: freedom, solidarity, subsidiarity, human rights and the rule of law, equality between women and men and the social market economy. I am convinced that the political forces represented here are driven by the sincere desire to help improve the situation of our fellow citizens. Dear colleagues, we are also one of the two branches of the budgetary authority. We must perform this function with responsibility, as we have always done, but also with vision. We are about to start discussions on the multiannual financial framework. I am convinced that the new budget must be a political budget, which departs from distributive logic and which is based on clear objectives. We must first make political choices and only then decide on the budgetary means to achieve them, and not the other way around. This Parliament has to express itself several times on the need to establish new own resources. I am personally convinced of this need and I urge to continue thinking and discussing it within our House, as well as with the other institutions. Dear colleges, look at this House. In this hemicycle sit colleagues who come from all regions of Europe, from the most remote corners of our continent and from the outermost regions. Here all the peoples of the European Union are represented. Parliament is the heart of Europe. This Parliament is the only place on the continent where directly elected representatives can openly discuss continental issues. The only place where they can confront each other, get to know each other and work together to solve common problems. In this Assembly, the heads of state of the member countries and of the whole world spoke, eminent personalities, great figures of our time. This gives our Institution a dimension which goes well beyond the role that the treaties confer on it. This dimension must be reinforced. On this occasion, I would like to remind all heads of state of the Union that they have a standing invitation to speak to the plenary. Dear colleagues, in this House we have an invaluable wealth of political sensibilities, opinions and ideas. We all want "a Parliament where people talk", but always on the basis of ideas and mutual respect. We are a living Parliament and I will ensure that all the energies and ideas in this room can be expressed and contribute to discussion and reflection. As I always say, I want to be the Speaker of Parliament, not a Prime Minister. Parliament must put itself back at the head of the reflection on the future of Europe and provide the political impetus that the Union constantly needs. Europe must be changed where it is necessary, but we must move forward. The President of the Commission - whom I thank - has submitted to us a reflection paper on the future of our common project. I know that all political families have led this reflection. The time has come to exchange our respective conclusions, for example during a large open debate in plenary. We will therefore still need to exchange views with the main European players that we should invite here. This will be an opportunity for Parliament to position itself at the center of the debate and to fulfill its proper role as a political discussion forum. Dear colleagues, during his speech investiture, my illustrious predecessor Simone Veil recalled that "democratic control is the first function of any elected assembly". We therefore have a duty to be demanding in exercising this control over the executive. The practice of “Spitzenkandidaten”, inaugurated during the last European elections, further strengthens the bond of political trust between Parliament and the Commission. This development must be consolidated. For the Union to work, the Commission must be able to count on the confidence and support of Parliament. However, this trust is not automatic and must be earned every day. Finally, I advocate good understanding between institutions, mutual respect and loyal cooperation. Our unity is our strength, let us never forget. Our history shows that strengthening the Union has always been accompanied by strengthening Parliament. I remain convinced that the battle to obtain the right of initiative is crucial in this regard and must continue. Strengthening the parliamentary dimension of the Union also requires increasingly close cooperation with national parliaments. Europe will be democratic or it will not be. Let me stress, Parliament is the living heart of democracy and gives the Union democratic legitimacy. Without this Parliament, the Union would be nothing but a congress system, supported by a cold and distant bureaucracy. Parliament ensures and embodies the primacy of politics over bureaucracy. Dear colleagues, Parliament is the real "sounding board" for the expectations of European citizens. We must listen to them, establish a permanent, open and transparent dialogue with them. We are the most open Parliament in the world. My effort throughout my mandate will be to ensure that our doors are open to citizens. Each Member is called upon to play a fundamental role of link between citizens and the institutions of the Union: he is not only a representative citizens to the Union, but also a representative of the Union to citizens. It’s a lot of work, which keeps us busy every moment of our day, including weekends. This is why it must be said loud and clear that MEPs are not just a finger on the voting system or a hand raised in plenary: they are the representatives of the peoples of Europe and deserve to be respected and listened to. They are their voice and they must be able to express it. (Applause) This is my vision and I will do everything in my power to ensure that the dignity of Members of Parliament is preserved and their role enhanced. We must be proud of who we are. I, as President and colleague, am proud of your work, here and outside this Chamber. Thank you for what you do behind the scenes, in the committees, in the political groups, in the various organs of the House and, above all, in your constituencies. I say thank you for the energy you spend every day in meetings, discussions, negotiations, conferences, contacts, meetings with citizens and civil society. Your work is not always visible, but ultimately it ensures the exercise of democracy within the Union.

name: Iratxe García Pérez (S&D).
text: - Mr President, I wanted to inform this House that yesterday a young Spanish aid worker, Lorena Enebral, was assassinated while doing her work as a Red Cross aid worker in Afghanistan.I understand that it is important and necessary that from this Parliament we launch a message of support and solidarity to his family and to the Red Cross and a recognition to all the men and women who dedicate their time, their knowledge and their lives to help others.

name: Przewodniczący. –
text: Thank you for that vote, thank you for your reactions.

name: Przewodniczący. –
text: The next item on the agenda is the vote.(Results and other details of the vote: see Minutes)

name: Dennis de Jong
text: Reporter.- I will be very brief, but since we did not have a plenary debate on my report, I would like to take this opportunity to call on the Commission to quickly and concretely adopt the recommendations that were accepted almost unanimously in the Committee on the Internal Market.to follow.Entrepreneurs are not quick to go to court, certainly not against a parent company.And yet there can be numerous wrongs in the franchise world.In the coming months, I expect the Commission to take action against possible unfair trade practices and also to scrutinize competition policy.We need to get rid of the Commission's passive stance so far.

name: Steven Woolfe (NI).
text: – Mr President, I rise under Rule 184 and refer to the English version of the paper, page 10 of 24, section 4, which makes the sentence that Parliament ‘strongly affirms that the denial of sexual and reproductive health and rights services, including safe and legal abortion, is a form of violence against women’. This clause could effectively make it a criminal offence for anyone who believes in the reduction of abortion or believes in abortion. The accompanying legal paper that is attached to it makes no reference to the potential crime of being an abortion denier. I would therefore ask in respect that the legal team refer to this document and review it once again, otherwise millions of people in the European Union as a result of this could be deemed a criminal immediately upon this vote.

name: Przewodniczący. –
text: Thank you very much.We take note of this speech, although it is a bit to the side of what we will vote on.

name: Przewodniczący. –
text: I hereby close the vote.

name: Diane James (NI).
text: – Mr President, the United Kingdom is a major component of the European Union Space Programme, and in my United Kingdom South—East regional constituency I have companies and universities at the forefront of developing responses to the challenges of space exploration and development. The United Kingdom’s role will not diminish post—Brexit. Hence I voted to ensure that this pivotal role continues as part of a vibrant and energetic response to the challenges from the likes of China, India, Russia and the United States.

name: Stanislav Polčák (PPE).
text: - Mr President, I voted in favor of this report because I consider space to be extremely important, but it is also important to me that the report also contains innovative moments, such as support for small and medium-sized enterprises, support for start-ups in the use of technology., which in its source actually comes from that outer space.At the same time, it was very inspiring for me that the rapporteur also found the role of municipalities and cities in planning the development and use of technologies that come from space.These are, I think, very inspiring stimuli.Not only for this reason, but also, for example, for the simple reason that the space agency is based in Prague and is a very inspiring sector in the development of the European Union, I supported this report.

name: Bogdan Andrzej Zdrojewski (PPE).
text: - Mr Chairman!First of all, I would like to point out that this is a key report.Finally, in this matter it is not a compromise, but an optimal assessment of the important activity of both the European Parliament and the Commission.First of all, I would like to point out that it has been emphasized - which is very important - the need to build long-term financial guarantees.Secondly, it was finally written into the report that the civil - it is true - the civilian space system Galileo and Copernicus must also play a role related to the security of Europe and the security of citizens.And the last thing that I myself bring to your attention is in the report and it covers two issues: the need to improve education and promote the project itself.Its effectiveness depends on it.

name: Diane James (NI).
text: – Mr President, academic further and distance education as part of a life-long learning strategy are to be commended, and they do not require the European Union membership to enact. I have supported this vote to ensure that young people across Member States have a level playing field in terms of the instruments available to achieve their educational goals. The challenge, though, will be for national governments to ensure that commercial suppliers now deliver.

name: Ilhan Kyuchyuk (ALDE).
text: – Mr President, I have supported this vote because life-long learning is a necessity in today’s dynamic, technologically—driven societies. Customised distance learning which offers more flexible access to education is becoming essential, especially for people with special needs and other vulnerable groups, people in employment or people living in remote areas.  Mr President, academic further and distance education are rapidly expanding sectors with significant potential in terms of economic growth and job creation as they pay and play an increasingly important role in facilitating the adaption of workers to economic and technological change throughout their professional lives. It has become clear that in order to remain competitive, and to give low- and high-skilled workers alike the best chance of success, businesses together with education and training institutions need to offer training and career—focused education throughout people’s working lives.

name: Bogdan Andrzej Zdrojewski (PPE).
text: - Mr Chairman!Colleague Milan Zver did a great job here.However, I want to emphasize that in his assessments he was very mild.From my point of view, it was worth supporting this report, but it is also worth emphasizing that distance learning leaves a lot to be desired.In short, we have a lot to do here.While supporting the Bologna system, I would also like to draw attention to its limitations.The variety of education models, as well as their better adaptation or matching to tasks and business markets will serve Europe.Despite the need to support this unification of the entire project, the entire system, i.e. the use of specific matrices, I am still in favor of some diversity, but some flexibility, but some freedom, both at the academic level and below, because it will serve the labor marketin short, our economic and economic prosperity.

name: Момчил Неков (S&D).
text: - Mr President, Mr Zver's report brings to the fore some key issues facing academic continuing and distance education. For many it is difficult to work and study at the same time, while others cannot afford to study at the university they want or move to a more remote place due to lack of financial opportunities. Regular attendance proves to be a challenge for young people living in remote and sparsely populated areas. More flexible education systems, in particular distance learning, can address these challenges. That is why I believe that it is extremely important to guarantee access to it and to improve its quality, so that young people can be more adaptable to changing conditions and become more competitive. I consider it extremely important to pay attention to the need to recognize the skills and competencies acquired outside the regular form of education. Traditional education is not the only path to professional success. Today, employers increasingly value and seek skills that are acquired outside the classroom. It is distance learning that is an opportunity to improve skills and acquire skills without disturbing the balance between work and personal life.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (ECR).
text: - Mr President, online networking of local communities is an important initiative. It should, of course, ensure universal accessibility, without exclusions for both social and economic reasons, but also for reasons of geographical distance. This is especially true for the Aegean islands, such as Agathonisi, a very small island with 154 inhabitants which is constantly threatened by Turkey. This effort therefore strengthens territorial cohesion at the same time. Of course we have to keep in mind that the money has to reach these small communities and the system has to be accessible to everyone. I believe that the fact that there is a view that "first come first served" - that is, the one who comes first and asks will get the money - will in fact strengthen the communities that are more prepared, to the detriment of the communities that are not so ready . At the same time, the system must strengthen rural areas, secure funds and, of course, have free accessibility as provided by the regulation.

name: Michaela Šojdrová (PPE).
text: - Mr President, I think the good news is that the European Parliament has today adopted a proposal for a regulation on promoting internet access in municipalities.I would like to emphasize the importance of regional proportionality and thus the accessibility of municipalities in the regions as well.I would also like to emphasize that the European Parliament has adopted amendments to the European Commission's original proposal, which will avoid duplication and thus eliminate threats to competition.I think this is good news for citizens, especially for countries with a high density of small municipalities, where the internet connection is not yet fully secured.Of course, this also applies to the Czech Republic, and it is important that the European Commission and the Member States make information about this project as accessible to the municipalities as possible.

name: Tibor Szanyi (S&D).
text: - Mr President, I voted in favor of this report because providing free WiFi access is a big step towards reducing the digital divide and creating a digital Europe. After all, everyone needs the Internet today, but broadband internet access is still lower in rural areas in all Member States. It is particularly positive to me that all this has been targeted by the 'Smart Villages' initiative. In addition to and with full internet coverage, further improvements can be made in European villages. The “Smart Villages” initiative will create a living environment with active digital solutions that will stop the destruction of villages, emigration and rural degradation. The 'WiFi4EU' program, which could be a first step towards a digital Europe for many municipalities, is therefore a perfect fit for smart villages.

name: Seán Kelly (PPE).
text: – A Uachtaráin, tugaim lántacaíocht do na moltaí seo agus bhí áthas orm labhairt ar an ábhar ar son mo ghrúpa ar maidin.  Tá sé an-tábhachtach go mbeadh fáil ar an idirlíon ag gach uile shaoránach san Aontas, gan eisceacht, ach ní mar sin atá go háirithe faoin tuath.  I mo thír féin mar shampla, tá a lán áiteanna amuigh faoin tuath agus tá luas an idirlín atá ar fáil dóibh dhá uair níos moille ná mar atá sé, mar shampla, sa phríomhchathair - Baile Átha Cliath. Níl sé seo sásúil; dá bharr tá easpa infheistíochta ann, easpa jabanna, agus tá an t-aos óg ag teitheath na tuaithe.  Is féidir é sin a athrú agus cabhróidh an scéim nua seo chun é sin a dhéanamh.  Chuige sin, molaim gach uile dhuine a bhí páirteach sa scéim seo a thabhairt dúinn agus tá súil agam go gcuirfidh údaráis in Éirinn isteach ar an scéim.

name: Stanislav Polčák (PPE).
text: - Mr President, I also supported this report because access to the Internet is really about the quality of life of each of us. The point is to create comparable conditions for access to the Internet, to connectivity. If you ask in some municipalities or in some territories in Europe whether they have a 3G connection at all, it is like a trip to Mars. And we are already talking about the fifth row of connections. I think that this approach is very important so that the countryside is not depopulated, so that we can really create an intelligent village and help maintain it. There are 6,250 municipalities in the Czech Republic, which is a large number, and this approach represents a great challenge and a great advantage for Czech, Moravian and Silesian villages. At the same time, I would like to criticize the Czech government, because it has not yet used up a crown in the third highest allocation of money to ensure connectivity in this programming period.

name: Diane Dodds (NI).
text: – Mr President, high—speed internet connectivity is an important tool towards encouraging the creation of jobs and attracting inward investment. Since 2008, DUP ministers in the Department for the Economy in Northern Ireland have channelled approximately GBP 65 million into upgrades in our telecoms networks. We are also delighted that, as part of a confidence and supply deal with our Government, GBP 150 million will be invested in ultra-fast broadband across our province over the next two years. It is now important that this money reaches those in greatest need, particularly in rural areas where internet speeds are poor. The Sinn Féin refusal to form an executive government by holding Northern Ireland to ransom because of a political wish list will not stop this vital investment from going ahead. However, it does hold the potential to prevent local Ministers from making local decisions on how it is spent. It is now time that Sinn Féin – and those who in recent weeks have chosen to prop them up – remove all the barriers towards the restoration of devolution in Northern Ireland.

name: Eleonora Forenza (GUE/NGL).
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I wanted to argue the vote against the report, starting with a fundamental consideration: in fact, new investments in renewable energy are being prevented and removed and we absolutely do not trust this rhetoric of new standards of transparency and safety. , which would then be entrusted to the Commission. I wonder what the Commission has done, for example, to achieve security and transparency on the Trans-Adriatic pipeline, which will depart from Azerbaijan and cross the Adriatic Sea; what it has done in terms of transparency, for example, on the scandal involving the family of the President of Azerbaijan and, above all, I wonder what is meant by transparency when the pipeline in question is now explicitly spoken of in terms of mafioduct. I do not sincerely believe that the new energy policy of the European Union can be based on a replacement of Russia with countries like Qatar and Azerbaijan: indeed, we would have expected a more significant breakthrough in terms of investment in renewables.

name: Seán Kelly (PPE).
text: – A Uachtaráin, ba mhaith liom ar dtús comhghairdeas a ghabháil le mo chara, an tUachtarán Jerzy Buzek as ucht an dea-obair a rinne sé sa tuarascáil seo; agus bhí áthas orm coimoibriú leis maidir le hé a chur chun críche. Gan dabht ar bith, tá sé an-tábhachtach go mbeadh gás ar fáil do gach uile thír san Aontas agus go mbeadh bealaí éagsúla chun é a thabhairt isteach i ngach tír. Dá bhrí sin, na moltaí atá anseo cabhróidh siad chun é sin a dhéanamh, agus freisin an comhoibriú a bheidh ann idir na tíortha san Aontas. Beidh sin an-tábhachtach. Maidir le mo thír féin, tá amhras orm go mbeimid ag brath rómhór ar an Ríocht Aontaithe nuair a fhágfaidh siad an tAontas don ghás; an chuid is mó de ag teacht isteach ar chónascadh amháin, agus níl sé seo sláintiúil. Dá bhrí sin, tá seans againn sean-LNG a chur chun críche agus gás a thabhairt isteach sa chás seo, agus is PCI é sin don tír agus tá súil agam gur féidir linn é a thógáil go luath.

name: Stanislav Polčák (PPE).
text: - Mr President, I also supported this report.The reason for my vote is part of the agreement between the European Parliament and the Council at first reading, which includes a regional approach to risk assessment and the creation of a plan of preventive and mitigating measures based on the so-called emergency supply corridors.It is an efficient and effective way to achieve a significantly higher level of energy security.That is the main reason why I supported this draft report or this resolution.The agreement between the European Parliament and the Council also introduces a solidarity clause as a legally binding principle and a last resort.However, this should not be seen as an alternative to market preventive measures, but as a procedure that is the ultima ratio, that is, the last resort.

name: José Inácio Faria (PPE).
text: - Mr President, I voted in favor of this resolution because I believe that the European Union and the Member States must assertively support the maintenance of the global moratorium on commercial whaling and the ban on international trade in whale products. In fact, despite the fact that the International Whaling Commission imposed a worldwide moratorium on commercial whaling, the truth is that Norway continues to hunt whales. In fact, Norway even, in 2017, sharply increased exports of whale meat. It should be noted that products derived from whales are exported from Norway to Japan through at least three ports in the European Union and the European Union, by allowing this transit, is facilitating trade in whale species that are protected by European legislation and whose hunting violates the international ban on commercial whaling. Therefore, the Commission should assess all possibilities to ensure that whale meat cannot be illegally dispatched through European Union ports and the Council and the Commission should adopt a common approach at future meetings of the International Whaling Commission on hunting to whales and must establish contacts with third countries in order to achieve a majority in favor of creating whale sanctuaries. With the adoption of this resolution, the European Union is giving a clear signal of repudiation of this barbaric and inhumane practice.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (ECR).
text: - Mr President, whaling for commercial purposes has been banned worldwide through a moratorium imposed by the International Whaling Commission. And yet, despite this, Japan and especially Norway are constantly violating and violating the decisions of the international community. Thus, since 1993, Norway continues whaling, violating the moratorium and the list of sites. For 2017 we have specific complaints: Norway has increased its whaling quota from 880 to 999 whales. In fact, Norway also uses European Union ports to export whale products to Japan. How is whale meat transported through European Union ports? Are the regulations complied with, in particular Regulation 338 of 1997? I voted in favor of the report under discussion because I believe that Norway is tackling the issue of illegal whaling.

name: Diane James (NI).
text: – Mr President, I have supported this vote, despite real misgivings that it was not taut enough, on the basis that at least it is a step in the right direction. But if the European Union was actually serious about tackling this issue it would propose enforceable sanctions, but of course the European Union is dependent on Norwegian oil and gas, and hence that is a step too far. Norway hunts minke whales under a so-called International Whaling Commission objection, the hunt relies on state subsidies and the government is constantly searching for new markets to exploit – with young people and tourists being major targets. Norway has aggressively fought to retain its right to hunt whales, despite it being unnecessary, uneconomical and unquestionably cruel. I am calling upon Norway to stop it, and to stop it today.

name: Jiří Pospíšil (PPE).
text: - Mr President, the subject of animal protection is very important to me personally.I believe that modern politics must protect animals.Animals are living beings who suffer, and we must perceive these things.Animals are not things.That is why today I supported the European Parliament's resolution, which clearly calls on Norway, which does not comply with the ban on commercial whaling, to start complying with this ban and to stop increasing the quotas that it regulates every year and increases the number of whales caught in this year.Whales are living beings, they have an extremely beneficial benefit for the marine ecosystem.In addition, the method of hunting is extremely unethical and painful for animals.So I am very pleased that we have adopted this resolution and I have fully supported it.

name: Urszula Krupa (ECR).
text: - Mr Chairman!Everyone, especially at a certain level of personal development, including the state level, should counteract all forms of violence against women, both domestic and psychological.However, I voted against the report for a simple reason, as violence should not be combated by violence, and this is the hallmark of the records that treat the refusal to kill a conceived child as violence, among other controversial terms.I also remind those who use the body disposition argument that as humans, we have limited power and cannot control most physiological or automatic functions.The more a conceived child is not a part of the body, it is a separate creature most exposed to violence according to EU law, which says that abortion is a human right.By applying ideological pressure, he also uses violence.

name: Tania González Peñas (GUE/NGL).
text: - Mr President, I voted in favor of the European Union joining the Istanbul Convention, because I believe that we have to be firm in preventing and fighting all forms of violence against women. However, there are still thirteen Member States to sign the Convention, and those that have ratified it still have insufficient policies. This is the case in Spain, where the budget has been reduced for years - which has been denounced by CEDAW - without reducing the number of murders. In a European Union where one in three women over 15 years of age has been the victim of some type of sexist violence, we still have to take giant steps, starting with the housing guarantee for the victims, but also guaranteeing coordination and cooperation between States to avoid cases like that of Juana Rivas, who has gone from being a victim of mistreatment by her partner to being considered guilty due to the absence of legislation that protects her and gives her guarantees. Let's take an example of the social movements that are claiming the fight against machismo and against sexist violence throughout the world, from the Ni una menos marches in Latin America to Black Monday in Poland, from the demonstrations in the United States against the misogyny of Trump to the mobilizations in India and also all the mobilizations in Europe. The women of the world no longer allow their pain to remain invisible. Not one less!

name: Krisztina Morvai (NI).
text: - Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, in connection with the signing of the Istanbul Convention, I would like to inform you that, as a criminal lawyer and a member of the Committee on Women's Rights, I have embarked on an important study, the conclusions and results of which I will share with you. The essence of the research is as follows: I would like to review legally closed criminal cases in which the victim has died as a result of domestic violence, partner abuse or harassment, and I would like to identify common factors in these cases in the history. I would like to state how effective early intervention could have prevented these tragic deaths. I think it is a very important task for us to realize that domestic violence, partner abuse, harassment are potentially life-threatening acts, so we should finally rise above the various ideological struggles that now “gender”, not “gender”, such a party, is so party, there is no place for party politics here, which is why I am asking everyone to come to the research report regardless of party affiliation. I call and look forward to seeing you.

name: Jadwiga Wiśniewska (ECR).
text: - Mr Chairman!At the outset, I would like to emphasize that I am a staunch opponent of all forms of violence against women, however, the Istanbul Convention does not solve the problem of violence, as it is a tool of political and ideological propaganda, which serves to promote a gender concept that is harmful to society.The Convention indicates, ladies and gentlemen, that the source of violence is the stereotypical roles of women and men, and such are the roles of a woman as a mother and wife, and a man as husband and father.For example, in the name of non-discrimination, discrimination is made against those who value the Christian roots of European culture.That is why I voted against this convention.

name: Michaela Šojdrová (PPE).
text: - Mr President, let me explain why I did not vote in favor of the draft report. The European People's Party is in favor of zero tolerance of violence against women, which is why it has also tabled amendments so that we can all vote in favor of this report. Unfortunately, during the vote, the European Parliament rejected our amendments, leaving the report with provisions in which the European Union wants to unduly interfere in the competence of the Member States and calls for the full accession of the EU to the Convention. I agree that ratification is a symbolic gesture that can, in some countries, highlight the problem and force governments to address it. But it must be the free decision of governments and parliaments. Violence is evil and must be opposed. It is necessary to protect those who suffer only because they are weaker, be they women, children, the elderly or the unborn child. I do not see a difference, but unfortunately paragraph four has not been deleted and so the report combines the incompatible, the fight against violence against women and the right to abortion. That is why it is unacceptable to me.

name: Marek Jurek (ECR).
text: - Mr Chairman! Ladies and gentlemen, Recognizing today by Parliament with a broad 60% that protecting the lives of the weakest is a form of violence, confirming it with an even wider majority, seventy percent, this is not, ladies and gentlemen, but an attack on the right to life, because you stopped taking it into account, it is an attack on rights of nations, this is an attack on the future of Europe and this is an attack on our community of fate. Therefore, I do not know what you are counting on, what is more here - contempt or hostility? The hostility of the belief that states that want to protect the lives of the weakest should be ruled out, or the contempt of the belief that we can be bent to this type of practice? One thing is for sure. The political forces which today dominate the leadership of the European Union and which today dominate the largest countries in Europe are leading Europe to catastrophe. We have seen a great many crises: Brexit, the immigration crisis, but the ones that come as a result of this policy that you are running will be even bigger unless we manage to reverse it.

name: Tibor Szanyi (S&D).
text: - Mr President, I voted strongly in favor of this report because I agree with the Commission's proposal that the EU should accede to the Istanbul Convention. This is the first comprehensive, legally binding instrument to prevent and eliminate violence against women and gender-based violence. Unfortunately, Hungary has not yet ratified this convention either, as its government does not put the issue on the agenda in the Hungarian parliament. It seems that the Hungarian government wants to hide behind the skirt of the European Union on this issue, ie they want to free themselves from national ratification, while domestic violence takes more victims than terrorism. So let there be zero tolerance for violence against women! Be the first step on this path! Moreover, personally, I would go even further: let there be zero tolerance for violence against women, children and the elderly!

name: Andrejs Mamikins (S&D).
text: – Mr President, it is the duty of every civilised and cultural society to combat all forms of violence against women and domestic violence. The Istanbul Convention colleagues, however, used this serious issue to introduce for the first time the definition of gender and gender identity that is independent from a person’s sex in the international law. The fight against violence against women, assistance to its victims and education as part of the prevention of violence are among the exclusive competences of the EU Member States. By joining the Istanbul Convention, the EU would violate the Lisbon Treaty and exceed its powers. Today, violence against women and domestic violence is a criminal offence in all the Member States of the EU, but not all of them have ratified the controversial Istanbul Convention because they have many serious doubts about its text. If society loses its ability to distinguish between a man and woman, the fight against violence against women remains only an informal commitment. Such superficial formalism does not help women victims. That is why I voted against.

name: Janusz Korwin-Mikke (NI).
text: – Mr President, I voted no because it goes against the policy of equal rights of sexes. I do not understand why women must be preferred to men. I must inform you that the President of the Silesian branch of our party, who was a doctor in a big hospital in a big Silesian town, says that the number of husbands hurt by their wives is greater than the number of wives hurt by men, because men almost never admit that they have been beaten by a woman. So I do not see why there is this inequality.

name: Diane Dodds (NI).
text: – Mr President, in July, the Department of Justice published statistics which demonstrated that one in eight people in Northern Ireland have suffered domestic violence from a partner. The same survey finds that between 2015 and 2016 victims only reported roughly a third of the worst cases to police. Even more shocking was the fact that three quarters of those serious incidents of abuse occurred within what remained current, active relationships. These are unacceptable figures.  We must do everything in our power to tackle these awful abuses and assist victims to safely and successfully free themselves from abusive domestic environments. It is wrong that the PSNI should currently have to respond to one domestic incident every 19 minutes. I welcome the commitment by the Home Secretary, Amber Rudd, to bring forward domestic legislation in the form of the domestic violence and abuse bill.  International agreements are fine. However, the greatest priority of legislators should be targeted, local interventions that benefit victims in the hardest—to—reach situations.

name: Eleonora Forenza (GUE/NGL).
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, first of all I wanted to ask that this Chamber be called upon to respect fundamental and established truths: the denial, or we could perhaps say denialism, of a phenomenon that has been established, established and of global dimension, such as male violence and against women, it should not be denied in this House, which is why, all the more reason, I claim my vote in favor of the draft resolution. I underline the seriousness of the fact that 13 Member States still have not ratified the Istanbul Convention, in the face of the fact that, instead, in 2030 the objective, among those of sustainable development, of equality and equality between men and women is foreseen . I believe that it is no coincidence that the one against male and state violence against women and against women is a global movement, which has started in Argentina, which is called "Not one less", precisely because the cases of femicide are now they are not cases that concern the news - indeed they are not at all - they are cultural, political, material and symbolic questions, they are questions of civilization. I would just like to say that, as a feminist and as a Member of the European Parliament, I will participate on 28 September in the World Day for the Right to Sexual and Reproductive Self-determination.

name: Jude Kirton-Darling (S&D).
text: – Mr President, I voted in favour today because, through globalisation, companies increasingly rely on long, global supply chains to produce the goods that we consume every day. This poses major challenges to ensure the enforcement of international standards, whether labour rights or environmental protection – an impossible task to undertake on our own. We urgently need common rules with our trading partners so that global value chains amount to more than just offshoring and outsourcing of jobs and pollution, hurting both our workers and the planet. Today’s report offers a key means of achieving this by advocating a shift away from the failed voluntary self—regulation to mandatory due diligence. The OECD is moving on this, the G20 is moving on this, and, whether we are inside or outside the European Union, the Commission and the UK Government must move on this too.

name: Момчил Неков (S&D).
text: - Mr President, the European Union is and remains the largest trade bloc in the world. With this "glory", however, comes responsibility, both to third parties and to our own citizens. I support this report because I believe that the Union should respond even more effectively to social and economic dumping and unfair trade practices and ensure a level playing field. However, this should not only apply in third countries. I would like to express my disapproval of the approach of many multinational companies in the European Union, which are abusing the economic situation of other Member States. Pressure on suppliers and heavy bond contracts are just the tip of the iceberg. The social and economic dumping that some Western politicians are talking about has its dimension in the actions of many of their companies in the countries of the so-called Eastern and Central Europe, which, for example, pay less for equal work and responsibility. This and other similar injustices must stop.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (ECR).
text: - Mr President, globalization, market opening, neoliberalism and the functioning of Outsourcing have essentially succeeded, first, in dismantling the economies of developed countries and, at the same time, in enslaving the peoples of developing countries where multinationals decided to shift production processes, lead to deindustrialisation of developed countries and at the same time ostensibly invest in the developing world, where everyone works for a piece of bread. And there the big multinationals do not even enforce labor rights, they do not enforce the rules and conventions of the International Labor Organization, they do not comply with environmental standards, they lead children to work, they now exploit everyone, and I think that needs to be tackled specifically. measures by the European Union, but also by the world community.

name: Seán Kelly (PPE).
text: – Mr President, as a member of the Committee on International Trade, I fully understand that the global value chain is at the centre of the international economy, trade and investment policy, and I voted in favour of this report.  The resulting innumerable networks involved in international production bring with them opportunities for development and employment, but also exposure to violations of human rights and regulations. The ‘Trade For All’ communication prioritises effectiveness and transparency in trade policy and brings to the forefront the need to promote sustainable development, human rights and good governance in international trade.  I welcome the EU’s many country—specific initiatives, which aim to secure human rights protection and transparency in the context of international trade, and I hope we can continue in this vein.

name: Przewodniczący. –
text: I hereby close the explanation of vote.

name: Presidente. –
text: The session resumed.I greet the Commission and the Council.The next item is the presentation by the Council on its position on the general draft budget of the European Union for the financial year 2018 (2017/2720 (RSP)).I remind the honorable Members that there is no "catch the eye" procedure for this debate and no "blue card" questions will be accepted.

name: Märt Kivine
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Mr President, it is my honour today to present to this great house of democracy the Council position on the draft budget of the European Union for the financial year 2018, as adopted by the Member States on 4 September this year. Respecting the time allocated to discussion, I will be very concise in my remarks. First, on behalf of the Council, I wish to emphasise, and be very clear about, the facts. The Council is bringing forward a draft budget that, both in commitments and payments, proposes increases compared to the 2017 budget. In detail, as follows: an increase of EUR 990 million – 0.6% – compared to the 2017 levels for commitment appropriations and, respectively, an increase of EUR 9.9 billion, or 7.39%, for payment appropriations. Second, the Council attaches great relevance to the fiscal stance of the Union and has therefore moved to increase the contingency margins for next year. We need the EU budget to provide flexibility as much as we need predictability. On this basis, the Council and the Presidency will strive to reach an outcome on next year’s budget that will take the Union forward. The Council seeks to emphasise the expenditure on areas which have the highest European added value and stem from the political priorities of the Union: stimulating growth and jobs, strengthening security and tackling migration. I believe that these priorities are shared by Parliament. At the same time, and respecting the budget process as outlined in the Treaty, the Council sees room for savings and re-sizing of estimates in the initial budget proposed by the Commission without endangering the effective implementation and execution of EU programmes. Having said this, please allow me to take a quick glimpse inside the draft budget and its guiding principles. Sustaining growth and job creation remains one of the Council’s most important priorities. For 2018 the Council wants to support smart and inclusive growth with EUR 76.5 billion in commitments and EUR 66.4 billion in payments, up by 2.1% and 17.5% respectively compared to the 2017 levels.
