With regard to subheading 1a – Competitiveness for Growth and Jobs – the Council acknowledges the importance of this policy area, which shows implementation rates. I would also wish to highlight that the Council proposal suggests growth for the main programmes in subheading 1a as compared to the available benchmark, the 2017 budget. The Council decided to endorse the Commission’s proposal for programmes like COSME, Erasmus+ and nuclear decommissioning. We also retained financing to core areas of Horizon 2020, a research and innovation programme, to the initiatives protecting Union financial interests, the energy projects, to aid economic recovery, the completion of former programmes, and pilot projects and preparatory actions. The Council also accepted the level of appropriations as proposed by the Commission for new initiatives like WiFi4EU, the European Solidarity Corps, as well as the European Fund for Strategic Investments, including an amount in the reserve for its extension. In some budget lines, however, under subheading 1a, the growth rate has been adjusted downwards, mostly due to the expected realistic absorption capacity and reviewing the scope of administrative expenses. Moving forward, as for subheading 1b – Cohesion Policy, the core instrument of the European Union for creating growth and jobs – the Council maintains the level of commitment appropriations as proposed by the Commission while targeted adjustments are being suggested in payments appropriations. The second priority for the Council is to ensure a high level of security and grant adequate financing for migration and related external policies. With this in mind, as regards heading 3, Security and Citizenship, the Council accepts the Commission proposal and continues to provide resources for the programmes and agencies related to migration. The Council also supports the Commission’s proposal to mobilise the Flexibility Instrument to cover the priority needs under this heading. Under heading 4, Global Europe, the draft budget largely based on the Commission’s proposal shows a reduction of appropriations compared to 2017 due to last year’s exceptional contribution of EUR 750 million from the EU budget to the facility for refugees in Turkey. Now allow me to address the issues of headings 2 and 5 in a few words. Under heading 2, Sustainable Growth and Natural Resources, the Council proposes some adjustments mainly affecting the first pillar of the common agricultural policy. The adjustments anticipate the upward revision of agricultural assigned revenues in the forthcoming autumn forecast. Some additional savings were identified under the annual actions of the sustainable fisheries partnership agreements based on past under—implementation. As regards heading 5, Administration, the Council, after a very attentive scrutiny, set the budget of the relevant institutions at what we deem to be an appropriate level, taking into account the specificities of institutions. The Council carried out targeted savings and increased the standard flat-rate abatement on salaries for most institutions and offices. Moreover, the Council adopted a statement about the efforts made to reach the 5% staff reduction target over the period of 2013 to 2017 by Union institutions and EU bodies. There is still some improvement possible in order to fully achieve the target by all institutions. The Council considers that the level of staff needs to be kept under continuous monitoring to ensure that the savings achieved are consolidated. I would like to draw to a conclusion by iterating the following points. The moderation of expenditure growth in the 2018 budget, as compared to the 2017 in certain areas that the Council is suggesting, have been put for your consideration after serious scrutiny by the Council. The guiding underlying principles of the prioritisation were: first, limiting budget growth of some programmes in order to increase flexibility through bigger margins under the MFF ceiling, and secondly, seeking savings in the administrative expenditures whilst reflecting the progress of the programmes and their past execution rate. Further, no reductions were applied to the completion lines of the 2007—2013 programming period in order to maintain a successful path for phasing out the backlog of unpaid bills. No reductions were applied to the core activities of humanitarian aid. Having said this, I am very conscious of the next steps in the budget process. I intend to weigh the forthcoming position that Parliament will adopt with earnest and serious deliberations in exactly the same vein as the Council was serious and deliberative while formulating its position. On those premises and thanking you for hearing out the rationale of the Council position, I hope we can move towards a reasonable and sustained budget for 2018 that will bring maximum benefits for our European citizens.

name: Günther Oettinger
text: Member of the Commission. - Mr President, Mr Minister and ladies and gentlemen representatives of the Council Presidency, ladies and gentlemen, ladies and gentlemen! With knowledge of the foreseeable “Brexit”, 2018 will remain a normal budget year with 28 members. After the Commission presented its draft budget a few months ago, we now have - and we thank you for this - constructive positions from Parliament and the Council, and I believe that the existing differences in the approaches can be brought to a common result very soon. We have no differences in the structure of the budget. We are equally convinced of the goals we want to pursue: growth and employment, doing as much as possible for Europe's competitiveness, managing migration financially, and organizing external and internal security at a high level in the interests of our citizens . The Commission proposal has done everything possible to demonstrate economy in terms of administrative expenditure on staff and material resources and investments. We will and want to have achieved our 5% savings target on time. Now, if the Council's position is to propose another 1.5% cut in spending, we have certain concerns that we need to address because further downsizing would jeopardize our services and job performance capabilities. What I want to say about the cohesion programs is that we continue to assume for next year that the cohesion programs and requests for funds will have reached full speed. We are late, in 2014 and 2015 we didn’t co-finance nearly as much, thereby triggering investments in infrastructure, as it would actually have been possible and desirable. However, in the next year, when we have reached full speed, we want to avoid having outstanding bills in Brussels and that we get a payment backlog. That is why, also in close coordination with the member states, we are convinced that these funds will be used as a need for next year. As the Commission, we are pleased that smaller but important projects such as WiFi4EU or the founding of the European Solidarity Corps are being adequately financed in this start-up and implementation phase and that the Council supports this accordingly. For today I just want to announce that we want to use the deliberations in the trialogue in the next few weeks to convince you of our projects, especially in the future, in the field of research, in the field of competitiveness, in the field of innovation. I am concerned that the Horizon 2020 commitment appropriations are cut by half a billion euros. The Council, Parliament and the Commission decided a few years ago: We want to invest three percent of our gross national product in research and innovation. We're at two percent. The more we talk about it, the less we achieve the goal. Research is the basis for future competitiveness. We Europeans should actually invest 150 billion more annually. To cut half a billion now seems to me to be going in the wrong direction, especially since we only want to finance large-scale research projects in which European added value can be demonstrated. For example, after the cuts, we have to reject three out of four applications in the field of digital technology. We're not catching up with Silicon Valley and the Pentagon and China. Or health research projects - cancer, Alzheimer's, rare diseases, personalized medicine. Cutting back on the health budget means that we are making somewhat slower progress in research into health. In the quantum technology, which I pursued in my previous portfolio, we have taken a flagship initiative with important institutes, industry and the Member States. If we Here, too, if we cut the budget of 130 million by 32 million and at the same time see how Google, Apple, Facebook, Amazon and Microsoft are investing billions, we are sending the wrong signal. We are therefore not fighting for theoretical appropriations, not for the general budgetary dimension. Savings are necessary and possible, but I want to convince you of the projects. And cuts can lead to the cancellation of projects or the delay of projects. Take the cuts at Connecting Europe, at Galileo, at ITER, at Copernicus: you can cut the funds, but then we will finish later. What we don't invest in 2018, we have to invest in 2020, 2021 or 2022. I think we should rather keep the financial resources or even increase them so as not to shift expenses into the future and implement these projects later than the Americans or Asians. And then we will have to look closely at the geopolitical challenges - security, migration - and discuss with you - because you are on site - whether and where cuts are justifiable and which approach is realistic. All in all, when I look at the next financial framework, reaching a compromise in 2018 will be a piece of cake. That is why we could even consider doing without some of the meetings for October and November. The faster, the more tightly we advise, the more time we have to thoroughly prepare the next financial period, where there are billions in gaps. In this case, I don't foresee that for 2018. Thank you very much for the excellent work done by the Council Presidency and Parliament's rapporteurs.

name: Siegfried Mureşan
text: rapporteur. – Mr President, Commissioner Oettinger, Märt Kivine and Estonian Presidency colleagues, welcome here today to the European Parliament. We are now entering a decisive phase in the procedure to agree on an EU budget for 2018. We have spent the first half of the year agreeing on political priorities, and we have done important work together in agreeing that growth, jobs and the safety and the security of citizens have to be the political priorities of the budget of the Union for next year. These are the right priorities because this is what the citizens of Europe expect the Union to deliver and these are exactly the areas where the Union adds value. Now, we need to deliver on the promises which we made together in the first half of the year. We are simply not credible in saying that we want a more innovative European Union and at the same time cutting EUR 491 million from innovation and research programmes. We are not credible in saying that we want infrastructure in Europe to be better: energy, digital, highways, railways and at the same time we cut EUR 111 million from the Connecting Europe Facility and EUR 99 million from large infrastructure projects. The total cuts proposed by the Council are EUR 1.7 billion. Let me be very clear: what the Council is proposing here is a budget for a weaker European Union because less investments today means a weaker European economy in the future. The Commissioner has outlined this with examples from the digital area in a very convincing manner.  The European Commission has understood in the very first half of the year that growth, jobs, safety and security have to be our priorities, and they have put together a very meaningful budget. This is why I also support allocating most of the resources that we have for research, for SMEs, for infrastructure projects, standing by the side of farmers, particularly young farmers, and fulfiling our commitments when it comes to the Cohesion and Structural Funds. The low absorption rates in the first year of this financial programing period for the Cohesion and Structural Funds does not mean that the absorption rate will stay low in the years to come. On the contrary, it means that now projects will be at full speed and the money is needed over the next years. There is no worse signal that the Union can give to SMEs, to citizens and to NGOs than not being able to pay its bills.  This is why I am calling on all sides to come together in the upcoming weeks to put forward a meaningful budget for the Union in 2018 – a budget based on investments, supporting research, innovation, SMEs and important projects – to put money in the good projects that apply for EU funds, to stand by the side of our immediate neighbourhood, be it south, be it east, be it the Western Balkans, improve safety and security, and make use of the agencies of the Union which we have and which are there to improve the safety and security of the citizens of Europe.

name: Richard Ashworth
text: rapporteur. – Mr President, in April this year this House agreed to an increase in the Parliament’s annual budget of 2.3%. Bearing in mind the level of inflation, I thought that was a realistic proposition and I recommend it be taken as a benchmark for the other institutions. So, I am happy to report that the majority of the other institutions accept that point, and I am happy to say that they have made similar proposals.  There are three exceptions that I would mention to the House. First, the European Data Protection Supervisor has been tasked with expanding his activities, and of course this would involve an abnormal expenditure on his part in 2018. Secondly, the European Court of Auditors are faced with a large increase in workload, and this too I accept as a legitimate and a reasonable demand. Finally, the European Court of Justice makes a very strong case for increased funding, both because of raised activity levels and increased translation costs, and for addressing some significant security issues. Faced with these extra costs, therefore, it is my judgement that the Council has cut some of the funding levels too far, and I recommend to this House that we reinstate some of those levels. Nevertheless, to keep the overall level of budget expenditure under control, we need to achieve further savings. In part, I propose to meet those additional costs through efficiency gains, and here I am happy to report that the Court of Auditors have gone some way to meeting us in that respect. But in part two we have to exercise budgetary discipline, and in so doing we will have to redistribute some of the funding.  To that end, I propose to freeze the budgets of the Committee of Regions and the European Economic and Social Committee for the year 2018. I am also conscious that the European External Action Service faces significant rising costs – in part due to increased staffing levels, but also partly due to the cost of the strategic communications programme.  Most of this cost should be absorbed by the EEAS from their current budget, but I do accept there may be need for a small upward adjustment when we have the precise figures.  Mr President, I ask this House to bear in mind that, if you agree with me that the figure agreed for this Parliament of 2.3% is a reasonable and responsible increase, and if we are to apply that to the other sections, then there will be tough, difficult decisions to be made. I look forward to discussing my proposals with the shadows in the coming weeks, and I hope for their support.

name: Märt Kivine
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Mr President, many thanks for your thorough, passionate and deliberative remarks. Let me just comment with a very few words. Commissioner, your case made especially for research is compelling, and I can assure you that the Council has a sympathetic spot in its heart about that. We will take that back to our Council colleagues and we will certainly discuss that going forward in the budget process. It is an excellent point and it is a point to be considered, as you said, thinking about the long-term competitiveness of the continent. Thank you very much, Mr Rapporteur, dear Siegfried. Your passionate points about the infrastructure, the SMEs, the farmers: we take good note of that. This much I can and will promise, and I will discuss them with our Council colleagues and with you, undoubtedly, soon enough, when we start in-depth discussions about the budget. Mr Ashworth, thanks for your remarks. These are excellent points and as such we will take them fully on board in our considerations going forward and treating the administrative costs of the Council. Having said that and recognising that we are about to embark on very close and tight trilogues and other negotiation means, let me make a few more remarks just to conclude today’s discussion. Firstly, I wish to thank you on behalf of the Council and myself and my colleagues for your views, and thank you for presenting them so straightforwardly and frankly. Today’s debate, to my mind, highlighted the fact that we do wish to strive for the common goal, to achieve the best budget we can for the European Union and its citizens. As I have said, I fully respect that the European Parliament may have – and probably will have – a different take on the proposed budget for the year 2018. I can assure you that we will work hard with you after you have formally adopted your position. We know that we can count on the Commission and on you, Mr Oettinger, in helping to converge our positions and suggest skilful and balanced compromise solutions. I wish also to thank Mr Arthuis (even if he is absent), as well as Mr Mureşan and Mr Ashworth, the rapporteurs, for our interaction to date and going forward. Europe as a whole needs a budget which is responsive to citizens’ requests, even if that is a constantly moving target. I am confident that, with the dedication of the European Parliament and the Commission, as well as our own, we will be able to reach an agreement, and a good agreement, in due time.

name: Presidente. –
text: The discussion is closed.Written declarations (Rule 162)

name: Νότης Μαριάς (ECR)
text: in writing. - Viewers in the same project again, with a budget which is a budget of austerity and violent fiscal adjustment. In this way, however, neither the economic crisis nor the refugee crisis can be tackled. Little money is available for employment and growth at a time when Europe is plagued by armies of the unemployed, especially the unemployed of the younger generation. Of course, we must point out that the sums available in the field of immigration are also crumbs, if we take into account the millions of refugees and illegal immigrants who are flooding Europe. Greece has spent more than 2.5 billion euros on tackling the refugee crisis. So we need a lot more money to tackle the big problems that Europe has today.

name: Андрей Новаков (PPE)
text: In written form. - For me as an MEP, a European citizen and especially as a Bulgarian, the EU budget reflects the priorities of the people. For six decades, it has been the shuttle to the political priorities of the Member States and the institutions. € 161 billion is not just money, but Europe's investment in its own future. As a representative of the European Parliament, my greatest responsibility is to defend the interests of European citizens and Bulgarians. Additional funding for road infrastructure and scientific innovation must be a priority in next year's EU budget. The goal is in Bulgaria to be able to finance more of the good projects in these two areas. The data show that there are more quality projects in our country than the Commission can finance. At the same time, in the 2018 budget, I will defend the security and awareness of consumers, as well as European culture. Horizon 2020, the Connectivity Instrument, the Creative Europe Program and the Consumer Protection Program are the shortest path to the prosperity of the citizens of the Union. For the last 25 years, the EU has emerged as an ambitious project, and we must be just as ambitious in the forthcoming budget negotiations. Success is when we manage to take off, even in stormy weather. This applies both to aviation and to the preparation and implementation of the budget.

name: Presidente. –
text: The next item is the report by Bodil Valero, on behalf of the Committee on Foreign Affairs, on "Arms export: implementation of Common Position 2008/944 / CFSP" (2008/944 / CFSP) (A8-0264 /2017).

name: Bodil Valero
text: rapporteur. - Mr President! I would like to begin by thanking all the shadow rapporteurs for their good cooperation. Even though we do not agree on all the details, I understand that we have a great consensus that control of arms exports must be strengthened. We have different political orientations, but when it comes to the issue of preventing weapons from falling into the wrong hands, we agree. Arms export control is an important part of our foreign policy, but it is also becoming an internal political issue as we have witnessed more and more terrorist attacks around Europe carried out by supporters of Daesh, who we know have access to European weapons. Following the terrorist attacks in Catalonia, the focus of the discussion was clearly on arms exports. We had then read in the Spanish media that the king would go to Saudi Arabia to promote arms exports - Spanish arms exports. After the act, the debate came to be about just that. "We want peace - not to sell weapons", was the message on the streets of Barcelona. The connection was arms sales to Saudi Arabia. Saudi Arabia pays for mosques in Europe. Well-integrated young people are radicalized in mosques and commit terrorist acts in Europe. But Saudi Arabia not only supports the financing of radical mosques in Europe but has also systematically re-exported European weapons to the war in Syria, where terrorist groups such as Al Qaeda, the Nusra Front and Daesh have also seized arms. We can never accept that European weapons end up in the hands of terrorists. We have a comprehensive and clear common set of rules in the common position with its eight criteria. It is a strong regulatory framework that could make virtually all arms exports to conflict regions or countries that grossly violate human rights impossible if strictly applied. With the result in hand, we can now state that the Member States' risk assessments have not been satisfactory and that several of the common position's criteria should have stopped exports to, for example, Saudi Arabia. But since it is up to each country to check that it complies with the regulations, the countries can in principle break it without hindrance. But even if the common position has been followed, we are now in the situation that countries that in peacetime bought weapons and other military equipment from us for their own defense today actively participate in wars of aggression in other countries or provide combat groups in other countries with weapons. Then a number of questions arise. Why do some EU countries continue to grant new licenses to countries at war? Can we stop the follow-up deliveries? Can we stop weapons from ending up with other end users? The last two questions do not help the rules with us at present. What we have previously proposed by Parliament is an embargo on Saudi Arabia. Today we propose that the embargo be used in more situations. Embargo is the only effective system we have for stopping exports that is no longer compliant with the regulations. Developments also show that our long-term risk assessments must be so much better. We would need to look not only at what the equipment is to be used for but at the situation in the recipient country as a whole when a permit is granted. We must also ask ourselves how it is possible that 40% of our total arms exports go to the powder keg in the Middle East and only 15% to other European countries, which is our second major market. And is it reasonable that we in Europe have such an overcapacity in weapons systems that we are forced to export so that our activities do not collapse? The arms industry was created to cover the needs of its own defense, but many times jobs are claimed as a basis for continued support. However, I would like to remind you that, according to Article 10 of the common position, labor market reasons are not a basis for export authorizations. In this year's report, we set out a direction and come up with a clear message: The regulations must be followed. The EU should not close its eyes when European weapons are used in violation of our own rules. We also makes some recommendations for changes, including tightening up reporting requirements to enable better scrutiny, the possibility of imposing sanctions on countries that break the rules, and not least, we hope that Federica Mogherini will take the initiative to actually use the embargoin cases where countries violate international humanitarian law.It is not just international peace or the image of Europe that is at stake, but it is also about the security of our own citizens.

name: Matti Maasikas
text: President-in-Office of the Council, on behalf of the Vice-President of the Commission/High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy. – Mr President, speaking on behalf of the High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy, Mrs Mogherini, I welcome both this opportunity to join you today and the preparation and discussion of the report prepared by Ms Valero. This is a testimony to parliamentary scrutiny of arms exports, which is a sound follow-up to transparency applied at EU level on arms export issues. Interaction channels on arms export issues with Parliament and civil society, including NGOs, the academic world and the industry have developed considerably over the years. This is an invaluable achievement and it illustrates that transparency and dialogue can fruitfully take place without prejudice to the respective responsibilities of national and EU stakeholders. At a time when we advocate further transparency worldwide, notably via the Arms Trade Treaty (ATT), we believe it is important to ensure that transparency does not run counter to national and regional security. The EU framework governing arms exports mainly revolves around the EU common position on arms exports adopted in 2008. This framework is unique. It is based on the national responsibility of EU Member States on arms export licensing decisions, together with well-developed information-sharing between the export control authorities of Member States. The risk assessment criteria laid down by the EU common position are comprehensive and far-reaching, notably in terms of respect for human rights and international humanitarian law, the risk of diversion and the impact on internal and regional stability. Their daily application by national licensing offices is supported by the so—called user’s guide that was revised in 2015, notably in order to align it with the Arms Trade Treaty. Against this background of national responsibility exercised with common risk assessment criteria, the overarching objectives of the EU common position are to promote responsible arms export policies and the convergence of national arms export policies. In support of these objectives, the Council and the European External Action Service provide an information-sharing platform which is the dedicated Council working party on arms exports, and an IT platform enabling the exchange of information relevant for risk assessment, including details on license denials. Like the EU guidelines, these information-sharing components have been recently overhauled and updated as a result of the review of the EU common position achieved in 2015. This has contributed – and continues to further contribute – to the convergence of arms export policies as they are being put into practice. Briefly widening the picture outside the EU, in our close neighbourhood a number of third countries have aligned with the criteria of the EU common position. To assist them in their daily operational implementation, the EU has had in place since 2009 an outreach programme funding technical cooperation. The latest phase, covering the years 2016-2017, will come to a close in December, but steps are already being taken to continue the work with a new Council decision for the years 2018 and 2019. Secondly, and moving to an even larger picture, I would like to refer to the Arms Trade Treaty. This Treaty sets unique and widely-accepted standards to achieve greater responsibility and transparency in the arms trade. The ATT entered into force in December 2014 and so far, 130 states have signed it and 92 countries are state parties, including all 28 EU Member States. Of note, however, is that some of the largest arms exporters and importers, such as Russia, China, India and Pakistan, have not signed or ratified it. All diplomatic opportunities are used to encourage countries that have taken no steps towards the Treaty to join it by providing the EU assistance programme where needed and requested. The arms trade is becoming more and more globalised. It is our duty to lead by example when it comes to arms exports from the EU. It is equally our duty to encourage and support other arms manufacturers and traders to apply the ATT standards.

name: Tunne Kelam
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. – Mr President, I would like to thank colleague Valero for her commitment, openness and readiness to understand different points of view, some of which are still there. At the start, I am satisfied that the report clearly confirms the right of every sovereign state to self-defence. Consequently, states also have a legitimate right to acquire military technologies for the support purposes of self-defence.  The common position of eight criteria is a strong commitment by the Member States to systematically control and verify exports of the products of national defence industries. Issuing export licences is based on clear principles. There are several problems with the implementation of the common position, and therefore we support a more demanding and coherent approach. However, the PPE sees no need for extra new criteria or new specific structures or sanctions to enforce control. The first task for us is to secure full and strict implementation with existing commitments. What we need most is more timely and systematic exchange of information on export licences and actual exports. Member States have different ways of acquiring information. Sharing relevant information quickly and regularly is important when other governments have to decide whether to grant an arms export licence or to refuse it, and I welcome the Council’s approach to these problems – especially providing, for example, info-sharing platforms, etc.  Diversion of arms remains a major concern. We fully agree with it. We need to address this problem efficiently through joint strategy and action, both by Member States and the Commission. We have asked for separate votes on paragraph 29 and paragraph 34. Together with the ECR, we hope that colleagues will be able to support them.

name: Inés Ayala Sender
text: on behalf of the S & amp; D Group. - Mr President, I also join in the gratitude and satisfaction for the cooperation with Mrs Valero, which is always very positive, and I also thank her for having incorporated some innovative points, such as the possibility of establishing a list of entities and individuals who are known or suspected of being involved in the illegal arms trade and who, however, also appear as potential partners or partners. Also due to the possibility of incorporating the need to increase security against cyber attacks, especially considering that access to license networks and data on national licenses can also be one of the elements of greatest risk and, therefore, Therefore, there is a need to better train and better educate the people who have that obligation. It has also given us the opportunity to include an aspect related to the future of Brexit - that is, when the UK is no longer in the European Union - so that the UK's ability to maintain the same level of security is not reduced in terms of the international arms trade and control, above all, so don't create some kind of hole. I also thank you very much for having integrated the aspects related to the need to identify and cover whistleblowers, precisely so that they can report, when they have identified it in their companies or even in the administrations, some situation in which they are not The control obligations of the Common Position apply. I also thank you for the possibility - just as we have identified bad practices with a kind of black list - of identifying in third countries those who are doing well and who are applying the control of this export in bilateral trade with the European Union. Finally, I thank you for the need to be able to integrate more and more European and United Nations regulations to arrive at a much stronger approach to arms export control mechanisms.

name: Geoffrey Van Orden
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Mr President, we should remember that our defence industries are vital elements of our national security, as well as our national economic well-being. We should not underestimate their importance. Five European countries are among the world’s top ten arms exporters. Like our armed forces, the arms industries of European countries are well regulated and responsibly controlled. We have export control regimes, primarily to ensure that, as far as possible, weapons and key components do not get into the wrong hands, and by that I mean our potential enemies, rogue states and terrorists. We don’t want to impose more regulation on our own national industries merely to advance the cause of EU political integration, and I should mention that my own country, the United Kingdom, already has a robust and comprehensive arms export control system irrespective, by the way, of EU activity. While there is much in the Valero report we can agree with, we also take issue on a number of points. Most of these concern the constant effort to enhance the role of the EU over its Member States. I very much hope the Parliament will reject any suggestion of sanctions against a Member State not complying with a common position, and similarly, we don’t see the necessity, in these times of budgetary pressure, for the establishment of EU funds to be used for capacity-building among licensing and enforcement officials in Member States. I am pleased that, following the acceptance of our amendment, there is at least mention of the UN’s International Arms Trade Treaty, but this is under-played – and thank you, by the way, Mr Maasikas, for your emphasis on this. We have to ask why there is a necessity for increased EU activity in this area when it is the wider international community that needs to be taking action. In fact, very little mention is made of the countries that have been the worst abusers in the International Arms Trade System, feeding violent insurgency and terrorism in all continents of the world. I think of Russia, Iran, Pakistan, North Korea, China: this is where we should focus our attention. None of these countries are signatories to the UN Arms Trade Treaty, while all EU Member States are. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Molly Scott Cato (Verts/ALE)
text: blue-card question. – This debate on the arms trade coincides with blockades and demonstrations against the world’s biggest so-called ‘arms fair’ taking place in London, and shortly after Prime Minister May’s trade visit to Saudi Arabia. Can I ask Mr Van Orden whether he will vote in favour of the Valero report, which calls for an end to arms sales to Saudi, which are being used to kill Yemeni children?

name: Geoffrey Van Orden (ECR)
text: blue-card answer. – I notice you had prepared your question before I had even started to speak, and also I don’t like the formulation you have used in your question to me. Of course I condemn totally the killing of children and other civilians in situations of armed conflict. But a ban on arms exports to Saudi Arabia? No, I don’t support that. By the way, there was an action taken by the Campaign Against the Arms Trade – and of course, this is where it all comes from – against the United Kingdom Government. It was heard in the High Court of the United Kingdom in July of this year, and the High Court came out in favour of the British Government. We don’t have time for me to read the whole judgment, but I am very happy to circulate it to you. Basically it found that the decision of the Secretary of State of the United Kingdom not to suspend export licences to the Kingdom of Arabia was not irrational or unlawful indeed, and it was fully backed.

name: Javier Nart
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. - Mr President, please, let's not mix legitimate concepts: what is legitimate defense, what does an active defense industry mean; let's not prostitute her with the business. Therefore, it is essential that the eight criteria that were agreed in 2008 are effective, and not simply a rhetorical reference. And the reality - not the rhetoric - is called, for example, Yemen, where hundreds, thousands of people are being bombarded with products made in Europe, and this is a shame. And, consequently, what cannot be said is that what is happening now in the European Union has to continue to happen because the blood business has to keep flowing for the reality of our defense to exist. Do not prostitute my legitimate defense with the obscene business of the blood of others. Consequently, if we have approved the eight criteria, it is to maintain them. If there are penalties for issues of overproduction of milk, for example, it is obscenity that there are no penalties when weapons are sold outside of the eight criteria. And it is a reality that leading export countries are violating the eight criteria. Consequently, either we comply with what we approved or let's be honest: let's eliminate the eight criteria and, in that sense, let's say, cynically, but at least with honesty and honesty, that we are dedicated to selling to whoever buys us because what matters is business and not ethics. That is the bottom line.

name: Sabine Lösing
text: on behalf of the GUE / NGL Group. - Mister President! When I hear Mr van Orden like that, everything is wonderfully organized. But arms exports from the EU countries have been exploding for years. Mr Nart rightly referred to Yemen. So I am glad that the report suggests steps to limit this madness. In some places I would have liked more substance so that we can really make progress in this area. The problem is obvious: as the report emphasizes, the eight criteria actually define the legally binding framework for European arms exports - and this is about European arms exports. Regarding Mr. Kelam: It's not about new criteria. We have to state, however, that almost all states violate these regulations, in some cases considerably - that is what this is about. In Germany, for example - and we're not talking about Russia today - studies show that in 2015 alone over 4,000 export licenses in 76 countries violated these criteria or were classified as problematic. In many other EU countries it could hardly look better. So what we urgently need are three things - unfortunately the report only makes detailed proposals on the first aspect and remains somewhat vague on the other two: what is needed is a uniform and finally complete and rapid reporting obligation on the part of the Member States. It is necessary that compliance with the 8 criteria is verified by an independent body, and sanction mechanisms are necessary for countries that notoriously violate the regulations. Without these measures, EU export regulations will continue to be full of holes like a fishing net and European weapons will fuel wars and conflicts around the world.

name: Ulrike Lunacek
text: on behalf of the Verts / ALE Group. - Mr President, Minister, ladies and gentlemen! In the debate about refugee movements in recent years, we have seen more and more that the question of the causes of flight and how to deal with them is also coming to the fore. On the one hand, it is about fair trade relations so that people's livelihoods are not destroyed and they are driven out and then have to flee. But it is also about arms exports. And I would really like to thank my Green colleague Bodil Valero for this excellent report, which makes it clear that the common EU position on arms exports from 2008 is legally binding and that arms exports to warring countries and to countries opposed to humanitarian action are legally binding Violate the law, prohibit. That is why I also support the demand that all arms exports to Saudi Arabia be banned, because Saudi Arabia is waging war in Yemen - that has already been mentioned. It must be clear that this can no longer be the case. My home country Austria also delivered 30,000 small arms to Saudi Arabia last year. This bloodshed in Yemen must finally come to an end. I support the demand and call on the EU Foreign Minister, Mrs Mogherini, to actually initiate an arms embargo against Saudi Arabia.

name: James Carver
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. – Mr President, the export of arms and munitions should depend on the assessment of an individual and truly sovereign government. Whilst critical and sceptical of many areas of my own government’s policy in this area, I believe that such policy must always remain in their hands alone and thereby be directly accountable to the British electorate. It is well known that such a contentious issue will always factor into a general election campaign. The aims of this report precisely restrict that democratic accountability by suggesting that following Brexit, the UK should remain tied to the common EU position. I firmly reject this notion, and whilst Her Majesty’s Government has remained light on detailing our future defence arrangements and foreign policy ties through their future partnership paper, released only this morning, it is, quite frankly, vague and lacking in detail. Such a lack of clarity is unhelpful to all sides and will probably only serve to further frustrate matters. It is not good enough. To truly regain our independence in this area, the UK must withdraw from the EU military command structure and work on a truly bilateral basis and where necessary, use NATO as a conduit on areas of operational crossover. That is what the British electorate voted for when deciding to leave the European Union in last year’s referendum.

name: Jean-Luc Schaffhauser
text: on behalf of the ENF group. - Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, this report will further worsen the rules on arms exports from the Member States, while these rules and their use already hamper the freedom of our States. We saw it in the Mistral affair, where France, by breaking its word, destroyed the confidence that potential buyers could have in it. And we followed the recommendations. Yet when Western weapons have to arrive in the hands of neo-Nazi groups, like in Ukraine, or jihadist groups, like in Syria, or the Middle East, which has a very special vision of democracy and human rights , so that remains possible, with the support of the Commission and even with the support of this Parliament, for certain countries. We cannot subjugate the credibility and independence of France abroad. Our sovereignty is at stake. It is time for France to leave this Europe.

name: Michael Gahler (PPE).
text: - Madam President, lugupeetud härra Maasikas. Thank you for your comments. I am glad that we have this debate every year, because the subject is an important one for our foreign policy. First of all, it should be recognized that we as the European Union are the only region in this world that has such a demanding catalog of criteria as to when something should not be delivered. This catalog is actually a recommendation to other parts of the world to orient themselves on it. At the same time, part of the realism is that we would probably not have this common position of the Council if it were not for the Member States to apply these criteria to their own exports and then to decide whether they correspond to them or not. That is also part of the truth. Nonetheless, it is entirely appropriate for us to speak regularly about the situation in certain conflict zones within the framework of the relevant working groups of the Council. It would be good if the result of such debates would be to come to common positions on a specific conflict region. That would serve the security of the world as a whole and the respective conflict regions. The debate must continue in the Council. And if at all, then the national parliaments should debate whether their respective governments comply with these criteria, but not others who are not called to do so.

name: Tonino Picula (S&D).
text: - Madam President, the report rightly emphasizes that states have a legitimate right to procure military technology for defense purposes. But we must not ignore the fact that much is not transparent in arms exports, there is no standardized system of verification and reporting. The lack of transparency harms companies that develop and produce defense technology in compliance with all regulations, but we cannot ignore the data that the end users of exported weapons often do not meet the criteria of common positions. Almost one hundred billion euros of licenses issued for the export of weapons a year from the European Union is a huge amount of money. Let us not hesitate to ask for a greater level of transparency about where money and weapons come from and where they end up. The international community is often late in political reactions after the outbreak of armed conflict. That is why we need clear criteria that will regulate arms exports. Deteriorating security opportunities at the global level, but the lack of a common European defense policy, fragmentation and duplication of resources are the causes of the expansionary export of military technology. These are also the best arguments for strengthening security and defense integration with the European Defense Union.

name: Ruža Tomašić (ECR).
text: - Mr President, weapons exported by European manufacturers to third countries often end up in the wrong hands and are used to commit serious war crimes and violations of humanitarian law. As disturbing as it may be, we will find it difficult to change that, because war in itself is a great disaster that can, as a rule, bring the worst out of people. The character of the military industry is such that it depends on conflicts, and even if we manage to control sales to third countries, we still cannot stop further resale. Weapons will find their way to whoever needs them because, after all, it is man who kills, not weapons. This initiative to bring the military industry of the member states under the control of the High Representative for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy will not yield results, and represents another attempt by the Union to appropriate new competencies. In the end, I can't agree to that, especially because I think it would only benefit large producers, while quality producers who follow the rules from small Member States would not have a chance.

name: Miguel Urbán Crespo (GUE/NGL).
text: - Mr President, a report published yesterday by Amnesty International stated that each year firearms kill around half a million people. And several million more are caught in brutal conflicts fueled by irresponsible arms sales. Irresponsibility such as showering Saudi Arabia with arms, which bombs schools, hospitals and other civilian infrastructure in Yemen. Or train Saudi pilots in Spain to subsequently intervene in military operations in Yemen, violating international humanitarian law. From here we urge not only the European institutions, but especially the Spanish Government and the royal house to review business and military relations with countries such as Saudi Arabia and Qatar. Business interests can never condition foreign policy or take precedence over human rights. This report contains very positive elements in relation to compliance with international treaties, human rights and transparency. We understand that the main thing is not only to vote in favor of this report, but to commit ourselves not to remain a dead letter.

name: Klaus Buchner (Verts/ALE).
text: - Mister President! The European Parliament has today spoken out clearly against arms exports to crisis areas. But it is shameful that my home country Germany is still one of the main exporters of weapons to crisis areas worldwide. Regardless of who becomes Federal Chancellor on September 24th - Merkel or Schulz - the countless arms exports will continue. Merkel, Gabriel and Schulz like to portray themselves in public as the rescuers of the refugees, but the black-and-red government fueled many of the causes of flight through its arms exports. She has delivered to countries like Qatar, Egypt and Saudi Arabia that use German exports to oppress their own people. Turkey also fights the Kurds with German weapons. Saudi Arabia itself is waging war in Yemen with German weapons. Egypt bombs its own people - ostensibly to fight terrorists. For me it is incredibly hypocritical when we create the causes of flight and then let ourselves be celebrated as human friends because we take in these refugees.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD).
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, it has been more than a year and a half since we discussed the previous dossier on the implementation of the common position on arms exports. Since then, very little has changed: the arms business is proceeding at full speed for the member states, with increasing exports to countries with dubious democratic standards: Egypt, Saudi Arabia and Turkey are in fact among the main buyers. Yes, Saudi Arabia, against which we in this Parliament asked to impose an arms embargo in February 2016, considering exports to Riyadh in violation of the European common position. My country, Italy, has even seen a real boom in exports to Saudi Arabia, which went from EUR 257 million to EUR 427 million in 2016. We speak and vote but the Member States are deaf to our words: bombs continue to fall on Yemen, and beyond; civilians and children continue to die: our hands are stained with blood. An constraint of eight criteria unchecked and without sanctions is just a hypocritical way to simulate a semblance of respectability. That is what my amendment has been saying for years, and I thank rapporteur Bodil Valero for having accepted it this year in her report. In 2012, the European Union won the Nobel Peace Prize: it is time for you to start being worthy of it.

name: Gilles Lebreton (ENF).
text: - Mr President, national defense is a national competence and it must remain so.Every state has the right to acquire military technology to defend itself, and it has the right to freely export its weapons.Care must be taken, however, to avoid selling arms to states that turn them against us, either directly or through terrorist organizations.I therefore approve of the Valero report when it emphasizes the usefulness of consultation between European states, including with the United Kingdom.I approve of him even more when he advises them to decide on an embargo on the sale of arms to Saudi Arabia.I am, on the other hand, outraged by the Valero report when it seeks to give the Union the power to authorize or not allow states to export their arms.Such a recommendation is contrary to national sovereignty.That’s why I’ll be voting against it.

name: Michèle Alliot-Marie (PPE).
text: - Mr. President, when we talk about national defense or the export of arms, we cannot just say anything. In particular, it should be remembered today that the major arms exporting countries - and in particular European countries - respect extremely precise standards, international standards and European standards. And that even some countries - including France - have national standards that are even stricter than European standards. We must then recall, when we talk about these subjects, the convergence of interests, ultimately, of the countries in particular in the face of terrorism, in the fight against trafficking, which is necessary, in the face of the destabilization of a certain number of countries. In a world where conflicts are initially local but increasingly internationalized, it is obvious that there is a certain solidarity and that we cannot refuse countries to be able to defend themselves, and especially when they share the same values ​​as ours. A priori rejecting arms exports, as some advocate, is a purely ideological position. This is to deny countries the right to defend themselves, it is to deny, in the name of blind naivety or no less blind angelism, our fellow citizens the right to be protected. Strictly controlling arms exports, yes it is an obvious moral and ethical legal requirement, but refusing exports in the name of a pacifist utopia is to pave the way for others who will not have the same scruples. that we. (The speaker accepts to answer a 'blue card' question (Rule 162 (8) of the Rules))

name: Ulrike Lunacek (Verts/ALE)
text: Ask about the “blue card” procedure.- Mrs. Alliot-Marie!You say that this report is a pacifist report and that member states cannot be banned from exporting arms.The common EU position on arms exports was decided by the member states, by the governments of the member states, including France, and there are eight criteria to which countries no arms may be exported, for example when that country is at war.And Saudi Arabia is at war with Yemen.Civil targets are being bombed there, markets and residential areas are being bombed there, there are thousands of dead and injured in this country due to arms exports from France, Germany and possibly also from Austria and Great Britain and others.Do you really consider it legitimate to say here that this is somehow pacifist nonsense?This is about human lives and wars that are promoted!

name: Michèle Alliot-Marie (PPE)
text: answer "blue card". - Mrs. Lunacek, war I know what it is. As Minister of Defense, I have been to countries at war and I have indeed seen what it means. So from that point of view, I know it. In your question, there are actually two elements. The first concerns the criteria. Yes, countries have set criteria, I told you, especially European countries, and I told you that France was the country that had the strictest criteria in the whole world on arms exports. So that's the first thing. With regard to Saudi Arabia - I hear you talk a lot about Saudi Arabia - I remind you that I chair the delegation for relations between the European Union and the countries of the Arabian Gulf. So if you are talking about Saudi Arabia, maybe also talking about Iran and those who are indeed causing so much damage to the people. Look at reports from other countries and also remember one thing, that the All Arab Gulf Coalition intervened at the behest of the legitimate Yemeni government. So are you saying that you are supporting rebels against legitimate governments? This is also the question you are asking.

name: Ana Gomes (S&D).
text: - Monsieur le Président, je soutiens absolument ce that Mme Lunacek came from directing Mme Alliot-Marie et je lui rappelle that c'était sous la Présidence française that cette position commune est devenue une position commune. I would like to thank colleague Bodil Valero, in this line, for the report that identifies the problem of arms export control in the European Union and that several Member States, including France, do not comply with the common position, systematically violating its eight criteria. A striking example is precisely the export of arms to Saudi Arabia. This Parliament requested, already in February 2016, the arms embargo to the European Union due to the criminal war of aggression against Yemen and could talk about many more aspects and the case of Saudi Arabia cannot deny the other cases, but it is a case. The transfer of arms, regardless of the nature of the importing regime, fuels conflict and repression, with disproportionate effects for civilians, threatens global security and our security, the European one, because arms exported to third countries re-enter the European Union through the trafficking of weapons and can end up in the hands of terrorist groups, as was seen in France, by the way. It is essential that we create an independent supervisory authority and a standardized verification and notification mechanism for Member States with sanctions. There is an urgent need for post-export controls to ensure that arms are not re-exported to destinations and end users that do not meet the criteria of the common position and it is also crucial to ensure that the post-Brexit United Kingdom remains legally bound by the common position. .

name: Christofer Fjellner (PPE).
text: - Mr President! In this matter, it is easy to become popular or maybe I should say populist. It reads something like this: "Weapons are terrible, they kill people and therefore we should ban arms exports." However, the export of munitions is ultimately a matter of defense and security policy. In defense and security policy, there are rarely any simple truths. Which defense industry companies are allowed to sell what, to whom and when, must be assessed individually, and this changes very often over time. But what this issue is really about is something else. It is about who should decide on this. In Sweden, few politicians would probably say that they want something other than that "in Sweden we decide on Swedish arms exports, on Swedish defense and security policy". In this vote, however, I believe that very many, especially the red-greens, will learn to follow Bodil Valero's position, which means that we must have the common position that must be followed by sanctions. It is to make it supranational, to give up parts of our self-determination when it comes to defense and security policy. It is as if subsidiarity is an outer coat that you can take off when it is uncomfortable and put on again when you have to show yourself to the voters, but no one will accept that. I am convinced that we need to do a lot more when it comes to cooperation in the defense industry. On the other hand, having joint decision-making to a greater extent when it comes to defense exports, I think, only leads to mistakes. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question) (Rule 162 (8))

name: Bodil Valero (Verts/ALE)
text: question ("blue card").- I must then ask the question where you have found the information that Sweden or the Member States would not decide on their own arms exports.The common position is minimum rules.That is what we have jointly committed to follow - that is the minimum level.You, Christofer Fjellner, know just like me that in Sweden we are making our regulations even stricter.We will continue on that path.Your party is in it, my party is in it.Nowhere in this report does it say that we are trying to stop arms exports, but it is about controlling the arms exports we have and compliance with the regulations - the common regulations.

name: Christofer Fjellner (PPE)
text: answer ("blue card").- You do not mention the small crucial difference between what is today the common position and what you demand, namely that sanctions be introduced against those who make a different assessment for these issues to change over time.If it is the case that the EU has the opportunity to impose sanctions and punish those countries that make a different assessment, then it is by definition supranational.I am convinced that your report will pass with a fairly large majority.I must congratulate you on that to some extent.Happily, however, I do not think there is a chance that this with sanctions will become a reality.I am convinced that the Member States, like me, value having national competence and safeguard national competence and stop the idea of sanctions.

name: Soraya Post (S&D).
text: - Mr President! I would like to begin by thanking the rapporteur, Bodil Valero, for her work. As a representative of the Feminist Initiative and as a crystal clear convinced pacifist, it is always worrying for me to vote for weapons in all their forms. However, I support the fact that we must increase control over arms exports from the EU. It needs. Most recently today, The Economist wrote that the world's global arms trade is booming. An even better way is to ban arms production altogether. On July 17, the UN took a historic decision to ban all nuclear weapons. Then it was above all the women's and peace movement that had fought for this for many years. Many did not think it was possible to get such a ban. "It's never possible," the fighting activists were told. But the pessimists were wrong. It is possible to abolish weapons, and that is exactly how we are changing the world - with a feminist vision that we can create a peaceful world without weapons, through dialogue.

name: Gilles Pargneaux (S&D).
text: - Mr President, in this messy, unstable, too dangerous world, it is obvious that we must build a Europe of defense.Yesterday, it was an ever stronger reality, today it is a necessity that must be implemented, in accordance with our values, by combining responsibility and trust.Responsibility in building this Europe of defense.Giant steps have been taken over the past year.Our Parliament must support them.Confidence, because in a rule of law like ours, we must be accountable, that is the stake of this Valero report, which rightly calls for control of arms exports for better transparency in this sector.Responsibility, in a Europe of defense that protects us, the confidence of our fellow citizens in our action for our collective security, this is our European message today.

name: Sergio Gaetano Cofferati (S&D).
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I sincerely believe that Europe needs new, stricter and more effective rules regarding the control of arms exports. The picture we have before us is disturbing. Two things have happened in the last few years: the first, commented on several times, is the increase in arms exports by the 28 countries of the European Union. The second would deserve a little more attention and instead is neglected: we are faced with a systematic and growing violation of the eight criteria that should manage and underlie this process of exchange between production and purchase by the countries that they ask. Now, without new rules, without a sanctioning system worthy of the name, we will continue to preach peace and at the same time, sometimes even unwittingly - but this does not change the responsibilities - to fuel war. It is therefore essential to change direction and it is essential to do what is recommended by the excellent proposal of rapporteur Valero.

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D).
text: – Madam President, it is highly important to have a consistent and coherent implementation of the EU common position, which is essential for the EU’s credibility as a values-based global actor. Given the impact of arms exports on human security, arms control should be strict, transparent, effective and accepted by all parties. Therefore, the Member States should respect the legally-binding nature of the common position and comply with the minimum requirements arising therein. I believe that the implementation of the common position requires more strict application of the common criteria and improved transparency of the EU arms export control system, especially in light of the most recent figures, according to which exports from the EU28 amounted to 26-27% of the global total in 2012-2016. Last but not least, in order to strengthen compliance with reporting obligations, I support the development of a tough sanctioning mechanism for Member States which fail to comply with the common position.

name: Arne Lietz (S&D).
text: - Madam President! As the report of the European Parliament makes clear, there has unfortunately been really no progress in the implementation of the eight EU criteria for arms exports that have existed since 2008. Unfortunately, not all member states adhere to the common, legally binding catalog of criteria. That is why I support the report's call for EU countries that violate this to be sanctioned. I also expressly support the European Parliament's call, repeated in the report, for an EU arms embargo on Saudi Arabia. We finally need a coherent European foreign policy in which all Member States agree on the export of armaments and technologies. Our Chancellor candidate Martin Schulz rightly says that it cannot be that some member states of the EU no longer export arms to problematic countries, while other member states continue to deliver to the same countries. I would like to reply to my German colleague, Mr Buchner, that, in contrast to the CDU, which is not demanding anything, social democracy in Germany would like to ban the export of small arms and light weapons to third countries in the federal election program or would like to reduce exports. Our goal must finally be a uniform, restrictive arms export policy for all of Europe.

name: Kateřina Konečná (GUE/NGL).
text: - Madam President, this report shows how dangerous we are.We currently see the largest volume of arms transfers since the end of the Cold War.The European Union is the second largest exporter of arms, 86% of which end up in the Middle East, a region torn apart by long-standing conflicts.The report rightly states that some Member States are entering into strategic partnerships with countries where human rights are being violated.However, what is fundamentally missing from the report is the call for a reduction in the amount of money for armaments.I hope no one here thinks the former US President Bush's statement is that the more soldiers, the more peace.The European Union is the winner of the Nobel Peace Prize and is also the second largest arms exporter, and that is hypocritical.It is hypocritical and cost human lives.Let's think about it!

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (NI).
text: Madam President, it is well known that the defense industry contributes significantly to the shielding of the national armed forces but also to the GDP of each Member State. But there is unfair competition and impunity for companies from major arms exporting states, which are involved in scandals and illegal financing in order to secure similar contracts. The implementation of a Union arms export field will not provide solutions in this direction, but will create barriers to cross-border defense armaments sales and sales to third countries. The European defense industry, as a vital factor in the credibility of the emerging common security and defense policy, is doomed to failure due to the existence of different defense objectives between Member States and the simultaneous absence of common defense orientations. Proof is the complete absence of the Union in the practical confrontation of Turkey's aggression against Greece and the Republic of Cyprus.

name: Jean-Paul Denanot (S&D).
text: - Madam President, many of us here are deeply pacifists, but we must not be naive. That is why I welcome Mrs Valero's balanced report. He insists on several necessities. Obviously, those of defense but also those of industry and armaments. Here too, we must not be naive because we know very well that Russia, China and the United States, to name a few, have a very competitive arms industry. But what interests me most in this report are the criteria that we want to put forward: first, indeed, respect for human rights in importing countries, the behavior of States, both internally and internationally, and then compliance with precautionary principles. I believe that, from this point of view, we have to be very vigilant because we have seen that a number of weapons and technologies have ended up in hands which did not have only pacifist intentions. Next, we must fight against smuggling and illegal trade and ensure the transparency of transactions - this seems very important to me - before national parliaments, but also increasingly before the European Parliament, for a Europe of defense that, like Gilles Pargneaux, I call my wishes.

name: Krisztina Morvai (NI).
text: - Madam President, my country, Hungary, has been saying for a long time that we should focus on the roots of the migratory flood and the refugee crisis. Such roots are armed conflicts, and it would be time to finally raise the issue of responsibility now as well. Because my country, Hungary, is not responsible for these things. For example, whose excellent idea was that the Assad regime should be overthrown in Syria and that various groups, most of them terrorists, should be armed to do so? Perhaps those who benefited from this should now receive Syrian refugees. Similarly, who invented weapons of mass destruction in Iraq and therefore launched a bloody war against Iraq? Who benefited from this war? Maybe they should take responsibility. Who thought that the Gaddafi regime should be overthrown in Libya so that they could not catch those coming from black Africa, sub-Saharan Africa? It would be good to clarify and stop these responsibility issues for Hungary now ... (The President cut off the speaker)

name: Julie Ward (S&D).
text: – Madam President, as we are speaking, the Defence and Security Equipment International Fair is happening right now in London’s Docklands where it happens every two years. It features 1 500 or more exhibitors from all around the world, displaying arms ranging from sniper rifles, to tanks, to combat aircraft, to warships. They are joined by trade visitors and military delegations, including those from human rights abusing regimes and countries involved in conflict. This fair is organised by Clarion Events and the British Government department’s Defence and Security Organisation, whose support is crucial to its success. But it takes place in secret, behind heavily protected security fences and police lines designed to allow arms dealers to trade their wares unhindered by transparency or public protest, and it is subsidised by the UK taxpayer. So I really welcome this report and all the people who have spoken in support of more transparency.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D).
text: - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, between 2012 and 2016 the volume of weapons marketed reached alarming figures, higher than in any other five years since the end of the Cold War. There has been an increase of almost 10% compared to the previous five-year reference period, accompanied by a greater number of exports to countries classified as "problematic" in the light of the common European position, in particular to the Middle East. It is clear that these data reflect a profoundly changed, unstable and constantly evolving international context. The time has come, however, to introduce a new criterion in the common position, a criterion that takes due account of the risk of corruption and diversion in the export of arms, avoiding that European technologies end up fueling conflicts that we ourselves have an interest in. to solve. In this sense, greater interaction between COARM and SIAE is desirable, in order to better understand the situation in the destination countries and identify potential end users of European technologies.

name: Matti Maasikas
text: President-in-Office of the Council, on behalf of the Vice-President of the Commission/High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy. – Madam President, I would like to thank Members very much for this debate. It has again become clear that arms exports is a field paved with extremely complex sets of issues: humane, moral, economic, geopolitical, political and so on. I will not go into these issues here, but I want to support what Michael Gahler said earlier in this debate, namely that, of all arms exporters, the EU has the most robust system in place for oversight and reporting, with criteria in place, probably in the whole world. That is perhaps not something that can be appreciated by everybody, but it is at least a fact that must be acknowledged by everybody, including in this House. There were two more specific sets of questions, the first concerning arms exports to the countries in the Middle East region, more particularly to countries like Syria, Saudi Arabia, Iraq and Yemen. I was referring to the criteria, and criteria No 2, the human rights criteria, was used as a reason for denial of an export licence 72 times in the year 2015 and 89 times in the year 2016. You may say it is not enough, but it is also a trend to be observed. As for the calls to issue an EU arms export embargo for any particular country in the world, it must be known for that that the unanimous support of all EU Member States is needed.  Now let me thank you for this very useful exchange. One of the main achievements of the EU common position relates to increased transparency across the EU on arms export issues. Our discussion today demonstrates that detailed information is regularly made available at EU level and open for parliamentary and public scrutiny. The fact that national decisions on arms exports are reported, and therefore questioned, in turn supports the responsibility of the competent authorities and fosters their accountability. This nexus between transparency and responsibility is the essence of the EU common position and, at the larger global level, of the Arms Trade Treaty.  The EU common position specifies very clearly that licensing decisions remain at the national discretion of EU Member States. Against this background of national responsibility, the EU common position supports greater convergence through a number of common elements and information sharing. As such, convergence remains, by definition, always a work in progress. The improvements decided as a result of the review of the EU common position have supported further convergence. Undoubtedly, greater parliamentary scrutiny at the national and the EU level, as called for by the present report, can further incentivise convergence. Let me close on this note of truly shared interests and by signalling once again my appreciation of Parliament’s role in keeping this important issue on the agenda.

name: Bodil Valero
text: rapporteur. - The debate really shows how different perceptions we can have in this house but also how important it is. I would have liked to have answered Geoffrey van Orden, who complained that we are not talking about the rest of the world at this stage, but it is in fact the case that we are talking about European export controls. That is why we are talking about Europe's exports, not other countries' exports. As I said earlier, we are not talking about stopping all arms exports. Nor are we talking about countries not having the right to defend themselves. However, it seems that there is an opinion from some here in the house that this is what we are saying. Then I would like to urge them to read the report again before they vote tomorrow. I mentioned that we have a common position, and that is a very good set of rules. I completely agree that it is a good set of rules if we really use it. Now it turns out that we mean that these criteria are violated in many different cases. According to a study that has been done, they are violated - according to COARM's study. Nevertheless, Member States consider that they have a stricter regulatory framework than the common position actually is. Then I have to ask myself if this is really the case. I just heard that France has the strictest regulations. I have previously heard that the British have the strictest regulations. In my country, we say that we have the strictest regulations. However, it is not about who has the strictest regulations, but it is about us following the common rules that we actually have. We have agreed on this - we will follow this. Then we can have stricter rules than the common position, but we can not have less strict rules and refer only to national law. We also have the Arms Trade Treaty, where there is an article that we do not have either in the common position or in Swedish legislation, and it is about gender-based violence. It is also something that we read into human rights, but that is a criterion that we do not include.We will also have that at some point in the future, I hope.When we then discuss where the level should be, I mean that we must always focus on having the best possible practice and not the worst possible practice.We must reach high, not aim low.

name: La Présidente. –
text: The debate is closed.The vote will take place on Wednesday, September 13, 2017. Written statements (Rule 162)

name: Janusz Zemke (S&D)
text: in writing.- The countries of the European Union are a large supplier of arms in the world, and the value of exports from the EU constitutes 26% of total arms exports.This means that the EU is the second largest arms exporter after the United States (33%), ahead of Russia (23%).Arms exports to the Middle East have in practice doubled in the past few years.The problem, however, is that some of these weapons end up in unstable states and are sometimes used not only in armed conflicts, but also for internal repression.There are also cases where weapons from EU countries end up in terrorist groups, e.g. in Syria and Iraq.All this means that the Union should radically increase controls on arms exports.Export permits must also include risk assessments of the firearm going to a recipient other than that specified in the order.

name: La Présidente. –
text: The next item is the debate on the statement by the Vice-President of the Commission and High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy on the situation in North Korea (2017/2826 (RSP)).

name: Federica Mogherini
text: VPC/HR. – Madame la Présidente, permettez-moi de remercier la Présidence estonienne pour avoir pris le débat précédent à ma place. I would like to thank the Hemicycle for the opportunity to debate an issue that has not often been on the agenda of our work here in the European Parliament but has been very much at the centre of our European Union work in diplomatic terms in the last years. I would also like to start by thanking the UN Security Council and all its Members for the new resolution on North Korea that was adopted just hours ago. I believe that in tough moments like this – the level of threat posed by North Korea to the region and the world is quite clear and unprecedented – only a united international community can help build effective solutions. This is needed because we are still far from the goal of a complete, verifiable and irreversible denuclearisation of the Korean Peninsula. Yet the international community did the right thing a few hours ago – strengthening the pressure on North Korea while calling at the same time for a peaceful solution to the crisis through a meaningful, credible, political dialogue; strengthening economic pressure – sanctions – and keeping the door of dialogue open, encouraging a meaningful, political diplomatic solution – a peaceful solution to this crisis.
