Because we can do it. We are the richest continent in the world, we are the best organised, the most civilised continent in the world. If we cannot do it, then who can? (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Tibor Szanyi (S&D)
text: Blue card question.- Thank you very much, Madam Member.I agree with many of what you have said, but my question is whether you agree - this was a UN statement recently - that there are two things among the deepest causes of migration: one is the climate, we all know that., the other is bad governance.By the way, I think that this should be changed, and not just the consequence, which is migration.What do you think about this?

name: Sophia in ‘t Veld (ALDE)
text: blue-card answer. – I am not a sociologist or anything, but there are many, many different causes – and there always have been, throughout history –that have pushed people to move: it may be war, persecution, violence or poverty, but interestingly experts now also say that as African countries are developing, people actually have more means to become mobile. So it may actually be that it’s not just poverty pushing them out; there may also be other reasons. I’m pretty convinced that climate change, too – I mean just look at the images of the extreme conditions – is going to push people to move. So we should stop clinging to this myth of ‘Fortress Europe’ and start managing migration.

name: Barbara Spinelli
text: on behalf of the GUE / NGL Group. - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I imagine that the Vice-President knows the warnings from the UN High Commissioner and Doctors Without Borders about the Paris agreements on Libya, Chad and Niger. The warnings talk about detention camps, where migrants suffer violence and death. The NGO alarm also concerns Chad and Niger control of the escape routes south of Libya. They will be, assisted by Europeans, to control the oases where the caravans stop to quench their thirst. The new routes will be mined or without water wells. The truth is that Africa will become our prison, of unprecedented proportions, which we co-finance. And the most impressive thing is that the Union is aware of this: it does not ignore that 80% of the displaced are already in Africa, that a very small part arrives in Europe, that Libya has not signed the Geneva Convention. Nevertheless, the Union rejoices at the decrease in flows, of the mocked smugglers. This rejoicing is the darkest chapter of its present history. Defining detention centers as unacceptable is pointless, given that the Union has accepted them! The sure thing is that she will not be able to say, when she will be held accountable - because sooner or later she will be - "we didn't know".

name: Judith Sargentini
text: on behalf of the Verts / ALE Group. –Fewer boats have arrived in Italy in recent weeks. Of course, fewer people who can drown is good news. But why is it that fewer boats leave Libya and do we know what happens to those people who do not leave, where those people are now? We cannot protect people in Libya. You are not in Libya and in fact international organizations such as IOM and UNHCR are not in Libya either. There are no international camps under protection in Libya. There are none. There is no reception of international organizations. So we don't know exactly what is happening, but we do hear about assault, about rape, about the slave trade and even about murder in detention centers. Can you guarantee, Mrs Mogherini, that you will not be here again next year to tell us that something terrible has happened to those people in Libya that we are not letting go or that we are returning? So fewer people get on boats, but are fewer people leaving, for example, from a village somewhere in West Gambia? Are there actually more young women and men staying in, for example, the village of Dankunku? This is in The Gambia and we have been there with the Human Rights Commission, a village where there is no work. Are fewer young people actually leaving there? Where are your proposals to achieve that, the real poverty reduction? Because that is what we would like: that boys and girls do not have to leave Dankunku or all those other villages in Africa, where people dream of a better life.

name: Laura Ferrara
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I listened to Vice President Mogherini's speech. I agree on one thing: you told us about internal contradictions in the European Union. And, I add, also a great hypocrisy within the European Union. We talked about humanitarian issues, we talked about violence, torture, we talked about people who are extremely vulnerable and in need of protection. But we note a strong internal contradiction in the European Union between an ideal model, a Union made up of solidarity, cooperation, protection of fundamental rights, and a real model, which is visible to all, of the European Union: a cynical model, a ruthless model, a model that is ready to continue to follow the trend already undertaken with the agreements with Turkey and, therefore, to give money, whatever the cost, as long as the arrivals of migrants in Europe cease. So, if we have to look at the facts - I take your invitation - let's look at the facts: we see that the European Union has allocated EUR 46 million for Libya. However, we have an investigation by a news agency, the Associated Press, which was picked up by the main newspapers across Europe and around the world, which tells us about an agreement between the government of Tripoli and the militiamen. An agreement that seems to have even been supported by the Italian government: it seems that Italian officials were present. So, this is unacceptable to us. I ask you, Vice President Mogherini, as Vice President of the Commission and as an Italian, to ascertain whether what emerged from this investigation is true. Because it would be completely unacceptable for a European Union that advocates for fundamental rights to allocate EUR 46 million to fundamentally pay militiamen, fundamentally to pay for traffickers, who were previously paid by desperate asylum seekers, ready to do anything to escape from war situations e of persecutions; today we have traffickers who are probably paid with EU funds to block those same landings. Then we must shed light on what is happening, because otherwise it is useless to continue talking about compassion, solidarity, cooperation. We must face the facts: this is not the European Union that looks after the protection of fundamental rights. We want a European Union where there is real cooperation, where there is real control over where these funds that are allocated go. We need to see if this money goes into the hands of the traffickers. We have the recent ruling by the Court of Justice of the European Union, which rejected Hungary's appeals for the failure to relocate migrants. Here, then, we want a European Union in which the rules and principles, the values ​​contained in the treaties, are respected. We want solidarity, we want cooperation, we want respect for fundamental rights, we want the management of migratory flows not to be entrusted to traffickers but there are legal and safe ways of access for those who have the right to international protection.

name: Mario Borghezio
text: on behalf of the ENF Group. - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, the accusation of hypocrisy is partial, because there is another one: it is that of duplicity, because you in this House thanked the NGOs, but you forgot to say even one word on the shadows that are gathering over the work of some of them and, above all, in claiming the blocking of landings for the European Union, he did not spend a word to defend Minister Minniti, of whom I am an opponent in Italy, but that he was a gentleman for his honesty, publicly declaring as a minister that he had decided to take a tough action to block the landings, because Italy's democratic holding was threatened! Because the Italians were sick of landings! We need to talk about these things: even when we remember the conditions of migrants in Libya, we must remember in what conditions this European Union has that gentleman Erdogan keep the migrants who have been blocked on the way to the Balkans! You are a gang of hypocrites!

name: Udo Voigt (NI).
text: - Madam President!Ms. Mogherini, I appreciate a lot of your diplomatic activities, especially in the Middle East.But today I have to ask you: who do you represent?Do you represent the peoples of Africa or do you represent the peoples of Europe?You said that behind all the numbers there are people who have names, who have bad experiences.Ms. Mogherini, behind the many thousands of victims of terror and Islamist violence in Europe there are also people who have names, who have relatives, who have friends, who have lost loved ones who have been torn out of life.Why are there not these incidents in Poland, not in Hungary, not in Slovakia, not in the Czech Republic?Yes, because they operate a border guard and don't let such people into their country.I propose that we entrust the security of Europe's external borders to the Hungarians and Poles so that our people are safe again in the future.

name: Tomáš Zdechovský (PPE).
text: - Madam President, I would like to warn you in advance that, at the end, I will have a technical note on what you did during this meeting. I would like to begin by thanking you, Madam High Representative, for today's speech, and I would like to highlight a few positive things that deserve attention. Firstly, the good news is that many aspects of the crisis are gradually improving, whether it is effective identification procedures, the introduction of new security features, the functioning of Frontex or bilateral agreements with Turkey and Libya. All of these things are gradually mitigating the effects of the crisis, and we see that the European Union is taking steps in the right direction and must continue to do so. However, this is the imaginary tip of the iceberg of the whole migration crisis, because there are also many negative phenomena that the entire European Union must deal with and, for example, help to address the countries most affected by the economic crisis, namely Italy. It is, for example, the cooperation of some non-profit organizations with smugglers, which has been pointed out by the Italian authorities. The biggest shock, however, is that a number of renowned organizations are on the list of these revealed non-profit organizations, which proves the depth of this problem. There is an exploitation of refugees and migrants, it is not just about the financial profit that these organizations get from it. I mentioned this last night and I am happy to repeat it, it is necessary to mobilize forces to combat this business and it is necessary for the European Union to help the Italian Government to force these organizations to stop this business with migrants. And now to a technical remark: can you, Madam President, tell me, according to which rule is not a blue card granted to someone who has speaking time in the debate? And the second question is, why do you selectively repeatedly deny me blue cards when I want to respond to someone in plenary?

name: Die Präsidentin.
text: - Mr. Zdechovský!That is one of the possibilities that we have here from the Bureau, when we are very advanced in the time, that we declare that those who are either still talking in the same debate or those who have already spoken in the debate,no longer get the floor over a blue card.I didn't come at the beginning of the debate, I came a little later.You then asked for the floor.After looking at the passage of time, I have decided, and will now say this again, that no one who is still on the list, but also no one who has already spoken, like Mrs in 't Veld, who is now giving you a blue oneWanted to ask a card, I gave the floor.I hope you can accept that.

name: Elena Valenciano (S&D).
text: - Madam President, the truth is that I believe that without foreign action there is no possible migration policy, and in my group we have always defended that the management of migration requires a global perspective, which is what the high representative defends. I want to thank you, Mrs Mogherini, not only for all the work that she does, but for her commitment, her dedication and her responsibility to this Parliament, to which she is always accountable. My colleagues have said many things that I would also repeat, but it is a shame, because time here is money. It seems to me that what is happening is that the short term - which is what the Council practices - is undermining the long-term solution. Foreign action is deployed to go to the root of the problems, above all. Because if we don't go to the root of the problems, we are simply not solving the crisis, which is not a crisis, because it is a structural problem. But as the Member States want immediate solutions, as the message that is being sold is that we must try to prevent migrants and refugees from reaching our borders, all the work that is done in the long term is damaged because the European Union appears, also, as the one that does not respect international law - we are talking about children, we could talk about women - as that unit that, in reality, is fractured and does not respect its own commitments. So, in reality, one institution is hurting the work of the other two.

name: Bernd Kölmel (ECR).
text: - Madam President! I should very much like to take up the words of the Commissioner who said that we must not lose sight of the realities. One of the realities of course is in particular: What are the Member States of the European Union actually ready for when we talk about aid? I have the feeling that this is permanently neglected here. There is a representative here for every country, there are many representatives. But we also have to have the courage to decide and say: To what extent can we help? Because reality means that we cannot plan anything in the dark that we cannot then realize at all. It is precisely this topic that requires us to be very sensitive on the one hand, but also to say in clear words what is feasible and what cannot. I have absolutely no understanding that we are now only referring to the humanitarian aspect. We all agree: Of course we want to help, but we cannot help indefinitely! That's why we have to define the framework of what is feasible for us.

name: Angelika Mlinar (ALDE).
text: - Madam President, dear High Representative! I would like to start with a statement which, if misinterpreted, may sound quite provocative. I am of the opinion: Africa needs more capitalism. However, not in the sense of the often assumed exploitative expression of the word, but in the sense of the possibilities to offer incentives for individuals to be innovative, to invest and to create added value. As long as Africa's population grows much faster than its economy and the governments put their own power interests before the well-being of the population, people will always emigrate and flee, and each one of us would do that too. Development aid must therefore always go hand in hand with building sustainable political and economic structures. I therefore believe that we need to focus on specific projects at the local level. The Committee of the Regions' Nicosia Initiative is a good example. Unfortunately, it is underfunded and not well known. But if we find 1,000 European cities that enter into a partnership with 1,000 cities in Africa and cooperate there from building and operating a hospital to garbage disposal or agriculture, we will achieve tangible improvements for the individual. At the same time, we should create a kind of European Fulbright system. African students should come to the European Union for a year or two and then return to their home country. The know-how we have gathered can achieve a lot more on site than the usual help that disappears in missing structures.

name: Malin Björk (GUE/NGL).
text: - Madam President! Criticism of the policies pursued and the externalization of EU borders is in fact widespread. It comes from NGOs, from Médecins Sans Frontières, from Amnesty, from Human Rights Watch, from the UN Commissioner for Human Rights, from the UN Commissioner for the Rights of Migrants, from Unicef. Still, I do not think that you, Federica Mogherini, respond to that criticism. You pretend it barely existed. The EU today is associated with deportations to war and conflict, to dirty deals with Erdoğan and now with Libya, to a continent that is forcing people to remain in completely inhumane conditions in Libya. Those who save lives in the Mediterranean are even accused of collaborating with smugglers and stopping their activities. How low should we sink? Criticism of this policy is growing. In Sweden, we now have a popular movement that demands that "Fort Europa" be stopped and that deportations to Afghanistan, for example, be stopped. The people - if you work together - do not want to see a "Fort Europe". They want to see an EU that creates safe and legal roads - which you also mentioned - and that takes joint responsibility for providing protection to people.

name: Barbara Lochbihler (Verts/ALE).
text: - Madam President! The objective of European refugee policy is clear: With the relocation of the European external borders far into the African continent, as many refugees as possible should be prevented from reaching the EU's external borders. The idea of ​​introducing European asylum procedures in African countries is not new. A German interior minister campaigned for this back in 2004. At that time, the contradiction between isolationist interests and human rights claims in favor of the human rights of refugees emerged. Today the outsourcing of the European asylum procedure to Africa is simply announced. Breaches of international law and violations of international conventions are becoming more and more a matter of course, from the EU-Turkey agreement to deportations to war zones. Breaches of the law, broken words and the mantra-like repetition of false claims and political errors shape the European refugee policy and that of many member states. Instead of making migration possible in a regulated manner, one makes oneself dependent on dictators, promotes the militarization of unstable regions such as currently in the Sahel belt and favors mafia militias. This policy not only harms those directly affected, it attacks the very foundations of the EU itself, namely the rule of law as the political basis and human rights as the ethical basis, and will therefore change Europe negatively.

name: Kristina Winberg (EFDD).
text: - Madam President! The European Union and its proponents have decided that they know better and have higher skills than the Member States themselves. Brussels will now have central control over, among other things, how many migrants a country can handle. Now the Visegrád countries have been forced to become multicultural or at least receive thousands of migrants. Do they want it? No! Did they vote for it? No, they do not. The ruling elite and the various leaders in Europe's countries are constantly finding new solutions. In September 2015, there were mandatory quotas. In May 2016, there was a permanent redistribution mechanism. You talked a lot about distribution keys last year. Now it's hotspots that apply. Macron and Merkel have already bypassed the EU and want to conclude an agreement on this themselves, but what if they set up a system of hotspots at the same time as we have a distribution mechanism? Should Sweden be forced to accept migrants through this mechanism as well? New ideas are constantly being put forward on how to force this migration on the people of Europe, and this shows that they are not trying to solve the root of the problem but only making mass migration to Europe a permanent state. Will it be a modular house in Bratislava now? Sitting strikes in Budapest? It remains to be seen, but the voters in 2019 may ask themselves whether they should trust us who have warned that migration is not the solution to all problems or those who have recently realized this. The choice is therefore between strong and secure nation-states that I am fighting for or forced migration to an increasingly insecure Europe that the Dublin IV rapporteur is fighting for.

name: Auke Zijlstra (ENF).
text: - There are few good developments in immigration policy.The Libyan Coast Guard does our job, but the so-called refugees are still coming.Once completed, they are not deported.The additional crime is not combated.In the EU, it now appears to be possible to pose as a refugee, almost kill someone, travel to another EU country and actually kill someone there.And apparently we still sing “welcome, welcome to my country”.But it is great that this Afghan will soon be able to pick up his possible family thanks to the EU.Because where would we be without such a highly educated role model?Mr President, the refugee treaty, family migration, the NGOs, together with Brussels' look-away behavior, are now literally a deadly cocktail.Fortunately, we still have Poland and Hungary.

name: Teresa Jiménez-Becerril Barrio (PPE).
text: - Madam President, High Representative, one of the fundamental objectives of the European Union is to have a forward-looking immigration policy, based on solidarity to address both legal and irregular immigration, and no one can say that we have stayed idly facing the migration crisis we have experienced in recent years, aggravated by the war in Syria and the situation in Libya. The Agreement with Turkey has slowed migration flows avoiding deaths in the eastern Mediterranean, but the problem has moved to another dangerous route between Libya and Italy, where traffickers have made the market in human beings their way of life. I therefore welcome the Commission's measures to assist Libya in border management and immigration, and also the extension of the Sofia military mission to combat human trafficking in the central Mediterranean. The answer to the migration challenge is to collaborate with the countries of origin and transit in matters of return and border control. But if we continue without solving the causes that cause people to have to emigrate, such as war, terrorism and extreme poverty, our effort will be useless. Nobody leaves their land, their home and endangers the lives of their children, if it is not because death is on their heels. Those are the refugees that I have seen in Greece, in Italy, in Lebanon, all with the same look of hopelessness. Looking for an answer that does not arrive, because there is a gap between what is said and what is done. Relocation mechanisms are slow, and we must step up the pace of reception. Relocation is not a choice, it is an obligation for all Member States. The security of the external borders must be strengthened, because it is the best way to preserve the free movement of people, which for me is one of the greatest advances in this European project. Finally, I want to remember that last year one of every three asylum seekers was a child, and I ask for greater protection for those children who flee from war and do so by facing dangers alone.

name: Tanja Fajon (S&D).
text: - There is no doubt that without resolving the situation in Africa and the Middle East, we will not be able to stop the deaths of people fleeing to the European continent. And that without global cooperation, without politicians with vision and courage, we will not succeed, so thank you. We reiterate that we need a common migration and asylum policy, but it seems that we are increasingly moving away from it or forgetting the humanity and dignity of migrants and refugees. The European Court of Justice in Luxembourg has ruled against Slovakia and Hungary, which do not participate in the scheme for the transfer of beneficiaries of international protection from Italy and Greece. The deadline for relocating 160,000 people will expire at the end of September. How will the Commission act? The Czech Republic, Poland and Hungary are still not cooperating. The latter asks for money for a fence. Austria is still exercising control with the army on the Schengen border with Slovenia. What are these messages, colleagues? If we do not regulate the situation in Europe ourselves, we will not solve it elsewhere in the world with credibility. And pushing problems to Libya without guaranteeing human rights is unacceptable. You have mentioned safe and legal routes, but there are no new proposals. The fight against criminal groups is crucial. More than 300 people arrived in Cyprus on Saturday, paying the smugglers $ 2,000 each. And it seems to me that here we are continuing our efforts for what you yourself have mentioned, for an opportunity for all people anywhere. For life.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (ECR).
text: - Madam President, recent developments on immigration are of particular concern. Migration flows from Turkey have increased in the Aegean islands. In Lesvos, Chios, Samos the inseparable now prevails. Migration flows have increased as generous benefits are now being given to those refugees and mainly illegal immigrants coming from Turkey. Benefits that include cash withdrawal cards amounting to 400 euros per month, provision of free housing and medical care, as well as promises for the provision of state, agricultural land for exploitation. At the same time, asylum procedures and deportations are done at a snail's pace. Finally, the 66,400 relocation program, which ends in a few days, has been implemented by about 18%, as France, Germany and other countries have not fulfilled their obligations, while some Eastern European countries, despite the relevant decision of the Court of Justice European Union, refuse to accept any relocation. The Aegean islands can not stand other refugees and illegal immigrants.

name: Marina Albiol Guzmán (GUE/NGL).
text: - Madam president; Mrs Mogherini, I think you have forgotten to explain the most important aspects of agreements such as the European Union with Libya or Niger, the real objective: that no one reaches Europe; or rather, that no one leaves Africa. They have managed to turn around migration and asylum policies. They no longer focus on reception, but on the contrary: no one set foot in Europe. It is no longer enough for them to lock them up in the CIE when they arrive here, or to deport them to Afghanistan, or to kick them back to Morocco. Now they go further. The borders of the European Union are controlled by Libyan militias. They are arming and financing those who enslave human beings. In Sudan they give political cover to a president who is being searched and captured by the International Criminal Court for genocide, in exchange for him arresting anyone who goes north. And in Turkey, Erdogan continues his repressive escalation with his approval, in exchange for him building walls.

name: Eva Joly (Verts/ALE).
text: - Madam President, Madam High Representative, Cédric Herrou, farmer, sentenced to four months in prison for having helped migrants to cross the Italian border. Pierre-Alain Mannoni, teacher-researcher, sentenced to two months in prison for having helped three Eritreans. In the Mediterranean, NGOs accused of colluding with smugglers and of creating an appeal. In France, in Europe, in 2017, solidarity is a crime. By overcoming the inactions of states, these women and men are the heroes of today. Human beings will continue to risk their lives, not for a shower in Calais but to escape war and poverty. The question is no longer whether we should welcome them but how we will welcome them. Outsourcing their fate to Libyan criminal networks or authoritarian regimes will not put an end to migration or their cause. It is time for States to show themselves responsible and equal to these ordinary heroes who honor the values ​​of a humane and united Europe.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD).
text: - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, kind High Representative, the recent containment of migratory flows from Libya must not lead us to believe that the worst is over. The agreements with the Libyan government, while on the one hand have led to an undoubted reduction in landings, on the other hand risk leaving thousands of Sub-Saharanians trapped in real concentration camps, such as that of Saba, where there is no respect for rights humans. We cannot have any illusions. The agreement with Libya is only a buffer measure that must be accompanied by long-term solutions, aimed at eradicating the root causes of migration through a policy of cooperation and sustainable development, which places people's rights and job creation for young people. Remember that the African population will grow to more than 2.5 billion people by 2050, and we cannot allow the agenda to be dictated by the usual economic interests of multinationals. The EU-AU Summit in Addis Ababa must be the time for this new beginning. Africa is the mirror of our ambitions as a geopolitical actor: it is up to us to decide which image we want it to reflect.

name: Edouard Ferrand (ENF).
text: - Madam President, Madam High Representative, ladies and gentlemen, every time the European Union has seized an area of ​​competence exclusively, it has been a disaster. I want to quote here the steel industry. Today, Europe hardly produces any steel. I want to quote fishing. Today, traditional fishing has been sacrificed for industrial fishing. I also want to talk about agriculture. Today, unfortunately, our continent, which was a great agricultural country, has been sacrificed in the face of the free trade treaty. Now you tell us about immigration. I think it's even worse with this immigration policy. It’s worse than fishing, worse than farming. Today, the immigration policy that you are proposing to us is a crazy and dramatic opening, precisely for the peoples of Europe. What your policy is about is migratory submersion, the programmed disappearance of our peoples and our civilization.

name: Carlos Coelho (PPE).
text: - Madam President, dear colleagues, Madam Commissioner - High Representative, I have repeatedly reiterated that the response to this crisis develops at two levels and in two stages: responding to the humanitarian emergency that requires immediate action and through structural measures that they focus on problems at the origin and which are necessarily medium and long term. Now, the truth is that we have been in emergency mode for three years. Serious and effective measures, in conjunction with countries of origin and transit, have fallen far short of what is necessary. How can we be announcing again measures that had been agreed and foreseen at the Valletta Summit, which took place in 2015? How can we still be waiting for contributions from Member States to the Africa Fund? I was pleased to see the joint statement you made with President Macron and other heads of state. However, there were - again - more declarations of will and with little news. One last word: when we realized the scale of the problem in Greece, we negotiated an agreement with Turkey to reduce arrivals to the Greek coast. When there was an increase in arrivals in Italy, we increased collaboration with Libya, including operations of a military nature. Today we are wondering what to do with the people who, in increasing numbers, arrive in Spain ... Commissioner - High Representative, we need structural responses. The Union's foreign policy, which you coordinate, is in this crucial context. This house expects greater commitment from you and the Member States.

name: Knut Fleckenstein (S&D).
text: - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen! That’s tough stuff, what you hear here. I think that should not simply be taken note of without being contradicted. It's not about opening the borders for everyone who wants to get in here. It's not about some romantic feeling to take people in here, but about two things: One is a minimum of humanity towards those who have come a long way because for various reasons they can no longer live at home. The second is a common rule of law that is actually aimed at all member states. It does not work when Hungary and others say: Let the European Court of Justice decide what it wants, we will not do it, and then we will pretend that the Commission is to blame, because it does its humanitarian work from the start could have been. In my opinion, migration policy is about three things: On the one hand, having a common policy of solidarity on how to deal with the people who have arrived here - that was far from being achieved. We have failed completely, needless to say, and there is no improvement in sight. Nor is any of the Council here who would like to hear that. And there are ways in which we can begin to have our first successes: namely in combating the causes on site and in what we do in between. Let me say one sentence, you said yes, we can talk a little longer, that's why I didn't pick up a blue card - just one sentence: What started out positively, I'm a little afraid of the order . I would prefer to first put the camps in Libya in order and then take actions like Sophia ... (The President cut off the speaker)

name: Zdzisław Krasnodębski (ECR).
text: - Madam President!From what Mrs Mogherini said, it appears that the Union has finally understood that it is necessary to help first of all on the spot and that external borders must be effectively protected.We are all ready for such help.On the other hand, the idea that Europe can accept millions of immigrants without causing a political and social catastrophe in Europe is a dangerous pipe dream, and the refugee issue is another matter, and here, as Mr Fleckenstein rightly said, they are mixed up.And it is the states that have the right to decide on the influx of immigrants to their territory, and it is free European societies, and no one else, that can decide on their ethnic and religious makeup.

name: Salvatore Domenico Pogliese (PPE).
text: - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I have received with great satisfaction the outcome of the Paris Summit on Immigration, which I believe represented a fundamental stage and which marks the radical change in Europe's approach to this absolutely strategic and on which a large slice of the credibility of our Europe is at stake. A radical change hoped for and urged also within this Chamber and which is finally ratified today, probably belatedly but which must nevertheless be received with great satisfaction. The absolute need for the modification of Dublin 3, which represents the real anomaly of the European reception system, the need also to act upstream and not downstream, through an extraordinary aid plan for Africa which the President constantly speaks of Tajani, also through active collaboration with countries of transit and departure - I am thinking of Libya, Niger, Chad - to identify migrants and to contain or prevent departures, especially of those who do not have the right to political asylum and other international safeguards. The strengthening and acceleration of returns are just some of the issues included in the joint declaration of great significance: but now we must be absolutely consequential and we must add in the shortest possible time to the modification of Dublin 3 within the Parliament and, subsequently, within the Council. Pending this happening, we need to accelerate on the issue of relocations, which have now reached 17% compared to the original plan. That is why, in line with what this Parliament proposed in its resolution of 18 May, the deadline must be extended beyond 26 September in order to ensure that the 160 000 asylum seekers are relocated. (The speaker agreed to answer a "blue card" question (Rule 162 (8)).

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D)
text: blue-card question. – In fact I attended a visit in Sicily, together with my colleague Pogliese from Italy, and I noticed the terrible situation that the Italian authorities, and also Frontex and other European Union institutions, are facing, considering the number of migrants crossing the Mediterranean. We absolutely have to show solidarity with all these countries. At the same time I am going to ask my colleague if he knows that a new route for unregulated illegal migration was opened over the Black Sea from Turkey to Bulgaria and Romania, and we are facing a terrible situation as well. (The President cut off the speaker)

name: Salvatore Domenico Pogliese (PPE)
text: Answer to a "blue card" question.- Italy has always been a land of welcome and continues to be, but we must welcome those who flee wars, discrimination and we cannot welcome everyone, and therefore economic migrants.I am perfectly aware of these new routes that are being trafficked today by human traffickers: the Italian system, in this sense, is absolutely efficient.I hope, I repeat, that a synthesis will be found among the requests for solidarity with regard to refugees, but we must be equally uncompromising towards economic migrants.

name: Andrea Cozzolino (S&D).
text: - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, as you have effectively pointed out, for years we have been immersed in a confrontation - and in part this is demonstrated by today's debate - a very hard and difficult public in the heart of Europe, which has prompted the debate on the phenomenon of migration as a matter of pure emergency, momentary and with internal security policies. The structural datum of the phenomenon is completely obscured: the conditions of a great reality such as Africa and the southern part of the Mediterranean. We conceal a fact of present and future reality: from fertility rates to economic and social conditions, which will continue to keep migratory pressure high, in particular from sub-Saharan Africa to Europe, to our aging as Europe. This is why it is essential to have a global policy, a policy towards Africa, as you announced, and the effort we have been putting in place for a few months is very positive. A policy of stabilization of the Maghreb is fundamental, starting with Libya, and guaranteeing safe channels of access to Europe and finally, in this more global vision, we must know that in the coming years what is defined as the phenomenon of "migrants" will become increasingly evident. climatic conditions "and the need to introduce ... (The President cut off the speaker.)

name: Ангел Джамбазки (ECR).
text: - Mr President, today we are faced with the sad results of an unwise and erroneous policy. In the first place is the disintegration of nation-states in North Africa and the Middle East, in which European countries have taken part and turned these countries into territories ruled only by criminal gangs and jihadist gangs. Secondly, it was the wrong policy to tell every illegal immigrant from all over the world "You are welcome on the European continent". Third is the ongoing unreasonable policy of forcible resettlement of illegal immigrants in European Union countries. Let me remind you, colleagues, that there are countries in the European Union that do not have a colonial past, that there are countries that are not responsible for damage, genocide caused on the territory of other nations and on other continents, and it is absolutely unreasonable to force these nations , despite the will of their nation states to accept quotas from illegal immigrants. This must be a sovereign decision, a sovereign desire of each nation state. Fourth, a qualitatively new policy must be pursued, and this policy must make it clear to other peoples and continents: "There is no chance of mass illegal immigration."

name: Jeroen Lenaers (PPE).
text: - Two years ago we spoke on the same subject here in this room. It was after the crisis summer of 2015 and I remember the feeling of disappointment on the part of many members, including myself, at the lack of concrete action and results. Today I can only conclude that an awful lot has happened in the past two years: the strengthening of the controls at our external borders; establishing the Border and Coast Guard; the arrangements with third countries to prevent refugees and migrants from losing their lives on a dangerous journey at sea; and even the redistribution of asylum seekers, which had a slow start, but which has received a boost in recent months, so that it must really be possible to actually help all those people who qualify for it to find a place. I therefore hope that the recent judgment of the European Court of Justice can give an extra push in the right direction. However, we cannot sit back. The fact that fewer people arrive in Europe from Africa means at the same time that more people are left behind in dire circumstances in, among other things, Libya. Those people deserve our protection, deserve our help, and deserve our attention. In addition, in Europe we still fail to get economic migrants, who have no right to stay, quickly and efficiently back to their country of origin. That is why I am asking the Council and the Commission to please give it more priority, because one of the sentences in the progress report on Nigeria, for example, is that "things are difficult, because we cannot find a date for a second round of negotiations", that is not the level of ambition I expect.

name: Josef Weidenholzer (S&D).
text: - Madam President! Madam Vice-President, I would like the Heads of State and Government to have heard your opinion, because they actually outdo each other in their symbolic campaigning and often do little to resolve the situation. This discussion here stands out clearly. Whatever we are discussing here today: A big problem always remains, namely that hundreds of thousands of people are on the move, live under unimaginable conditions, become victims of criminal smugglers. I know the situation of these people from my own observations, I can't get these images out of my head, and I miss a policy that focuses on these people, is geared towards these needs. We urgently need sufficient financial resources, not just commitments. We urgently need money for the camps and not for mafia-like states and structures. We have to advocate that the children in the camps have access to education. Unfortunately, this is never the case and it often takes a long time. Above all, however, there needs to be structures of participation and participation, the rule of law. Only then will it be possible, together with those affected, to develop perspectives that reduce the influence of external control by criminal organizations. Yes, and we need humanitarian corridors, and that requires the participation of those affected.

name: Heinz K. Becker (PPE).
text: - Madam President! Yes, Madam Vice-President of the Commission, the EU must continue to massively develop its proactive role in dealing with migration. We have to stop illegal immigration because we have to create the space to create legal opportunities for actual refugees. To which they, as people who are really persecuted, have a right. That means that in addition to efficient and seamless external border protection - very importantly - we need proper reception centers in Africa, which represent the beginning of a saving path for refugees, but must be a terminal for all other people who want to immigrate. Above all, the priority is to combat the causes of flight in the countries of origin themselves. We have to help the people in regions with war, terror and persecution. That is why we must continue to bring military actions, joint EU actions of a military nature, into the picture on a massive scale. But it will not happen without a European Marshall Plan with Africa. And anyone who studies the Marshall Plan will know that this means, applied to the present day, that no euro is spent without European control and that this is the only way we can give people a perspective on life in the regions.

name: Ana Gomes (S&D).
text: - It is frustrating to continue to debate this issue as if it were naturally part of our crisis agenda. For us and for you too, Ms. Mogherini. On the one hand, we have a Council that revolves around the definition of the concept of solidarity, without ever debating the Dublin proposal for a regulation. So? In Parliament, we are ready to move forward and we will not fail to insist on eliminating the criterion of the first country of entry, on automatic relocation and on legal and safe routes, for migrants and refugees, in order not to continue to feed the business of drug traffickers. human beings. On the other hand, the Commission and the Council continue the wrong drift of replicating the EU-Turkey declaration with third countries, with other third countries, namely with a Libya where UNHCR has no formal and legal presence and which the European Union has left overturned in the current incapacity governance. Externalizing responsibilities and borders is a recipe for the European Union's discredit and for further insecurity inside and outside it. It is urgent to break this vicious circle, to tell the truth to our citizens. We need refugees and migrants to fight the demographic decline of our societies and we will not block their entry, if not through the door, through the window.

name: Alessandra Mussolini (PPE).
text: - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, the joint declaration represents a huge achievement for Italy's migration activity. Italy has changed the agenda, and we find ourselves at a crossroads: it has been understood that we must not only think about what is happening in Europe but go uphill, not just stop downstream. So we talk about the relations that must be had with Africa, relations with Libya and the certainly difficult and serious situation in that country. We are talking about epochal themes! Nobody has the word or the truth: perhaps there is not one single truth, there are many. I have heard here about what happens, perhaps, in Africa of violence, of trafficking. And what is happening in Europe? And the organized and unorganized crime that exploits and continues to exploit migrants arriving on the Italian coasts and on the coasts of other European countries? We can say that this turn made by Europe, thanks also to the contribution of Italy, also occurred because the relocation system failed dramatically. This must be said! Because Europe is not yet united! Therefore, the important thing at the moment is to ensure, as High Representative Mogherini said, that, alongside a situation of poverty and aid to African populations, channels are also created for legal migration. This is a very important aspect. It can be done.

name: Νίκος Ανδρουλάκης (S&D).
text: - Madam President, two years after the peak of the refugee crisis, we are looking for a comprehensive plan. Agreements like those with Turkey do not seem to work and are impossible to implement in countries like Libya. According to official figures, 5,800 refugees are trapped on the island of Mytilene alone. The court's recent decision to dismiss the appeal by Slovakia and Hungary is a message of solidarity. However, only 19,000 of the 63,000 refugees have been relocated from Greece to a Member State. At the same time, returns to Greece under the Dublin Regulation began, making the situation even more difficult. Mrs Mogherini, I would like to ask you: the informal agreement of the Greek Minister of Immigration with his German counterpart, which limits family reunification of refugees to 70 per month, increasing the suffering and agony of 2,700 refugees, is legal, as you recently answered me. but is it moral?

name: Емил Радев (PPE).
text: - Mr President, for four years now we have been trying to resolve the refugee crisis in Europe and reduce the overall immigration pressure. For the countries on the first line of migration flows, such as Italy, Greece, Bulgaria, the issue of finding an effective and fast solution with a long-term result is of particular importance. Unfortunately, however, there is still no position in either the European Parliament or the Council on the amendment of the Dublin Regulation and, in particular, on its basic principle of the Member State's first entry responsibility for the applicant for protection. The amendment of the current principle is of particular importance and will be a demonstration of genuine solidarity. The European Union does not yet have strategically important readmission agreements with the countries of origin of the thousands of economic migrants who continue to reach the shores of Italy. On the other hand, control over refugee flows is based on ad hoc solutions, such as cooperation with Turkey and Afghanistan. It is time for the European Union to implement the signing and implementation of readmission agreements with the main countries of origin and transit. It is time to speed up the return of illegal migrants and those who do not qualify for international protection. It is time for potential migrants who come to Europe illegally and only in search of a better life, and not because they have a real need for international protection, to understand that the European Union is not the solution to their problems. The European Union has sufficient financial and political resources to make these words a reality. It's time to do it! (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question) (Rule 162 (8)).

name: Cécile Kashetu Kyenge (S&D)
text: Question "blue card".- I heard my colleague who, quite rightly, spoke of the country of first landing: I would like to know from my colleague if he shares the idea of a centralized system in the change of the Dublin regulation.Hence, it would no longer be a question of welcoming people to the country of first landing, but rather moving to a system managed at EU level.I'd like to hear his opinion.

name: Емил Радев (PPE)
text: answer a question asked by picking up a blue card. - Mr President, in the current regulation, unfortunately, the burden on all those entering the European Union lies with the first Member States, and this exposes countries such as Greece, Bulgaria, Italy to very large migrant pressures and especially economic difficulties in meeting all these people and care. That is why there must be European solidarity so that the countries on the front lines can accept these people, from then on they can live where they choose, and there must be enough economic opportunities for their normal way of life.

name: Elly Schlein (S&D).
text: - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, tomorrow we will talk about the state of the Union. Let's ask the 14 000 people who are stranded on the Greek islands; let's ask those who are denied their legitimate right to seek asylum and are sent back to Libya in the hands of their torturers, fueling what MSF defines as a real business of kidnapping, extortion and torture. According to the recently released UNICEF / IOM report, 77% of minors who transited the Mediterranean have been victims of abuse. Try to call them economic migrants: because these are the people you are sending back to where those abuses suffer. The policies in the European Council are aimed at one goal: externalization. Since they are not able to share the responsibilities, well, then they move the borders further south. The Associated Press investigation spoke of agreements between the Libyan and Italian governments and militias. And so the funds to Libya risk ending up in the hands of those who manage the smuggling of migrants and prisons. These policies have also been harshly criticized by the United Nations High Commissioner for Human Rights and the Commission, instead of listening to Parliament and pushing for common solutions and internal solidarity, seems resigned to the egoism of governments and supports them just when the Court of justice gives her reason for relocations. Instead, a courageous reform of Dublin is needed: we need to cancel the hypocritical criterion of the first country of access, as Parliament has already requested, and replace it with a permanent and automatic relocation mechanism, which considers people, their rights and their links in the other states. And to undermine the traffickers, the only way is not to pay them but to open legal and safe ways of access to the Union and to all Member States.

name: Milan Zver (PPE).
text: - According to opinion polls, migration and terrorism have been the main concern of the European public for more than two years. As many as 68% of Europeans, as well as Slovenes, want a common migration policy. This climate needs to be translated into a citizens' demand placed on politicians and institutions to respond appropriately. Citizens do not want anyone else to invite migrants and refugees to Europe, they do not want the European institutions and the Member States to give up when it comes to protecting external borders. People do not want too slow reactions and firefighting, such as discussions about whether quotas should be permanent or temporary, mandatory or optional, and the like. When we talk only about it, it means that we react badly to the situation, and also all together. But people want a proactive policy, crisis prevention, they want governments to be more active, for example, in replenishing Frontex. People want order and respect for Union law, including the return of people who are not entitled to international protection. It is not fair for migrant workers to take the place of those refugees who need help. And last but not least, what does the European public expect from migration policy policies and institutions? She expects that she, not only migrants, will also be guaranteed fundamental rights, such as security and dignity. He expects everyone who comes to respect the values ​​and their way of life. At the same time, he expects that all newcomers who are not ready to integrate or even engage in crime will be given up hospitality ...

name: Kati Piri (S&D).
text: - Last week, news reached us that the Italian secret service has struck a deal with the Libyan smuggling mafia to stop migrants. Several colleagues have already referred to this in the debate. In exchange for a few million euros, work together with armed militias to stop vulnerable people from boarding boats to Europe. I am shocked by this news and also expect that it will soon be made public what exactly agreements have been made with whom. If the reports are accurate, we will have reached a new low point in how the EU is dealing with the challenges of migration. Such solutions are not sustainable. Making us dependent on militias that kill and rape and are also the cause of the great instability in Libya is a very short-sighted policy. However you turn it, the only way to better manage migration is to create legal routes for vulnerable refugees and to invest more in good governance and strong economies in Africa, so that the young have more options for success in life than just risk the crossing to Europe. But as long as you have nothing to lose, you even put your life in the hands of a smuggler. So no quick fake solutions, but really tackling the root causes and that takes a lot of patience. It is good that a number of European countries are openly talking about legal routes for the first time. But then also do this in collaboration with partners in Africa and thereby give African young people a voice in the decision-making process. After all, it is also about their future.

name: Patrizia Toia (S&D).
text: - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, with the initiatives of the Italian government, landings on the Mediterranean route have decreased: this is a novelty which, however, must not mislead us. Immigration remains the priority of the European Union because it is, as has been said, a structural element, I would say historical, in this great change of era that we are experiencing. I said "priority of Europe", and not of Italy or Greece, because I recognize that today there is more awareness and I thank Vice President Mogherini for her proposals, for her activity and for the strategy that she today outlined us. However, there are still countries, such as Hungary, which officially declare that they do not accept the judgments of the Court. I think these things cannot remain without consequences. Today we work, in addition to saving lives, to manage flows, to combat trafficking, to promote development in countries of origin and transit. Italy has done a lot on its own, on this level, of what the European Union should do. But now everyone must fully assume his responsibilities, and the first responsibility is now to face the tragedy of the people massed in Libya. I believe, Madam Vice President, like you, that criticisms and observations are good because they spur us on. But faced with these criticisms, some free, which I have heard from other banks, and a little instrumental, we must respond with our conviction and our goal: to save lives, yes always, but, above all, to prevent people from enter this hell and fall victim to traffickers.

name: Die Präsidentin. –
text: I now have six responses to the catch-the-eye procedure, and I will take them all.Catch-the-eye procedure

name: Michaela Šojdrová (PPE).
text: - Madam President, two years after the escalation of the migration crisis, the European Union has taken a number of measures.Measures are in place to restrict the uncontrolled access of refugees, such as the agreement with Turkey, negotiations with Libya and other African countries, and the coast and border guards.Mandatory quotas for relocation do not work and there is not a sufficient return policy, after all, this has already been said here.As the migration crisis eases, it seems to us, so it seems to me personally that security is no longer a priority, and I consider that to be a mistake.I do not want to wait for further terrorist attacks and waves of violence to realize once again that security must be part of the solution to migration.Solidarity without security is not sustainable, that is, let us be in solidarity, but let us put the security of the European Union first.

name: Juan Fernando López Aguilar (S&D).
text: - Madam president; Commissioner Mogherini, repeatedly, recurrently, we debate in this European Parliament the latest developments on migration. We run the risk with our expressions of sadness and frustration of “routinizing” the tragedy, because we will continue to debate them a thousand times, unless we change our perspective at least on two essential points. The first is to change the negative perspective on migration and, in particular, on refugees to, at once, impose a positive, European and solidarity perspective, ordering solidarity between the Member States and changing the Dublin Regulation. And the second, establishing at once - in the absence of legal channels, which condemns so many people to risk their lives, lose them or submit to slavery to illicit traffic - legal channels of access to the European Union for those who seek protection humanitarian in accordance with our own law and with international humanitarian law: humanitarian visas, humanitarian corridors; for that we have our full support, Commissioner Mogherini.

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (NI).
text: - Madam President, despite what the High Representative has nicely told us, one does not need to have much political experience to realize that immigration is the biggest failure of the European Union's foreign policy. A failure, the consequences of which we and our children are suffering today and will suffer, who knows for how many years, how many generations of Europeans. A failure that has flooded Europe and especially the countries of entry with millions of illegal immigrants, jihadist terrorists who kill, rape, terrorize and threaten the existence of Europe. A failure that ultimately divided Europe. And what are the latest developments? Italy has been transformed into an international travel agency that transports illegal immigrants, mainly from Libya, inland, and Greece a vast camp of unhappy people, who are tormenting the local population and have no future to hope for. Let the High Representative take credit for this.

name: Caterina Chinnici (S&D).
text: - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, Madam High Representative, finally, you said, and for the first time, I would add, since the beginning of the migration crisis, a path of exit from the now structural emergency linked to the landings of applicants seems to be taking shapeasylum and migrants on European territory.However, much remains to be done.For example, further action by the European Union is needed to stabilize the situation in Libya but, above all, it is necessary to ensure that the human rights of migrants stranded in the North African state are respected, paying specific attention to the most vulnerable subjects, such as unaccompanied minors, and ensuringsufficient resources to finance the voluntary returns of third-country nationals stranded in Libya.But it is also necessary to activate even more effective measures and interventions to counter all those illicit trafficking connected to the migration crisis.

name: Krisztina Morvai (NI).
text: – Madam President, I have a question for Ms Mogherini. Is Hungary—bashing the one migration policy of the European Union or does it have anything else in mind? Is there any other strategy? Make no mistake, we the Hungarian people, are united in protecting our country from mass migration. We shall not give up, so you had better find something else. I would be most interested to find out what that is, because it is a fact that millions of people from faraway places have come to Europe at the invitation of Mrs Merkel and at the invitation of the European Union. This is a disaster. It has to be solved somehow. It is not the responsibility of my country, Hungary. We are not the ones who are going to solve it. We are going to continue protecting our country and protecting the Schengen borders of Europe in accordance with our obligations. I look forward to your answer.

name: Κωνσταντίνος Παπαδάκης (NI).
text: Madam President, thousands of refugees and migrants remain in the Greek islands, doubly trapped in miserable conditions as a result of the EU-Turkey agreement that is part of intensifying imperialist rivalries, while the European Union, under the guise of a refugee, promotes businesses and troops in Africa. and the Middle East for the interests of capital. In the Greek islands, although some NGO contracts have not been renewed, at least in the field of healthcare, but under the responsibility of the government and the European Union, timeless nudity and huge shortages of state hospitals and infrastructure pose an immediate threat to the health of refugees and migrants. of the local population. The informal agreement between Germany and Greece for a maximum family reunification of 70 people per month and 2,700 families will live for years the torment of the drop is an untold tragedy and barbarism. Immediately ensure the rights and movement of all refugees in the countries of destination, the peoples to clash with the reactionary policy of the European Union and governments, to condemn capitalism that brings poverty, misery, war, refuge.

name: Federica Mogherini
text: Vice-President of the Commission / High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy. - (IT) Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, it was, as is often the case on the subject of immigration, a debate which partly involved unfounded arguments. It would be good to see in the house of European democracy a more careful use of the information that, I am sure, Members of this Parliament have about what is real and what is not. We do a lot of work against fake news, while perhaps sometimes a little intellectual honesty between us would be enough or simply to get better information. However, I also believe that a large part of you have recognized that finally, and for the first time, a new path has been undertaken, still very difficult, still very fragile, which needs to be consolidated, but which is beginning to bear fruit in terms of protection. of people, saving lives, cooperation in terms of equal partnership with our African partners, with international organizations, dismantling criminal networks along the entire trafficking path, border protection and control, but also and above all, I would like to say, of work on the causes that determine the movement of tens of millions of people in the world, which do not concern only Europe, they concern a phenomenon that many of you have rightly defined epochal, historical and that will not disappear. It's not about stopping the flows, it's about managing the flows. I believe that the Hon. in 't Veld used the right word: "manage". It is about managing, and we can do, a complex phenomenon. We can do this if we start from the consideration of the fact that there is not a single measure that solves the problem within 24 hours but it is a matter of putting in place a series of measures on all fronts - the external one, the internal one, the economic, security, social, rights, governance, that climate, and I could continue - a series of measures that over time build answers and solutions, provided that we clarify one thing between ourselves: that we act as Europeans, with unity and internal coherence, which I hope will reflect unity and the consistency that we are managing to implement in our external action on the management of migratory flows. I am, personally, extremely satisfied with the degree of unity and coherence that the European institutions, the Member States, and I would like to say also the national governments and parliaments, the local authorities - some projects we are doing as Europeans have been mentioned here. shown on the external side of the management of migratory flows: the partnership with Africa, the tiring and difficult work with Libya, the work with international organizations, such as UNHCR and IOM, and so on. We have an internal coherence problem and I believe it is right not to deny it to us. I believe that this Parliament, in addition to being a European Parliament, is also made up of women and men who have political roles, within political parties, in the Member States. Then perhaps we also need a reflection on how to ensure the political coherence of the Union's work. Because it is true that there is still a lot of work to be done on coherence, solidarity and not closing our eyes to the fact that this is a phenomenon that will remain with us, as Europeans, for a long time. To close oneself in the illusion that we can raise a wall and only postpone the solution of the problem will remain outside. What we can do, instead, is to act together, sharing responsibility, which also means sharing hospitality, and as Europeans we can manage it: we are the richest continent in the world, we are the continent that guarantees rights more than anywhere else of the world, we are the continent to which it is recognized today, as opposed to a few years ago, a possibility and a capacity for leadership on the way it is It is possible to build partnerships to manage a complex problem together. I believe that if we recognize this need, if we recognize the reality of the facts, we give ourselves more tools to respond to the problems of our citizens as well. Denying them is usually not a good starting point for trying to fix them. I would like to conclude by quoting the words of Pope Francis. Gianni Pittella remembered him: I think he used very important words. I am always struck by his ability to keep his heart together, but also his rationality, common sense, the ability to call each of us to reasonableness as people, as citizens, as part of a community. And Pope Francis, in thanking also and above all Italy and Greece, which are the Member States of the European Union who have undertaken an enormous job, initially in solitude, and which I believe today deserve the recognition of a weight that have brought in the name and on behalf of the whole of Europe, and to whom we must offer support and solidarity and whose proposals we must listen to, because they know the phenomenon more than many, who perhaps refuse to put into practice European proposals or measures, and then when asked: "But exactly, how many irregular migrants from the Ivory Coast are there in your country?" it turns out there is one, maybe two. So let's also listen to the proposals that come from countries that are at the forefront, because they are the ones who know the reality of the phenomenon and how it can be managed together in a sustainable way. Here, together with the word "management" I believe that there is the word "sustainability". I said that Pope Francis thanked Italy and Greece - and I believe that we as Europeans have a duty to do so - because they have kept our hearts open and I believe that this is an appeal to each of us as servants of the institutions: I don't think is do-gooders; I believe that if politics and institutions lose the sense of their humanity, they are unlikely to be able to serve their own citizens. There is a human element that guides political action, otherwise politics loses its meaning, and I believe that this is the common basis of our working together; as Europeans we certainly have our common root in humanism. But the Pope has indicated a sort of action plan, which I think very beautifully reflects a large part of the things that we have tried, we have begun to implement in recent months and years. First: welcome and integration. This concerns the internal policies of the Union and not only the Union, because it is not only the European Union that has to manage this phenomenon: let us think of the United States, which has chosen another path at the moment; let's think of Canada; let us think of some countries in Latin America or Asia, which are facing similar phenomena with different policies and with different responses. First, I said, welcome and integration, which are linked to each other and I believe that, with great realism, Pope Francis recognizes that the only limit of hospitality is the capacity of each country to integrate and give a future. Second: work to improve living conditions in the fields in Libya and the Sahel. Here I would like to be very clear: this is exactly what the European Union, together with the United Nations agencies, is trying to do. Are we succeeding? Very partially. Too little. But we are starting to have results. Someone earlier said that UNHCR and IOM are not present in Libya. This is not true: they are present in Libya, thanks to funding from the European Union and a work being done, with the Libyan authorities, to give UNHCR and IOM access to the camps, check health conditions, offer protection , distribute food and water: this is a minimum, a minimum of first response. It's enough? No. Is that what we want? No. But we are the only ones, the only ones, who are asking themselves the problem of how to help the migrants they are in right now they are trapped in Libya in the hands of traffickers. And I can tell you that our African partners, whose nationalities are present in these camps in Libya, are thanking us. And these are people who in some cases we are helping to return voluntarily, with assisted returns, to their countries of origin. Because it's also about saving lives. So, I go back to asking: is our action enough? No, but I believe that a responsible European Union is a European Union that sees the problem, confronts it and tries to solve it, even when the solution is not one hundred percent satisfactory. We could improve, of course, but at least we are taking on a problem. And it's not that a year ago, two years ago or seven years ago this problem didn't exist: those who are Italian know it very well. The stories heard in Lampedusa five years ago were the same. Third: work for the growth of the African continent: economic growth, social growth, democratic growth. And I believe that this is truly the great turning point of our joint action. Partnership with Africa: not only and not so much with governments, but with the people; the growth of potential, the young people of Africa, the women of Africa, a partnership that looks not only at economic investments, including private ones, but also at participation, democracy, respect for human rights. I therefore believe that our task is to continue doing what we have finally - too late perhaps, but for the first time - undertaken: to increase the level of coherence and common responsibility within our Union; to show pride in what we have finally managed to put in place, including saving lives, but also to be very clear on how to be European, because there cannot be part-time Europeanism; one cannot think of being European on some policies and national on others. The European Union has many things to improve, to change - President Juncker will say many tomorrow - but I believe that we need this basic element of common solidarity.A family helps itself when one of the members is most in difficulty;on another case, on another theme, on another policy, solidarity can be reversed.This is the meaning of being together.I believe that this is also the basis for giving an effective and effective response also to internal management with regard to reception and integration.As you know, the Commission is also working on the Dublin regulation plan: Commissioner Avramopoulos has spoken to you about it many times and it is not from these banks that the problem can be solved.

name: Die Präsidentin. –
text: The debate is closed.Written statements (Rule 162)

name: Kinga Gál (PPE)
text: in writing. - In his introductory remarks, Frederica Mogherini, High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy, reported that the number of returns of illegal migrants had increased, that they were stepping up their efforts to curb human traffickers and assisting the Libyan coastguard. I all agree with these measures, but at the same time they are incapable of solving the current migration crisis on their own. There can be only one solution, and that is to separate economic migrants from real refugees before they enter Europe. This approach has been outlined by the Hungarian Prime Minister in his ten-point Schengen 2.0 action plan for more than a year and a half. It must be made crystal clear that only real refugees and only legally can enter the territory of the European Union. At the same time, the EU must finally acknowledge that no mandatory quota distribution program is suitable for tackling the migration crisis, as it is interpreted by illegal migrants as an invitation and an encouragement to human traffickers. Even the Member States that support and accept the migrant quota have not relocated the migrants imposed on them, so it may be that only 25% of the target was relocated a few days before the decision expired on 26 September. This again highlights the fact that the migrant quota approach is completely unsuitable for tackling the problem. It is not the trouble that needs to be brought here, but the help that needs to be brought there.

name: Илхан Кючюк (ALDE)
text: In written form. - The signed agreement with the Republic of Turkey and the measures to stop the Balkan route have given visible results in recent months. Unfortunately, this is not enough and the intense flow of arrivals on the shores of Italy during the summer is a clear signal that we still need to work to tackle the migration crisis. Once again, we must point to the instability and ongoing military conflicts in the countries of North Africa and the Middle East as the main causes. The complexity and scale of the crisis require a joint and coordinated effort by all Member States and pan-European solidarity. In fact, it is precisely the ineffective individual actions of the Member States on migration that make EU citizens feel incapable of coping with the crisis, and this generates xenophobia and intolerance. In this context, I admire the ruling of the European Court of Justice in recent days on the solidarity distribution of migrants and call on all Member States to work together and speed up progress in implementing common European policies. The management of illegal migration flows is about protecting the external borders and helping Member States that are under pressure. Now is the time to show that we can work together!

name: Die Präsidentin.
text: - The next item on the agenda is the debate on the statement by the Vice-President of the Commission and High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy on EU-Turkey relations (2017/2840 (RSP)).

name: Johannes Hahn
text: on behalf of the Vice-President of the Commission/High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy. – Madam President, Turkish society is going through difficult years, and so is our relationship with the country’s authorities. On many crucial issues we disagree with our Turkish interlocutors, from freedom of speech to the rule of law. Academics, journalists, civil society and critical voices have come under increasing pressure. The detention in July of another 10 human rights defenders, including EU nationals, was the latest in a long series of extremely worrying episodes. We cannot, we do not, and we will continue not to ignore these current negative developments. In our dialogue we insist that Turkey respect the highest democratic standards it has committed to as a candidate country to the European Union and as a member of the Council of Europe. This was the spirit of the meeting between Presidents Tusk, Juncker and Erdoğan on 25 May, and this is the spirit of the High Representative’s regular meetings with her counterpart, Foreign Minister Mevlüt Çavuşoğlu. The same applies to my encounters with the same Minister Çavuşoğlu, but also Minister Çelik, the European Minister of Turkey, and other members of the Government. Turkey is also our neighbour and a key player in a strategic region for the European Union. We are partners – difficult partners sometimes – but we work together on many different files that are fundamental both for the European Union and for Turkey, from counter-terrorism to migration to Syria, to name but a few. Our dialogue with Turkey on all these files is essential for all European citizens, for all Turkish citizens and for our entire region. Our dialogue is open, frank, critical, sometimes constructive, sometimes very difficult. Most recently at our high-level political dialogue on 25 July in Brussels, the High Representative and I made it clear to our Turkish counterparts that there is an urgent need for the current trend to be reversed if we want our reciprocal engagement to be sustainable. This goes for the domestic situation, with continued dismissals, suspensions and arrests, but equally so for bilateral relations between Turkey and some EU Member States. A month ago we agreed with our Turkish counterparts that we should all talk less about each other, and more to each other. Everyone could benefit from a more constructive attitude. At the same time, we must not lose sight of the long-term and, perhaps even more importantly, of the many people in Turkey who are also concerned, as we are, with the current trends. Let me end by noting that in our dialogue with Turkish opposition members, human rights defenders and journalists, the majority of them urge us to continue our dialogue with Turkey. Let us keep this in mind as we reflect on the next steps in our relationship. Meine Damen und Herren!
