Ich möchte aber auch die Gelegenheit nutzen, Frau Präsidentin – nachdem ich verstanden habe, dass Sie während der Debatte abgewechselt werden –, Ihnen alles Gute zu wünschen für Ihre neuen Herausforderungen und mich ganz persönlich für die gute Zusammenarbeit in den letzten Jahren bedanken. Vielen herzlichen Dank.

name: Die Präsidentin. –
text: Thank you very much, Commissioner!Hopefully we will also have the opportunity to work together in another form in the future.And I'll be a MEP until around the end of October.So maybe we'll see each other a few more times.

name: Cristian Dan Preda
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. - Madam President, here we are, therefore, for the third time in less than a year, discussing our relationship with Turkey and for the third time, most of us agree that in view of the political developments in Turkey , negotiations on the accession of this country to the Union should be temporarily suspended. When I say "political developments", I am referring, of course, to the constitutional referendum and above all to the numerous attacks on human rights and fundamental freedoms which have affected important categories of the population, ranging from journalists to the military, in particular. passing of course through school or university teachers. The Copenhagen criteria are clear and we must respect them. However, if at Parliament level the position is fixed, we are waiting for the Council to do the same. We can no longer afford to discuss Turkey and our present relationship with this country through several voices that are contradictory. In order to be credible, we must coordinate and not leave it to Ankara to do what suits him. I think the time has come to decide on a route to take and that we take responsibility for that choice. This is all the more important as Turkey is now a very important partner for the Union and all its Member States, and this applies to a multitude of areas. Migration and trade are just two visible aspects of this partnership. Therefore, it is necessary to know where this relationship is going and on what coordinates it will evolve in the short and medium term. In other words, if we take the prospect of membership off the negotiating table, what else do we put on? How do we see the future of the relationship between Brussels and Ankara? I think this question should not be taken lightly, because it is essential for the continuity of this relationship, but also for the image and credibility of the European Union in Turkey.If we are reacting to the Turkey of today, we must act with the Turkey of tomorrow in mind.This is also why, as rapporteur for the opinion of the AFET committee on the 2018 budget, I supported the redistribution of part of the funding planned for Turkey to Turkish civil society, which defends thefreedom of expression.

name: Kati Piri
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. – Madam President, as EU—Turkey relations have been put on the agenda of the next European Council meeting, I believe it is good to reiterate this Parliament’s position. This House has been speaking out loudly and clearly when it comes to the serious violations of fundamental rights in Turkey. Despite our many political differences and our diverging views on EU—Turkey relations, we have been united in our condemnation of rights abuses. In July – two months ago – we called for the formal suspension of the accession talks if the constitutional amendments were implemented unchanged. The situation in Turkey continues to be worrying, but there have been no developments in the last two months that would cause us to change the position we took two months ago. We also expect EU leaders to come forward with a clear and united response in October. The EU’s credibility is at stake when it comes to the accession talks with Turkey. At the same time, it is important to keep making a distinction between the Turkish Government and the Turkish population. In this respect, let me clearly state that the European Parliament never called for the withdrawal of the candidate status of Turkey nor for the shutting of all doors of communication. Taking away the European perspective from the Turkish people once and for all would be a grave mistake. However, the real question at hand is not whether Turkey can or cannot one day become a member of a future European Union. This is a theoretical debate. The real question at stake is: what we can do to reverse the current authoritarian trend in Turkey and how can we continue to support the millions of people in Turkey who believe in the same values? This is why I believe that starting negotiations on an upgraded customs union would be a first important step, although of course things need to improve first. Another important tool for the EU would be to continue financial support for civil society in Turkey. We must ensure that populism and xenophobia do not take over this debate. The Turkish people deserve our solidarity in difficult times. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Λευτέρης Χριστοφόρου (PPE)
text: blue card question. - Madam President, with full respect for what has been said about Turkey, I must say that the European Parliament must finally send another clear message. Turkey cannot, in a provocative and unacceptable way, hold a member state of the European Union and go to the talks for a solution to the Cyprus problem and demand that troops and guarantees remain in a member state of the European Union. For the past forty-three years, Turkey has not been able to occupy Cyprus, which is a full member of the European Union, and continues not to recognize the Republic of Cyprus. Turkey can not, and this must be linked to the negotiations, continue to provoke and insult ... (The President cut off the speaker)

name: Kati Piri (S&D)
text: blue-card answer. – In many ways I think the situation in Cyprus has already been very visible in EU—Turkey relations and in the accession talks as well. I personally very much regret that the talks collapsed before the summer, and I know that another political Group – not my Group – has also made a request to make sure that we also debate what happened in those talks and what would be a way forward. I believe that a united Cyprus living in peace would actually not only be best for the people living on the islands but for stability in the whole region and, of course, also for EU—Turkey relations.

name: Charles Tannock
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Madam President, EU-Turkey relations have become an all-too-familiar hotly-debated topic in this House. Just as Turkey drifts even further from western democratic norms on the domestic scene, its foreign policy decisions become ever more contrary to those of the European Union and NATO allies. Most recently we saw a USD 2.5 billion contract to purchase the Russian S400 anti-aircraft weapon system. This decision shows not only a disregard for the current strained relations between Russia and the West but also raises questions about its continued policy in Syria that diverges from that of the European Union and NATO: particularly now also Turkey’s offensive against the PYD fighters, against ISIS in Syria – another example – also its bullying of Cyprus in its attempts to rightfully explore for oil in its territorial waters. The situation inside Turkey, meanwhile, continues to reel from last year’s coup attempt. Despite already purging over 100 000 individuals from the civil service and the judiciary as well as arresting a further 50 000 people, it seems that the process continues unabated. Recent figures of 601 individuals arrested; 450 of them were accused of having Gulenist sympathies. Amid such developments, it is no wonder that Chancellor Merkel has called for the scrapping of EU accession talks for Turkey. I personally have long questioned the merits of Turkey’s accession to the European Union, and it seems now that such questions are coming to a head.

name: Alexander Graf Lambsdorff
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. - Madam President! Turkey and the European Union signed their association agreement in 1963. In 1999 Turkey got candidate status. Negotiations have been going on since 2005, and even in better times they haven't really gotten closer. It shows that both sides are not interested in joining in such a way that it could lead to anything. The people in Europe - 77% of Europeans - reject Turkey's accession and support the end of the negotiations. In Germany - in my country - it is 86%. Turkey has not met the Copenhagen criteria for a long time, and if we turn away from surveys and look at the legal situation, Article 5 of the negotiating framework comes into play. If there is a long and serious breach of the principles of freedom, democracy, respect for human rights, fundamental freedoms and the rule of law, it is up to the Commission to recommend that the negotiations be suspended. I can't understand why she doesn't. This House has done that several times - it is high time the Commission took this step too. We need this courage to think again. Dear Cristian Preda of the EPP: The question is, what will take the place of an accession process that is obviously dead? Then serious talks with Turkey about how to shape our relations will finally take place here. Discussions about a basic treaty, about energy policy, about the common organization of security in the eastern Mediterranean area, about the management of migration policy. We will then finally be able to make progress in fields where there has hardly been any before: culture, science - we can do so much together. The prerequisite is, of course, that the wrongly prisoners are released. You can't talk about anything else beforehand. I've been five now Years of the rapporteur of my group for Turkey, and from a liberal point of view I would like to say one thing in my last speech here on this subject that I find the relations and the developments in Turkey extremely deplorable. From the perspective of a liberal, freedom rights, minority rights, but also the development of the economy are important. When I look at how the trade unions keep trying to enforce their freedom of assembly in Taksim Square, how the Gesi Square protests were put down, what the Kurds are like, how freedom of the press is treated - the country is in 154th place worldwide, behind Iraq - the referendum which, according to the Venice Commission, will lead to the abolition of the separation of powers - all of this is really worrying. The customs union talks will also not be able to continue if the political situation does not develop. We say yes to the dialogue, Turkey remains an important neighbor - but it is high time to put this dialogue on a new basis.

name: Die Präsidentin. –
text: Dear colleague, Vice President Lambsdorff!Because it now appears to be your last speech, although you will still be here next time, I've let you talk a little longer.And I have to say to Mr Mavrides: Mr Mavrides, you are also on the list as a speaker.That means, I don't give a blue card to someone who will speak on the same topic or who has already spoken.I ask for your understanding, we are already behind schedule.Thank you.

name: Marie-Christine Vergiat
text: on behalf of the GUE / NGL Group. - Madam President, the Turkish question seems to embrace the German electoral campaign. Merkel even settled the membership debate. She never believed it - sic - and would even be prepared to break off talks on the customs union. Relations between Berlin and Ankara are souring, almost making us forget that Merkel was the main architect of the agreement, the declaration, sorry, the EU-Turkey. The situation in Turkey deserves better. Botched trials are on the increase, as evidenced in recent days by the resumption of trials of journalists from Cumhuriyet. Turkey is more than ever the world's biggest prison for journalists. French, I am thinking of Loup Bureau, imprisoned for a report on Turkish fighters in Syria, but also of all the imprisoned Kurds, and in particular our parliamentary colleagues, among whom Selahattin Demirtas and Figen Yüksekdag, co-chairs of the HDP, imprisoned for more than ten months, as well as to all the progressives who languish by the thousands in Turkish prisons and who are all accused of terrorism. In this context, to which must indeed be added the non-settlement of the Cyprus issue, any negotiation, with or without a human rights clause, seems incongruous. Only the rule of law should motivate decisions and not an Islamophobia that does not speak its name. Only the interests of the people should be of concern to us, not commercial interests. Unfortunately, we are quite far from it. It is not about being pro or anti-Turkish, but about treating Turkey like any country in our neighborhood.

name: Ska Keller
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Mr President, as colleagues have mentioned, Turkish President Erdoğan continues his relentless course against democracy and human rights, and he has put thousands of people into jail – journalists, teachers, politicians, and also, more and more EU citizens – and this is unacceptable. There can be no doubt that Erdoğan’s course requires a very strong and clear European response. I think we all agree on that, but the question is: what response? Because I think we need to find a response that is not just there for us to feel good but a response that actually achieves what we want to get to, and for that we need to indeed remember that Erdoğan is not Turkey and Turkey is not Erdoğan. 50% of people in Turkey voted against Erdoğan’s referendum, and people in Turkey are currently, every day, risking their freedom and their employment by speaking up, by defending their rights, by defending the rights of others. We must not forget those people and we must not leave them alone. We must do everything, rather, that we can to support them, and by everything I mean both on the institutional level but also with everything that we as MEPs and we as Groups can do. We have also one instrument in our hands that I believe will be very powerful in actually targeting Erdoğan without harming the opposition, and that is indeed the customs Union. I think it would be a scandal if we were to deepen our business ties with Turkey while journalists and labour unionists are in jail. And the customs union is actually not an instrument for political dialogue; it is an instrument for exchanging goods, for exchanging services. And that is also why Erdoğan wants it. He has never threatened to stop that one, and I think that is why we also need to especially use it. We need to say, no, we won’t do the modernisation and enlargement of the customs union unless there is progress on human rights. No business interests can really be more important than the interest of people to live in freedom and in the enjoyment of their rights, and the same is true – has to be true – for the export of weapons. There are still weapons exports happening today from European Union Member States to Turkey. But Turkey is a country in conflict: not a single weapon should be sent there, and certainly also not whole weapons factories. How to deal with Turkey? It is certainly not a good topic for an election campaign, nor for a competition about who hits the hardest. This is about the future of more than 70 million people and about the future of us. There will be a time after Erdoğan. Let’s not forget that.

name: Edouard Ferrand
text: on behalf of the ENF group. - Mr. President, a century ago, we spoke of Turkey, as being the great sick man of Europe. Today I think the real sick man in Europe is the European Union. You have entered into negotiations that do not rhyme with anything, you have made mistakes in your relations with Turkey, the relation which you have entered into with Turkey is only a transactional one. You have exchanged migrants for membership in the European Union. But the European peoples do not want your disastrous project and I believe that today you have completely taken the wrong path. It was necessary to offer a great partnership, a privileged partnership. Turkey, this great country, this great people, deserved something other than your proposals. I believe that you have made proposals which do not go in the direction of accession today, you have led Turkey to negotiations which will lead to nothing, you have wasted your time, and you have wasted a lot time to Turkey, the European Union and us MEPs.

name: David McAllister (PPE).
text: - Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, dear colleagues! Numerous previous speakers have already pointed out that and how Turkey has moved away from our European values ​​for several years. I also very much regret that. However, the latest developments in Turkey are once again a major cause for concern. I want to point out, among other things, that German citizens have also been arrested for no reason. These developments cannot go uncommented. And that is why I think it is right that Chancellor Angela Merkel has spoken out in favor of placing the subject of relations between the European Union and Turkey on the agenda of the next European Council in October, and then also with the European partners there Discuss the procedure in peace. As the European Parliament, we already voted with a large majority last year to suspend EU accession negotiations with Turkey. In view of the negative developments in this country, it makes no sense to continue the accession negotiations now - that was our message. But of course we know that ultimately it is up to the Member States to decide how to proceed. I would like to take up a point that has already been discussed. I have a different point of view than some of the previous speakers. Under these current conditions, from my point of view, there is no question of deepening trade relations. That is why, in my opinion, under these circumstances the Council should not give the Commission a mandate to negotiate with Turkey on an expansion of the customs union. Yes, close and special cooperation between the EU and Turkey, which serves the people on both sides, especially those who are also against the Erdoğan system. But given the recent developments in Turkey towards autocracy it cannot become a member of the European Union.EU membership is not the right path for Ankara, and there is currently no need for debates about a future closer customs union.

name: Victor Boştinaru (S&D).
text: - Mr President, Commissioner, we have a political system in Turkey today that considers differences of opinion and criticism to be an absolute evil. More than 160 Turkish journalists and European citizens have been arrested. Thousands of university professors, members of the academy, are in prison, some of them without even knowing their accusations and without having a trial. Of course, the European Parliament cannot accept this situation. But President Erdogan's rhetoric towards some Member States is largely for domestic consumption. Therefore, it is better to refrain from playing by the rules defined by Erdogan. Consequently, I fear that the prospect of a rupture in the dialogue with Turkey may give it new arguments to strengthen the authoritarian state it started even before the failed coup. Dear colleagues, I believe that we must avoid hasty, emotional or electoral decisions. I invite you to reflect and maintain a balanced and responsible position on the future of strategic relations between the European Union and Turkey. In this regard, I welcome the position taken by most foreign ministers at the last CAGRE meeting, which took place in Tallinn last week. Let's not forget, dear friends: Turkey has been and remains a strategic partner of the EU and the Member States, now and in the future. Turkey is a large and important country, with a very active, complex and largely pro-European civil society. The enlargement process has allowed us to positively influence the process of this country over several decades. It would be a tragic, fatal strategic mistake to suspend the bridges now.

name: President. –
text: You have already spoken under a blue card in this debate, so I am going to move to the next speaker. Apologies for that.

name: Ελένη Θεοχάρους (ECR).
text: - Mr President, Commissioner, accession procedures, pre-accession funding and the deepening of the customs union are interrelated issues. Erdogan does not care about the interruption of the accession process, but he is burning for the suspension of the customs union. On the other hand, the European Union upgraded the Customs Union without Turkey fulfilling its obligations to the Republic of Cyprus as it should. I have warned you, Commissioner, many times of the consequences. The Cypriot Government, which did not react, is also responsible, as is the European Union, which often puts economic interests above principles and values. With the Customs Union, Erdogan is not obliged to democratize his country, while at the same time expanding his trade with the European Union. That is why it continues its ruthless occupation of Cyprus, that is why it is gradually imposing its conditions on the settlement of the Cyprus problem and that is why the solution will be rejected by the Cypriot people because it will be unjust, racist, heterogeneous and inhuman while it will be a time bomb. in the foundations of the Union. (The President cut off the speaker)

name: Marietje Schaake (ALDE).
text: – Mr President, today’s debates and the points raised are roughly the same that we have had for years. Again, we talk about the lack of separation of powers, the lack of respect for the rule of law, the absence of due process and fair trial, the numerous breaches of people’s rights and fundamental freedoms, the opposition, the press, civil society and minorities. Add to that a constitutional package that will lead to increased concentration of powers, more recent attacks, including of European citizens, tensions in the NATO alliance, ongoing announcements of the reintroduction of the death penalty and the kinds of insults that partners do not exchange. So the question is not what is going on – it is crystal clear – but the question: is what is the EU’s answer? I think it is a good thing that this Parliament has been leading and has been consistent. We want to have an honest debate and an EU that acts on the basis of principles. We encourage the Council and the Commission to do the same next month – make an announcement and be clear – because, as it stands, we are basing our relation on the deal on migration, which we think has failed and is not even delivering. Because the re—energising of accession is going nowhere. There is no perspective on visa liberalisation, and the support for these kinds of deals is eroding further and further. So it is clear that we cannot continue like this. But we must make sure that any future arrangement is based on values.

name: Νεοκλής Συλικιώτης (GUE/NGL).
text: - Mr President, Turkey continues to violate the human rights and fundamental freedoms of its people, to persecute the Kurds, and to silence journalists. It also continues to illegally and by force of arms, a Member State of the European Union, Cyprus. It is unacceptable to ask for an upgrade of the Customs Union when Turkey has not yet implemented the obligations arising from the current Union agreement as a whole, refusing to recognize the Republic of Cyprus. We call on the Union to put pressure on Turkey to fulfill all its contractual obligations, to end the violation of human rights in the country, to return to the negotiating table for the solution of the Kurdish issue and to contribute constructively to the settlement of the Cyprus problem. The only lever of pressure from the European Union for Turkey to implement the above is the freezing of the accession negotiations until Turkey complies. This is the position that we overwhelmingly endorsed as the European Parliament in the resolution of the last plenary of July.

name: Bodil Valero (Verts/ALE).
text: - Mr President! I wonder if President Erdoğan thinks that his relations with the EU countries will be improved by constantly provoking and challenging us, or if it is part of a strategy to get us to close the door completely, so that he can blame the failure at home EU instead of on its own policies. I can not forget the quote where he likened democracy to a tram that you use until you no longer need it. Is it possible that Erdoğan has reached the final destination? What worries me today in our relations with Turkey is the unwarranted use of Interpol to silence regime critics abroad. It can hardly be the case that we suddenly have 60,000 criminal Turks who need to be wanted by Interpol. Of course, there may be 60,000 or more Turks who do not agree with the president's policy and who express it freely, but that is a crucial part of freedom of expression and opinion. In Sweden, a Swedish journalist with a Turkish background is now in prison awaiting deportation. His name is Hamza Yalcin, and he has lived in Sweden for 30 years. Information on when a possible extradition will take place varies, but it is worrying whether we give such a signal to the Turkish and Kurdish diaspora. (The President cut off the speaker)

name: Gilles Lebreton (ENF).
text: - Mr President, Turkey is our neighbor. We must therefore dialogue with it, as Commissioner Hahn has just underlined. We must have a dialogue on all subjects, and in particular in matters of migration policy, but we must be firm and not angelic, as Mogherini has just been a moment ago, echoing the Pope's words. But the Pope is in his role and the leaders of the Union should be in theirs. Dialogue is not submission. Turkey - it should be remembered - constantly violates human rights and its attitude is quite different from the values ​​we defend in this hemicycle. On the other hand, Erdogan openly laughs at us. Should we recall that the occupation of Cyprus continues, even though it is a Member State of the Union, and should we also recall that Erdogan came to Strasbourg 2 years ago to criticize the European civilization? The conclusion is obvious, my dear colleagues: it is that of the National Front, it is the one that Mrs Merkel has just taken up. Turkey's accession negotiations to the Union must be halted as a matter of urgency.

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (NI).
text: - Mr President, some safe conclusions have been drawn from the long negotiations with Turkey so far: The first is that Turkey is only interested in serving its national interests without being inconsistent with its commitments. towards the European Union to become a member. Secondly, when the European Union points out all this, Turkey becomes angry and threatens and blackmails. Finally, the President of Turkey does not have the slightest hesitation to violate human rights, to persecute political opponents, to imprison publishers, journalists, politicians, the military and anyone who disagrees with their views. In view of the above, the most pragmatic approach to Turkey's problem is to make it clear to the European Union that it does not intend to accept it as a member. If this is done, Turkey will change its behavior and find that it has no room to behave in a way that is unacceptable and hinders the European Union's foreign policy. A special relationship between the European Union and Turkey must be established.

name: Renate Sommer (PPE).
text: - Mister President! Mrs Mogherini said earlier that the European Parliament should be more honest with information. But what about the Commission itself and the Council? We know - it has been said many times, just now again - that the Turkish government has been breaking its European promise for years. And what are the Commission and the Council doing? Wait - it will get better. Core values ​​are trampled underfoot in Turkey. Europeans are arrested - for no reason. They are held in prison for months without consular assistance. That is something that we cannot accept at all, in addition to everything that we have already experienced with the Turkish government in recent years. I swear in your hand that if that happened to another country, the Commission and the Council would have reacted sharply long ago. But by doing nothing towards Turkey, the EU is making a fool of itself - by the way, just as Turkey made a fool of itself with its travel warning for Germany. I think it is time for a sharp reaction from the Council and the Commission. Yes, the accession has to be shelved, it will not take place anyway. What are the Commission and the Council afraid of? Everything else - including the expansion of the customs union - really depends on the behavior of Turkey itself, we have to make that clear to the outside world. At the moment we cannot expand the customs union. But we know, and we also have to make this clear to the Turkish people: Turkey needs us much more than we need Turkey, and with economic sanctions we might be able to bring Mr Erdoğan to his senses.

name: Knut Fleckenstein (S&D).
text: - Mr President, ladies and gentlemen! Commissioner, you gave us a landmark speech today. Turkey is a neighboring country, you are absolutely right. She's a partner, you're right too. We shouldn't talk so much about each other, but talk to each other - great observation. I absolutely agree with you. Because there are enough topics, NATO, culture, science, much more. But anyone who tramples on freedom of expression and the rule of law so clearly is dismissing us at the same time as this behavior, and he is telling us: We don't want to go to your club at all. We have to answer this de facto termination accordingly. And that is why this Parliament got it right when we said: We are suspending these negotiations, we will divert the money sensibly, away from the government and towards people - people to people contact. And, in my opinion, you from the Commission would have done well to have taken a clear position and not this lukewarm thing that comes our way. Especially you as an Austrian - you have a Foreign Minister who shows us how to stand smart and straight. I really would have expected more from you on this point. With the Council, I have no concerns that an opinion will be reached there. The Dutch Foreign Minister told us: We'd better keep talking after the elections because then you know what makes the Chancellor tick in Germany. At first she didn't want Turkey in, then she didn't want to break off the negotiations, and then she ran after Mr. Schulz. I am sure that after the elections there will be clarity. (The President cut off the speaker)

name: Ангел Джамбазки (ECR).
text: - Mr President, Turkey is not a European country, neither culturally, nor civilizationally, nor historically. In this sense, its full membership of the European Union is neither necessary nor possible. The government in Turkey continues to follow a dangerous, neo-Ottoman doctrine, continues to interfere in the internal affairs of sovereign neighboring countries, in the elections in Bulgaria, in Greece, in Germany, in the Netherlands. It continues to occupy Cyprus illegally. That is why we have been repeating for years, at least for three years, that these negotiations must be stopped. Finally, Chancellor Merkel, finally our former colleague Schultz, heard these calls and repeated them. I hope that these will not be just pre-election promises, but that they will be kept and fulfilled after the elections. Any concession to dictator Erdogan is unnecessary and unreasonable because it only strengthens it, because it gives him more opportunities to continue to crush civil society, to violate democratic rights and freedoms, and to continue to turn his country into a dictatorship. In this sense, I would like to ask when sanctions will be imposed on this authority in Turkey, which is violating everything that is being said in this Chamber.

name: Κώστας Χρυσόγονος (GUE/NGL).
text: - Mr President, no country is allowed to join the European Union if it does not respect the basic democratic principles. It is obvious to everyone in this Chamber that the Erdogan regime is increasingly moving away from these fundamental principles. Consequently, Turkey's accession becomes impossible and this was stated by the European Parliament in its decision requesting the suspension of the accession negotiations. This means that pre-accession financial assistance should be stopped immediately: 636 million euros for the year 2017 alone, go to the Erdogan regime to finance various actions such as attacks on Kurds, torture of political prisoners and more. This aid must stop, otherwise there is the Union's complicity in what Mr Erdogan and his henchmen are doing.

name: Janusz Korwin-Mikke (NI).
text: - Madam President!Turkey's main problem is called the Kurds, and we must remember that at the moment, a new Kurdistan is being formed at the borders of Turkey after Iraq.You have to admire the Turkish army that in this situation it stands with a weapon at its feet and is armed just in case.In this situation, the Kurds, a very sympathetic nation, have a choice: either if they are weak, President Assad will finish them, or if they are strong, they will declare independence, and then the Turkish army will come in and finish them.That is why I believe that the European Union should - as I proposed when the Kurds were here a year ago - insist that there is an agreement between the Kurds, that they get broad autonomy - as they have in Iraq - and thus end this fight in the northernSyria, which is very painful for everyone involved.Thank you for your attention.

name: Μιλτιάδης Κύρκος (S&D).
text: - Mr President, for so many years, important negotiating chapters have remained closed. In essence, we intervened only technocratically, in vain, uninspired in the accession process. Many hoped for Turkey's non-compliance and others fortified themselves behind Cyprus' substantive objections. But every year that Chapter 24 on Justice did not open, the current situation was getting closer. And as soon as Chapter 23 of Fundamental Rights did not open, it became easier for Erdogan to strengthen his sovereignty to the detriment of the Kemalist establishment, which, through its mistakes and arrogance, helped it to be seen as the reformer of a rotten regime. But even now, when many are calling for a rift with Turkey by playing hand-to-hand with Erdogan in the game of counterclaims, we can reverse this trend. Let us put the Republic, the rule of law, the customs union and the accession process, all together-package on the table, raising the cost of Erdogan's refusal to unimaginable heights. We owe a hand of solidarity and better living conditions to the Turkish people. Let us push for a way out because by leaving we leave Turkey alone in its unbelievable and dangerous impasses and we will all pay the heavy price together.

name: Arne Gericke (ECR).
text: - Mr President, Commissioner Hahn, ladies and gentlemen! At the beginning, may I ask you one thing - across all parliamentary groups: let's not be ridiculous! Let's not sell our European values ​​in Erdoğan's Turkish bazaar. Over 50 German citizens are now in custody in Turkey. Journalists are being held, including a young woman with a child. The despot from the Bosporus rears up when he is called that, but on the other hand never tires of insulting historically forgotten EU politicians as Nazis. It is enough! But we are still negotiating diligently on accession, paying pre-accession funds and economic aid, transferring six billion euros in tax money to Ankara as part of the more than dubious refugee deal, instead of simply ensuring the security of our external borders ourselves, as Hungary has shown us, as Macedonia has done managed on behalf of the EU. No more negotiations with Erdoğan, no money for Turkey and as an offer a new beginning without despots, towards a fair, privileged partnership!

name: Σοφία Σακοράφα (GUE/NGL).
text: - Mr President, Commissioner, you have confused us. Parliament has repeatedly issued resolutions condemning the situation in Turkey and even calling for the suspension of accession negotiations, while Mrs Merkel and her officials have said, for pre-election purposes, that Turkey will not join the European Union. , when they recently praised their cooperation with the Erdogan government. Mr Juncker said Turkey was jumping away from its European perspective and, at the same time, Ms Mogherini called Turkey a strategic partner and called for closer co-operation in key areas. Can you finally tell us whose position you are expressing? You understand, of course, that this timeless but deliberate 'alalum' about who will be responsible for the suspension of the negotiations gives years and an alibi to Turkey to continue its policy, leading your own policy to a dead end. So if your policy was dictated by European principles and values, you would have already suspended the accession negotiations. Unfortunately, the policy you pursue, both abroad and within the European Union, has nothing to do with these values.

name: Jeppe Kofod (S&D).
text: - Sir. Chairman! Sir. Commissioner Hahn! In 1993, Europe's leaders gathered in Copenhagen. In the shadow of the fall of the wall, a set of criteria for EU membership was adopted. It became the Copenhagen criteria, which stated that our Union consists of stable institutions that ensure democracy, the rule of law, human rights and, not least, respect for minorities. Based on these criteria, our European cooperation has grown from 12 to 15 countries in 1994, to 25 countries in 2004, 27 in 2007 and now 28 countries. But it is no secret that Turkey has so far not been able to live up to these demands. In fact, under President Erdogan's leadership, there has been only one way: back on all these fronts. It has declined markedly. That is why we must say clearly to Erdogan's Turkey that they have no future in the European Union. Therefore, we should take the consequences and stop the accession negotiations with the current Turkish government. It is the strongest signal we can send to the democratic, secular and constructive forces in Turkey, whose side we are, of course, on.

name: Mark Demesmaeker (ECR).
text: - Yes, a new political work year, a new beginning. It is never too late to gain new insights, not even for the Commission, Mr Hahn. I have listened very carefully to you and you are making the correct analysis about the bad relationship with Turkey. But you are not drawing the only correct conclusion when it comes to Turkey. Turkey will not join the European Union, not yesterday, today and tomorrow. Even Ms Merkel is no longer interested in EU membership for Turkey and is convinced that we should move to a different kind of relationship with that country. This can be a well-defined collaboration on trade, security and migration. There is support for that, but not for accession to the European Union. Are we going to be explained to the European citizen that Ankara is still passing by the till to receive many millions of euros in pre-accession aid? No, Mr Hahn. The only correct conclusion is that we are definitely putting an end to the accession talks with Turkey and pre-accession aid.

name: Κώστας Μαυρίδης (S&D).
text: - Mr President, human rights are being violated en masse in Turkey, which illegally occupies Cyprus, a territory of the European Union. The question is simple: What makes sanctions the right choice for other cases but, in the case of Turkey, should we reward it with trade, funds and credit? Recently, negotiations to end the occupation in Cyprus collapsed due to the Turkish stance. The UN Secretary-General understands that a normal state, especially a European Union state, cannot operate under the guarantee of Turkey and Turkish troops. Commissioner, I ask you a simple question: if your country, a Member State of the European Union, was the victim of invasion and occupation, would you accept Turkey as an invader as your country's guarantor?

name: Der Präsident.
text: - We now come to the catch-the-eye procedure.I have more reports than I can take and ask for your understanding.Catch-the-eye procedure

name: Laima Liucija Andrikienė (PPE).
text: - Turkey is a candidate country for membership of the European Union.She is a member of the Council of Europe.This implies that human rights and freedoms should be respected in Turkey.However, this is not the case.What we see happening in Turkey, we cannot like.Turkey is our neighbor and partner, a particularly important partner.Especially in areas such as trade or migrant crisis management, the security and defense of the European Union.The dialogue between the European Union and Turkey is open, although not always easy, as Commissioner Hahn said.It would be easier to end the ongoing negotiations than to continue them.However, I believe that by breaking the negotiations, by breaking the ties, we would achieve the opposite result than we want.The European Union would lose more than it would win.

name: Julie Ward (S&D).
text: – Mr President, the human rights situation in Turkey continues to deteriorate. A group of prominent human rights defenders, arrested in July, are still in prison on false charges. The director of Amnesty International Turkey, Idil Eser, spent time in solitary confinement and has not been able to meet with her family. These defenders must be released unconditionally. They must have our full support and they must be given humane conditions while they are in detention, such as family visits. The High Representative and Commission statements have not been strong enough on this. We need resolute action and we need loud words. Can we have clear commitment from the Commissioner and Ms Mogherini right now to make sure these human rights defenders are set free?

name: Jiří Pospíšil (PPE).
text: - Mr President, we are continuing the debate that ended a few weeks ago, and it is clear that the situation in Turkey has not changed, but has worsened.I reiterate here that I believe that the negotiations with Turkey on accession to the European Union need to be suspended, which should be a clear conclusion by the European Parliament towards the leaders who will be discussing this matter in a few weeks' time.Unlike some colleagues, I do not think that economic cooperation with Turkey needs to be deepened.If we deepen it, for example at the customs level, we are not helping the half of Turkish society that rejects Erdogan, but we are helping the President as such.This means that institutional cooperation should not be expanded, and let us send the money we send to Turkey to those who suffer under the regime, strengthen civil society, but please do not support the regime itself in any way and do not strengthen it in the future.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (ECR).
text: - Mr Hahn, EU-Turkey relations must finally be put on the right footing. The European Union must not tolerate the illegal behavior of Turkey, which daily violates Greek airspace, Greek territorial waters, threatens Greece with casus belli and questions the Greekness of the Aegean islands by promoting the gray zones. The European Union must not tolerate the illegal occupation of 37% of the Cypriot territory by the Turkish troops which in addition violate the EEZ of Cyprus. The European Union must therefore impose harsh measures and sanctions on Turkey, urging Ankara to end its threats against Greece, as well as to immediately withdraw the Turkish occupation troops from Cyprus. In addition, the accession negotiations between the European Union and Turkey must be stopped immediately, as well as the negotiations on the Customs Union, all funding from the European Union must be stopped, and the sale of arms to Turkey by the Member States of the Union must be banned. Only then will the sultan get the message.

name: José Inácio Faria (PPE).
text: - Mr President, Commissioner, Turkey's setback in terms of democracy, the rule of law, respect for minorities, including serious human rights violations in the Kurdish conflict, as well as recent attempts by the Turkish government to intervene in the election campaign. Germany, in the impasse in resolving the Cypriot question, do not allow negotiations to continue for that country's accession to the European Union. However, due to our historical relationship, the strategic importance of Turkey between two continents, its economic and military power, but also the challenges we share with the management of the migratory crisis and the fight against terrorism by the Islamic State, Europe is not can afford to ignore and harass Ankara. Dear Colleagues, although I believe that accession negotiations should be stopped sine die, I believe, however, that the European Union should not turn its back on Turkey and its people and should, on the contrary, maintain a serious and robust dialogue with Turkish authorities and urge the Turkish state to comply with its international commitments to defend fundamental rights and freedoms. Ladies and gentlemen, the Turkish people are not Erdogan and one day, I am sure, will break free from the oppressive yoke.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD).
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the Turkish government, in view of the German election on 24 September, has issued a warning to fellow countrymen, advising them to be cautious. For them, Germany would be racist and potentially dangerous. Erdogan's spokesman then increased the dose: bilateral relations victim of a limited horizon, the European Union lacks vision. I wonder what the Council is still waiting for to stop the accession negotiations, a request made by our Parliament not once but twice: in November 2016 and again in July 2017. Probably the German elections. I hope that with the polls closed, the inevitable only possible conclusion will be acknowledged: our values ​​are not negotiable, our voice cannot be silenced, while Erdogan continues his cleansing against anyone who dares raise a voice of dissent: more than 170 journalists continue to remain behind bars and, just yesterday, 17 "Cumhuriyet" journalists faced the second hearing of a sham trial. Not to mention the violence against the Kurds and the growing hostility towards Cyprus. EU-Turkey relations must be built on new foundations: yes to support for civil society, even giving the latter precisely these pre-accession funds. But now the time for words must be over and the right conclusions must be drawn from the behavior of the Turkish government.

name: Johannes Hahn
text: on behalf of the Vice-President of the Commission/High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy. – Mr President, personally I share many of your observations and judgements. I think we are all equally concerned about the downward trend in EU-Turkey relations, and I fear that it will not be the last time we discuss this here in this House. Clearly it is important to remain engaged, to keep channels open and to use these channels to stress that Turkey must respect the values on which our Union is based and to which is has signed up. So again, yes, as was said by Mr Faria, to a robust dialogue – but it is not a free lunch. Ankara must now urgently take clear steps to improve the human rights situation and to fix contentious bilateral issues with EU Member States in its own interest. I welcome the fact that our Member States will debate this at the October summit. In any case, in spring 2018 at the very latest, the Commission will have to pronounce on our relations with Turkey in our traditional Country Report, and it does not take a lot of political fantasy to imagine what I will have to write as things stand.

name: Der Präsident. –
text: The debate is closed.The vote on the resolution will take place during the October I part-session.Written statements (Rule 162)

name: Ivo Belet (PPE)
text: written.- Turkey's accession negotiations to the EU have been de facto frozen for a long time.Turkey distances itself more and more from European values.There is no longer any question of accession.It is a shame that the tires are so sour today, because everyone loses.I keep hoping this is temporary.The EU and Turkey have a mutual interest in remaining good allies in the fight against terrorism, in NATO and in addressing the conflict in Syria and refugee relief.

name: Aymeric Chauprade (NI)
text: in writing. - 12 years to understand that Turkey is not European. On September 3, 2017, Angela Merkel declared that "Turkey should not become a member of the European Union". This twist highlights the problem that we Europeans have with the long duration of history. It took us 12 years of negotiations and squandering more than 10 billion euros to come to the historical evidence: Turkey is not European! Turkish Islamists are only closing a brief parenthesis in Turkish history, that of the Kemalist nation-state. Before Erdogan, Erbakan, in the 1990s, announced the rupture: "We are not Westerners", he said, "We are not Europeans", before adding that in his eyes the European Union was, I quotes, “a Christian club under Masonic influence”. Turkey, this major player in the multipolar world, who played with us, who played with the Islamic State, with the flow of migrants, with the Turkish diasporas in Europe, this Turkey brings us back to the benches of the school, to receive one of the great lessons of history: our utopias are always swept away by the long duration of history.

name: Csaba Sógor (PPE)
text: in writing. – The Turkish Government has arrested more than 50 000 people in purges following the coup attempt in July 2016. It has imprisoned masses of journalists, wiped out freedom of speech and dismantled democratic structures and political checks and balances in the country. And now it uses European states to track down opponents and dissidents living abroad, jails European journalists and interferes in European elections. All the progress made over decades by Turkey towards democratisation – a process that the EU largely contributed to – is being reversed with extreme speed.  We cannot delude ourselves anymore about the prospect of Erdogan’s Turkey being a potential member of the EU and continue to pay millions of euro in accession aid for a country that has basically descended into autocracy. Keeping the status quo is not the right political signal the EU should send about Turkey, nor about itself.

name: Der Präsident. –
text: The next item on the agenda is the debate on the statement by the Vice-President of the Commission and High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy on the situation in Venezuela (2017/2834 (RSP)).

name: Christos Stylianides
text: on behalf of the Vice-President of the Commission/High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy. – Mr President, the people of Venezuela continue to suffer from violence, human rights violations and the deep economic crisis. All our actions as the European Union are focused on finding a way out of the current impasse, in close coordination with our partners around the world, and particularly in Latin America. All our efforts must aim at creating space for mediation between the government and the opposition. This is the only way of alleviating the suffering of the Venezuelan people.  The political violence this year has already cost too many lives. As many as 130 people were killed from April to August. Human rights violations are having a negative impact not only on the population but also on neighbouring countries, with many Venezuelans fleeing the country. The economic crisis has led to a further deterioration in living conditions. The scarcity of food is affecting children, elderly people and women in particular, not to mention the widespread shortages of medicines. As we expected, the election of a Constituent Assembly with serious doubts as to its legitimacy and representativeness has only contributed to raising tensions. Even before it took office on 2 August we had issued a statement explaining that the European Union does not and will not recognise the Constituent Assembly as legitimate. We have made clear that some steps are now urgent to de-escalate tensions and prevent a further deterioration in the situation. It is essential that the authorities fulfil the commitments agreed upon last year and reiterated in the letter from the Vatican Secretary of State, Cardinal Pietro Parolin. First, a clear electoral calendar must be established to allow the participation of all political parties from the opposition. In this regard it will also be critically important that the upcoming regional elections are free, fair and transparent on issues such as the registration of candidates, campaigning and the voting itself. So we will keep a close watch on this. Second, a humanitarian channel should be urgently opened. We are monitoring the situation very carefully. My team from DG ECHO is present in Bogota and carries out monitoring missions regularly. Let me stress here that the EU remains ready to reinforce its support to help address the most urgent needs of the population. Due to difficulties in access to the country what we are doing now is limited – targeted assistance in health and nutrition sectors – but we are exploring all possibilities for further support together with Member States, other donors and partner agencies. Third point, imprisoned opponents should be freed. We also believe that the acts and threats against the main opposition leaders, including the National Assembly President Julio Borges, the former Public Prosecutor Luisa Ortega, and the wife of Leopoldo López, Lilian Tintori, are major obstacles to a peaceful negotiated solution. Fourth and last point, the institutional prerogatives of the National Assembly should be respected. The Constituent Assembly is de facto replacing the legitimate parliament and this situation must come to an end. The European Union is united in backing these requests. Our unity was confirmed once again by EU foreign ministers in their informal meeting last week in Tallinn, and the High Representative, Federica Mogherini, and the ministers discussed their most recent diplomatic contacts and coordinated ahead of the meetings that the High Representative will hold next week in New York at the UN General Assembly’s ministerial week. We are ready to provide all our support to find a sustainable solution to the crisis together with our partners, starting with the Latin American countries, the Holy See and the United Nations. We have continuously expressed our support for regional mediation towards a non-violent return to democratic order and to address the economic and social plight of the Venezuelan people. EU foreign ministers in Tallinn also discussed the possibility of introducing targeted measures as a tool to raise pressure. At the moment we remain focused on our diplomatic and political contacts. We are ready to support by all means the possibility of a credible and meaningful regional mediation process, if requested by both sides and provided the four conditions that I listed are met. This is a moment of truth not only for Venezuela but for the whole of Latin America. The primary responsibility for ending this crisis lies in the country and in the region, and yet we will not close our eyes to the suffering of the people of Venezuela. Our contacts with our partners are discreet but constant and we really count on this Parliament also to use its network to facilitate mediation and of course, to work together for peace in Venezuela.

name: Luis de Grandes Pascual
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. - Mr President, Commissioner, the situation in Venezuela has reached a breaking point. It is no longer possible to wait for more events to act. We were able to understand Mrs. Mogherini's prudence and her initial diplomatic position, waiting for some negotiated solution to be found. But Maduro has consummated a "self-coup" that no longer allows expressing concerns or exploring sanctions. The time has come for the condemnation, without palliative, of a regime that, without respecting its Constitution, has destroyed every vestige of democracy. He prevented the recall with the lure of a "trick dialogue." He promoted and consummated the election of a monocolor and illegitimate Constituent Assembly, without a doubt, Mr. Commissioner. He nullified the capacities of the thus legitimate and constitutional National Assembly. He fired Attorney General Luisa Ortega, who has had to go into exile and has in turn accused Maduro and Diosdado Cabello of being two drug lords of a drug state. He releases him and successively imprisons the political prisoners Leopoldo López and Antonio Ledezma to demonstrate an all-embracing power, regardless of any type of judicial decision. He ends with any indication of disposition of powers, dismissing the Supreme Court and appointing another designated among his accomplices. He now initiates a persecution of the leaders of the opposition to disqualify it for the next elections. He did it with Capriles and will continue to do it with the others. Mrs. Mogherini - absent - hot cloths are no longer worth with a dictatorial and bloody regime, willing to enlist directly in a process of illegal, illegitimate and inhuman Cubanization. Many people are dying, some by gunshots, others as a consequence of the hunger and destitution to which the regime has subjected a people that belongs to a State that has enormous wealth within it. The time has come for the European Union to take responsibility and lead a common position. We must take action and to impose measures that, without further harming the Venezuelan people, freeze assets and prevent access to the territory of the European Union for all those implicated in the serious violations of human rights in Venezuela.We must demand the immediate release of all political prisoners;establish a channel to provide humanitarian assistance;demand respect for the independence of candidates for regional elections;demand an electoral call for the presidency of the Republic with a free and transparent process that can be observed by credible and prestigious international bodies.

name: Ramón Jáuregui Atondo
text: on behalf of the S & amp; D Group. - Mr. President, the creation of a Constituent Assembly and the deprivation of legislative powers from the National Assembly, in our opinion, violate the rule of law. They are clearly an overcoming of the most elementary democratic rules, and that is why I have to say very clearly that the Constituent Assembly is not democratic and that the European Union and this Parliament do not recognize it. Secondly, I believe that it is essential to continue demanding from the Government of Venezuela the freedom of political prisoners, the restitution of the powers of the National Assembly - of the legislative powers -, respect for the separation of powers and the facilitation of aid international in the key of humanitarian aid for the Venezuelan people. However, we also continue to bet on dialogue and negotiation, because basically a great agreement between the government and the opposition will be necessary for there to be a democratic and peaceful solution in that country. We do not exclude - I also say this clearly - the pressure that the international community is beginning to exert on the Government of Venezuela and, more particularly, on the political leaders of the Venezuelan regime for the violation of human rights. We are also willing to take that step if the pressure actually helps us to achieve an internal agreement that facilitates a democratic and peaceful solution to the crisis in Venezuela.

name: Charles Tannock
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Mr President, given events in Venezuela during the past year, the autocratic tendencies of President Maduro’s rule are now self—evident. Neutralising the legitimately elected National Assembly by convening a bogus constituent assembly, relying on the judgments of a pliant judiciary, repressing protests by violent crackdowns that have killed at least 130 people are all hallmarks of a wannabe dictator and, in his case, not a very clever one at that. It should also be remarked that most of the country’s opposition leaders have found themselves banned from politics, jailed or under house arrest.  As is illustrated by Jeremy Corbyn, the leader of the British Labour Party in my own Member State, there are many in this Parliament that wish to turn a blind eye to the undermining of democracy in Venezuela because of long—held sympathies for the Hugo Chavez model of socialism in Latin America. This now is a disservice to the millions of ordinary Venezuelans that are suffering from the ongoing political and economic mess and turmoil that Maduro has created. Chronic food and medical shortages continue to persist, a fact made all the more galling for a country with one of the world’s largest proven oil reserves. I believe strongly that the OAS, with EU support, must maintain the pressure on Venezuela to prevent the emergence of another Cuban dictatorship in Latin America.

name: Dita Charanzová
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. - Mr President, Commissioner, Venezuela suffered a coup last month and today is on the brink of a civil war. More than 130 dead, more than 5,000 arrests and thousands of cases of torture since April alone. Maduro continues to brutally repress his people and Venezuelans continue to suffer. This has to stop now. I have been calling for targeted sanctions on behalf of my ALDE Group since 2014. In recent weeks, President Tajani and many others have spoken in favor of this. But we need one last push: to move from words to actions. What are we waiting for? Negotiations have failed time and time again. I urge you that the European Union take a firm position against injustice and violence in Venezuela. I urge you to impose targeted sanctions against the leaders of the regime. I urge you to impose economic sanctions on Venezuelan public companies that keep the dictatorship alive. I urge the European Union to demand that complaints of crimes against humanity in Venezuela be investigated by the International Criminal Court.

name: Javier Couso Permuy
text: on behalf of the GUE / NGL Group. - Mr President, Commissioner, umpteenth debate on Venezuela. Any day they change the name of this institution to "European Parliament and Venezuela Affairs." It is regrettable to see the subordination of this Parliament and the European Union to the aggressive and destabilizing policy of Donald Trump, a policy of aggression modeled on the one carried out to overthrow and assassinate President Allende forty-four years ago. The support of this Parliament and the European Union for a part of the opposition that used street terrorism, that committed hate crimes, that encouraged a coup, is deplorable. Although some pretend to ignore the National Constituent Assembly, more than eight million Venezuelans voted for it in universal and auditable elections and, to date, no opposition party has formally challenged them. And most importantly: the next day peace settled. There is already peace. There is already an electoral route in forty days with all the opposition parties. Do not make the same mistakes that this Parliament and the European Union made because of your irresponsible interference in Libya or Myanmar. In Venezuela there are two parties, not just the one you listen to. At least there are eight million votes. Eight million citizens. They should listen to them too.

name: Ernest Urtasun
text: on behalf of the Verts / ALE Group. - Mr President, once again we have to see how we can use the instruments that we have as the European Union to favor a negotiated and agreed solution to the political crisis and the economic crisis and, above all, so that we can once again have an institutional dynamic shared by government and opposition. I think we have a chance; we are better today than a few weeks ago. Above all, I would like to celebrate the announcement that has been made that talks will begin in the Dominican Republic under the auspices of the Minister of Foreign Affairs of the Dominican Republic and the former President of the Zapatero Government. Today there was a meeting between the French Minister of Foreign Affairs Le Drian and the Venezuelan Minister of Foreign Affairs, in which both countries have reiterated their support for this negotiation process in the Dominican Republic, and I believe that tomorrow the Venezuelan Minister will travel to Madrid, where I hope that support can also be shown for this mediation. I believe that the European Union should focus right now here. I believe that this process of dialogue would not be favored at this time if, now that negotiations are beginning in the Dominican Republic, we begin to talk about sanctions, even if they are personal. I think that if this dialogue has started, it is better that we focus on it to make it a success. Because, in addition, I have the feeling that right now we are not just risking the future of Venezuela, that too. This is beginning to affect the regional dialogue and the dynamics of cooperation of the countries in Latin America and, therefore, it is very important that the dialogue process goes well, so that we can resume with full normality, for example, the dialogue EU-CELAC, which, as we all know, is suspended because of this crisis and I think this is not positive. Therefore, I would ask the European Union to support the mediation efforts. Is not the time to talk about sanctions and, if there is this opportunity in the Dominican Republic, please, let's bet on it.

name: Jean-Luc Schaffhauser
text: on behalf of the ENF group. - Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the question here is not to judge the domestic politics of Venezuela. It is a sovereign country and we cannot judge all the people of the world. In the name of what? Of our values? But, then, these values ​​must teach us respect for sovereignty. Each of us will appreciate this policy according to our sensitivity. I am not tempted, rest assured, by Mr. Chavez's socialism or even his communism. I have fought them and I am fighting them, but yet let us speak the truth beyond political bankruptcy. This country has faced US imperialism since the 19th century, and particularly since Hugo Chavez came to democratic power, following a decade of economic and social violence. This imperialism is much more real than the one you accuse Russia of. Our Parliament has approved sanctions against Russia for - and I quote - the destabilization of Ukraine. So why are those responsible for this destabilization of Venezuela not sanctioned by Brussels? The methods of destabilization are always the same as those used, moreover, by the imperialists: guided insurrectionary strikes, provoked violence, campaigns to denigrate the paid independent media and, to top it all, an attempted coup d'etat and the work-study program outside the institutional framework. We must not add crisis to the crisis, when we need mediation and truth. We must condemn violence wherever it comes from. We need humanitarian support and non-interference. It is a policy that we no longer practice because of a European policy which, itself, is becoming imperialist. All this forces us to rethink Europe on another institutional and united basis.

name: José Ignacio Salafranca Sánchez-Neyra (PPE).
text: - Mr President, Commissioner, you have perfectly described the situation in Venezuela: generalized violence, enormous suffering of the population, humanitarian emergency, violation of human rights, usurpation of national sovereignty and a totalitarian drift. That is why this Parliament is going to have to raise its voice again and tomorrow, in Mr López's report, it has to make a strong statement. My political group has been asking for selective sanctions that do not penalize the Venezuelan people against those responsible for serious human rights violations; And in this sense, Mr. President, I think it is important to emphasize that the European Parliament must once again demonstrate clearly in support of the democratic opposition in Venezuela. Beaten, persecuted, imprisoned, disabled, she is setting an example and a testimony of dignity in her fight for freedom. I would like, Mr. President, to ask the Commissioner to convey a message to the High Representative: Pope Francis, on his return trip to visit Colombia, has asked for greater involvement of the United Nations. You have referred to a regional mediation. Having failed the mediation of the presidents on behalf of UNASUR, suspended in Mercosur, condemned by the OAS, I would like to ask you if you think that the mediation of a special envoy or a special representative of the United Nations Secretary General, with the support of The international community and, of course, the European Union, could help bring the country out of the political crisis and humanitarian emergency in which it finds itself.

name: Francisco Assis (S&D).
text: - Mr President, Commissioner, we have, in fact, been here for two or three years now that we have come here to discuss - almost systematically - the issue of Venezuela and we have repeatedly called for the commitment of both parties and promoting a mediated dialogue, even by international bodies, which are above suspicion. Unfortunately the result of all this is the strengthening of a despotic regime, which has undermined the fundamental freedoms of the Venezuelan people, which has called into question the principle of separation of powers, which has promoted the phantom election of a Constituent Assembly that is not really representative of the sovereign people of Venezuela and that launched the country into a real humanitarian crisis. Today, Venezuela is experiencing an authentic humanitarian catastrophe. Which means that all these requests that we have made to promote dialogue and commitment have been in vain. I do not go so far as to say that we should not continue on this path. Evidently, this path is a path that must be followed to the limits. But I must also say that we cannot, from my point of view and my particular opinion, stop here and, for this very reason, I have, at this moment, a great mental opening for the possibility of applying sanctions of a selective nature to some of the main figures in Venezuela, because I am sure that this can contribute to calling into question the hard core of an absolutely despotic regime that is calling into question the fundamental rights of Venezuelans.

name: Anna Elżbieta Fotyga (ECR).
text: – Mr President, Venezuela is a beautiful country rich in resources with a Soviet-style kleptocratic regime killing its own people and their aspirations. Amazing that the foreign minister of such a regime was able to speak yesterday on human rights before the Human Rights Council of the United Nations.

name: Beatriz Becerra Basterrechea (ALDE).
text: - Mr President, Commissioner, please pass on to Mrs Mogherini what we are discussing today. Today we are not talking about a political crisis between two parties in Venezuela. Dear colleagues, in Venezuela what there is is an installed tyranny, what there is is a corrupt plot, with bosses linked to drug trafficking or to plots like Odebrecht's. And they will do whatever it takes to stay in power: lie, repress, starve the population or murder dissidents. We are talking about 130 people killed at the hands of armed groups in Venezuela so far this year. We are talking about 603 political prisoners, according to the latest list collected by the Venezuelan Penal Forum. In front of the tyrant Maduro, in front of his corrupt henchmen, dialogue is not worth it. The dialogue we know has failed. What is needed is to give courage and recognition to the democratic opposition and civil society that represent the dignity of Venezuela. They expect us to act and we owe it to them. If we establish sanctions for other countries, why not for Venezuela? It is time for sanctions for them, for the rulers responsible for human rights violations. The United Nations high commissioner has established clear signs of institutional systematic violence: a case of crimes against humanity. What are we here for, if not to ask for sanctions and to demand responsibility? It is time for us to act, and Venezuela deserves this and much more from us.

name: Cláudia Monteiro de Aguiar (PPE).
text: - Madam President, it goes without saying that the economic, political and social crisis in which Venezuela has been immersed for too long will be exhaustive, but it will never be too much to demand answers, to demand support, in the face of the regime that has already killed more than 130 people and that daily frees thousands of citizens from freedom. The critical voice of recurrent human rights violations is not only heard here, in Parliament. Also today, the United Nations High Commissioner for Human Rights spoke on this emergency and, yesterday, Pope Francis gave voice to the call of thousands to put an end to this humanitarian crisis. How long and how many more voices will be needed? Fear remains in place and the October 15 elections are already at hand. The fear that this will be an instrument to, once again, silence the candidates who oppose the dictatorial regime is present. I ask you, please, to take this message to Mrs. Mogherini, who is unfortunately absent today, to tell her that humanitarian aid does not reach the populations properly, the Government prevents the entry of medicines and food. In June I asked Ms. Mogherini: what is the Union doing in terms of humanitarian corridors? I am not satisfied with the answer I received and, therefore, because it is evasive, I put it again: what guarantees does it give us today and what guarantees do Venezuelans have that this help will reach them? For a year now Madeira has received around 3 thousand first generation immigrants, Portuguese descendants and spouses. Venezuelans also continue to arrive. I ask what mechanisms, what support, what funds can the Union make available to its states to support Venezuelans fleeing their own country? The violation of the rule of law principles is not a parallel reality, as the Portuguese extreme left is shamefully announced. Parallel reality does seem to be a world in which communists raise and support this type of regime.

name: Carlos Zorrinho (S&D).
text: - Mr President, Commissioner, I am well aware of the European Union's commitment to contributing to a solution to the serious crisis in Venezuela.The situation has been getting worse.The European Union cannot be a kind of privileged observer.We have to be solid and thoughtful actors.The call for negotiation and commitment between the parties, being meritorious, benefits those who are in a position of default and with no commitment in sight.We have to work hard on guarantees and consequences for those who ostensibly break them.The Venezuelan people have been deeply martyred.So sanctions that make the lives of the Venezuelan people even more difficult are not a good solution.But measures that make life difficult for leaders who repeatedly offend the principles of democratic legality are urgent and become increasingly urgent.

name: Renate Weber (ALDE).
text: – Mr President, we are talking about a country where the regime lost the popular support and turned the political fight into a fight against its people. A rich country whose citizens are hungry (a meal per day being a miracle), where basic medicines do not exist and which rejects international assistance. A country which contributed to the broadening of the meaning of a coup d’état when its Supreme Court decided it did not like the legally-elected parliament and announced it would legislate instead. It had to step back due to international pressure, but it opened the way for the President Maduro to illegally call for the election of the Constituent Assembly, whose task is to change the political landscape of the country. With political opponents in prison and this illegitimate body ruling, the dictatorship is in place. The time has come for the EU to impose sanctions on those responsible.

name: Francisco José Millán Mon (PPE).
text: - Mr. President, the situation in Venezuela - it has already been said - is extremely serious. The July 30 elections to the so-called Constituent Assembly constituted a very relevant milestone in the process of involution of the regime towards a dictatorship. It practically puts an end to the division of powers, violating the multiparty system, and democratically elected institutions are seen as unknown, ignored. The European Parliament, like other institutions of the Union, its Member States and a good part of the international community, does not recognize these elections. They unite us with the Latin American countries, principles and values. That is why we cannot be indifferent to the political, economic and social crisis that Venezuela is going through. Many of its inhabitants have European origin: Spanish citizens, Portuguese citizens, Italians; in short, many Europeans emigrated there when the country was another: respectful of freedoms, democracy and very prosperous economically. Vargas Llosa recently wrote that Venezuela was for decades an exemplary democracy, and that then its governments, verbatim, "fought an all-out battle against the dictatorships that were prospering in the rest of Latin America." Today, unfortunately, the situation is very different. Today many Venezuelans are trying to flee their country; There are many political prisoners and also many tortures, recently denounced by the United Nations High Commissioner for Human Rights. Yon Goicochea's recent testimony is shocking. On the other hand, the until recently attorney general Luisa Ortega, now in exile, speaks openly of rampant corruption. A specific amendment on Venezuela deals with these and other issues, which many Members of Parliament have submitted to Mr. López's report on European Union-Latin America relations. I hope that this amendment will be successful tomorrow. And finished. Venezuela needs the release of political prisoners and elections as soon as possible.I am sure that free and democratic elections will put a complete end to the regrettable Maduro regime, which a country like Venezuela does not deserve.And, I repeat, Mr. President, what I have said to Mrs. Mogherini on other occasions: you must get more involved.The action of the European Union in Venezuela, in this very serious crisis, does not have any visibility and I am afraid that it is not effective either.

name: Javi López (S&D).
text: - Mr. President, unfortunately, the situation in Venezuela continues to deteriorate. A crisis, that of the country, which has many faces. A political, institutional crisis, aggravated this summer after the convocation of a Constituent Assembly, which the opposition did not recognize, and with a process without democratic guarantees, in a country that we already know has politicians in jail. But also a humanitarian and economic crisis, with an economically broken country, which has seen a good part of its prosperity laminated, with hyperinflation, basic resource needs ... All this is combined with a security crisis: violence in the streets, deaths in political protests. Therefore, we want to send three messages. First, support the non-recognition of the Constituent Assembly by the high representative and the member states. Second, the path of national reconciliation, dialogue and free elections must be promoted. And third, the European Union and its Member States have to use all political and democratic tools to push in this direction.

name: Nuno Melo (PPE).
