text: - Mr President, a few days ago, Nicolás Maduro said that he is ready to become a dictator if that is necessary to stabilize prices and recover his country's turbulent economy. Pure deception, Nicolás Maduro is not willing to become a dictator. Nicolás Maduro is already a dictator and it is not because he is concerned about Venezuela's prices or economy. Coming from those who destroyed the economy of one of the richest countries in the world, just for anecdote such an argument. Nicolás Maduro does not mind being a dictator, even if it means, as it means, throwing an entire people into poverty, as he did. A President who, as denounced by the UN, allows torture, arbitrary arrests and the death of demonstrators in Venezuela, is a dictator. A President who isolates his country from the international democratic community is a dictator. A President who annihilates private property, kills the free press and nationalizes the means of production, is a dictator. A President who silences a parliament due to the fact that he has a majority that opposes him and makes an electoral simulation to fictionalize a Constituent Assembly all of his color, is a dictator. Saint Augustine said that as long as there is a will to fight, there is hope to win. Venezuela will win and the more I hear the extreme right linked to the extreme left here in the exact same arguments, the more I have this certainty. Venezuela will win, democracies will win.

name: José Inácio Faria (PPE).
text: - Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, stopping stories and fantasies: the reality is that the various resolutions condemning the repression of the Maduro regime passed in this house and the mediation attempts of the international community not only failed to create a space for dialogue that to restore the constitutional order and democracy in Venezuela, as they were unable to prevent the creation of a body that usurped the legislative powers of the democratically elected National Assembly, nor led to the release of the 603 opponents - 13 of them of European origin - who remain in prison for political motives, or even lead to the opening of a humanitarian channel. In this regard, I would like to draw your attention to a news item today that reflects the criminal intent of the Venezuelan government of not allowing its citizens access to healthcare, prohibiting 900 containers of medicines from Latin America to enter the country. In view of the seriousness of this political and humanitarian crisis, it is urgent for the Union to adopt individual and selective measures against those responsible for this situation, including for possible crimes against humanity, in the words of the United Nations High Commissioner for Human Rights. It is not, contrary to what the Venezuelan regime claims, and the extreme left, a declaration of economic war from abroad. It is about supporting a peaceful transition in that country and paying tribute to the memory of the 130 Venezuelans who, since April, lost their lives simply because they demanded respect for the rule of law, fundamental freedoms and democracy in their parents.

name: Laima Liucija Andrikienė (PPE).
text: –Mr President, Venezuela is in the midst of an unprecedented economic and political crisis marked by severe food and medicine shortages, soaring crime rates and an increasingly authoritarian executive. The international community is raising serious concerns that Venezuela is slipping into dictatorship, cautioning that democracy in the country was barely alive (if still alive). It is necessary to point out that Venezuela currently holds one of the 47 rotating seats on the UN Human Rights Council and thus has a particular duty to uphold the highest standards in the promotion and protection of human rights. The EU has to show a strong and clear opposition towards the regime in Venezuela. Imprisoned opponents of the Maduro regime have to be freed, humanitarian channels have to be opened, mediation efforts of all parties involved, namely the Holy See, the EU, the UN, countries in the region, are most welcome and should be supported, and finally, sanctions against those responsible for the abuses of human rights and the rule of law are to be introduced.

name: João Pimenta Lopes (GUE/NGL).
text: - Mr President, the hatred that is distilled here is the neocolonial hatred of those who despise and reject that a people - sovereignly - take the reins of their destiny in hand. This is what the Venezuelan people have been doing for 18 years, rejecting the yoke and capitalist exploitation, building a different model of society that managed, in this period, to achieve a breakthrough in social, political, cultural, educational development that few or no countries in the Union European Union can complain. Your hatred, projected medically by lies, promotes and fuels a reactionary, fascist right, which in Venezuela - with the support of the United States and the European Union - has, in recent years, promoted an increasing increase in disproportionate violence and a profound economic and social destabilization. A hatred aimed at sanctions that ignore the country's constitutional rule. The same hatred that now imposes criminal sanctions against Venezuela, of which the Venezuelan people will suffer firsthand, spreading hunger and misery through a fierce economic blockade that only serves your economic and geostrategic goals and interests.

name: Stanislav Polčák (PPE).
text: - Mr President, I am very pleased to speak to my colleague Piment Lopes, because what he said seems to me to be a scene from a completely different world.It was as if he did not see the dying people protesting on the streets of Venezuela, as if he did not see the fighting of the opposition, the suppression of legal demonstrations, as if he did not see those imprisoned in Venezuelan prisons, those tortured in those prisons.For me, these words were absolutely shocking like a series of statements from colleagues on the left.As if you didn't see all this and didn't want to hear it.In my opinion, we should really say enough about these phenomena in Venezuela.I would like to express my outrage at the actions of the Greek and Portuguese governments, which are making the European Union inoperable.I think we really should impose sanctions, be more proactive and support NGOs and the opposition in Venezuela.

name: Eduard Kukan (PPE)
text: - Mr President.Venezuela is in a critical situation.The country is on the verge of social and economic collapse.Madur's regime's repressive actions against the political opposition, disrespect for fundamental human rights and the liquidation of institutions have caused irreparable damage to society.In this situation, the sanctions of the international community are a proportionate response to the repression of the Venezuelan regime.The constant conditioning of basic democratic principles delays the possibilities of resolving the political crisis and the fundamental improvement of the economic and social situation.We must therefore support steps to build confidence and political stabilization in the country.The first of these steps should be the release of imprisoned opposition leaders and respect for the will of a democratically elected parliament.That is also why I fully support the nomination of the Venezuelan opposition for the Sakharov Prize.

name: Christos Stylianides
text: on behalf of the Vice-President of the Commission/High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy. – Mr President, first of all let me thank all of you for your substantial interventions. As I have already said, we will continue to follow closely the developments in Venezuela. Regarding our efforts in the humanitarian field, I have already described all of our efforts and we will definitely keep in touch with countries in Latin America, the Caribbean and other partners in order to be on the same line. We remain committed to supporting efforts to foster a peaceful, negotiated solution, but we are also aware that the time for engaging seriously in such efforts is quickly running out. We are ready to consider all available instruments to help the country find a way out of the crisis. The European Union and its Member States, our Member States, continue to monitor the evolution of the situation closely and will adjust the EU’s approach as dictated by circumstances, without ruling out any option, in case democratic principles are further undermined. I trust that we will continue to count on your support and the support of this political body, the European Parliament. We have played a crucial role in calling for a peaceful and constitutional outcome to the crisis in Venezuela. Give me the chance to encourage you to continue doing so.

name: Președintele. –
text: The debate was closed.Written declarations (Rule 162)

name: José Blanco López (S&D)
text: written. - This debate on Venezuela in the European Parliament constitutes a new example of the international concern that the situation in that country arouses. In the context of economic crisis, shortage of basic products, citizen insecurity, political violence and acute institutional tension, the Socialists agree on the following points: -The creation of a Constituent Assembly and the deprivation of its legislative powers to the National Assembly violate the Rules of the rule of law. The Constituent Assembly is not democratic and the EU does not recognize it. -We continue to demand from the Government of Venezuela: the freedom of political prisoners; the restitution of powers to the National Assembly; respect for the separation of powers; that international aid be provided to the people of Venezuela. -We continue to bet on dialogue and the internal agreement between the Government and the opposition to establish an electoral calendar, as the only peaceful and democratic solution to the current crisis. If this does not occur, we will ask the EU to study and adopt personalized sanctioning measures against the members of the Venezuelan Government and the Constituent Assembly who are responsible for human rights violations.

name: Agustín Díaz de Mera García Consuegra (PPE)
text: written. - The most painful of the situation in Venezuela is the humanitarian problem. It is an economic catastrophe, it is the most indebted country in the world, which indicates that there is no option for foreign exchange, there is high inflation, deterioration in the production levels of the industry, the collapse of agriculture ... These events have led to supply crisis. There is no food or medicine, poverty has increased by 82%, the mortality of hospitalized patients has increased tenfold and the death of newborns in hospitals by one hundred. In conclusion: dead, hungry, political prisoners and wounded. And meanwhile Maduro invents an undemocratic National Constituent Assembly; he dismisses the attorney general, Luisa Ortega Díaz; He continues the persecution and continues to harass the Venezuelan opposition and all citizens; he repeatedly rejects humanitarian assistance. I subscribe to the words of the United Nations High Commissioner for Human Rights, Zeid Ra’ad Al Hussein, and I now reiterate my shared request for an appeal and complaint before the International Criminal Court for Maduro and his accomplices. Venezuela deserves democracy, freedom, justice, peace, security and human rights. Long live free Venezuela!

name: Iratxe García Pérez (S&D)
text: written. - This debate on Venezuela in the European Parliament constitutes a new example of the international concern that the situation in that country arouses. In the context of economic crisis, shortage of basic products, citizen insecurity, political violence and acute institutional tension, the Socialists agree on the following points: - The creation of a Constituent Assembly and the deprivation of its legislative powers to the National Assembly violate the rules of the rule of law. The Constituent Assembly is not democratic and the EU does not recognize it. - We continue to demand from the Government of Venezuela: 1) The freedom of political prisoners. 2) The restitution of powers to the National Assembly. 3) Respect for the separation of powers. 4) Acceptance of international aid to the people of Venezuela. - We continue to bet on dialogue and the internal agreement between the Government and the opposition to establish an electoral calendar, as the only peaceful and democratic solution to the current crisis. If this does not occur, we will ask the EU to study and adopt personalized sanctioning measures against the members of the Venezuelan Government and the Constituent Assembly who are responsible for human rights violations.

name: Juan Fernando López Aguilar (S&D)
text: written. - This debate on Venezuela in the European Parliament constitutes a new example of the international concern that the situation in that country arouses. In the context of economic crisis, shortage of basic products, citizen insecurity, political violence and acute institutional tension, the Socialists agree on the following points: A) The creation of a Constituent Assembly and the deprivation of its legislative powers to the National Assembly violate the Rules of the Rule of Law. The Constituent Assembly is not democratic and the EU does not recognize it. B) We continue to demand from the Government of Venezuela: - The freedom of political prisoners - The restitution of powers to the National Assembly - Respect for the separation of powers - That international aid be provided to the people of Venezuela C) We continue to bet on dialogue and the internal agreement between the government and the opposition to establish an electoral calendar, as the only peaceful and democratic solution to the current crisis. If this does not occur, we will ask the EU to study and adopt personalized sanctioning measures against the members of the Venezuelan Government and the Constituent Assembly who are responsible for human rights violations.

name: Marlene Mizzi (S&D)
text: in writing. – Venezuela is facing a human rights and humanitarian crisis. The Maduro administration enjoys a tremendous concentration of power that violates human rights and creates a deep economic crisis. This political violence has cost too many lives. Opponents, including anti-government demonstrators, critics and opposition politicians have been arbitrarily arrested and prosecuted. Venezuelan groups identify over 600 detainees as political prisoners. The security forces have committed egregious abuses, including torture.  Severe shortages of medicines, medical supplies and food have intensified since 2014, and weak government responses have undermined Venezuelans’ rights to health and food. The shortage of food and medicines is affecting children, women and elderly people. We have to make sure that humanitarian corridors should be urgently opened in order to supply the people of Venezuela with food and medicines.

name: Președintele. –
text: The next item is the debate on the report by Javi López, on behalf of the Committee on Foreign Affairs, on the EU's political relations with Latin America (2017/2027 (INI)) (A8-0268 / 20017).

name: Javi López
text: speaker. - Mr President, as we well know, the world is experiencing a rapid and profound reorganization of international relations, and Europe runs the risk of being sandwiched between Atlantic weakness, a neighborhood full of conflicts - with some aggressive actors - and the rise of Asia . But that should not only concern us as Europeans; we are concerned because it also puts at risk the values ​​and principles that Europe represents in the world: the will to build international relations as a result of multilateralism, dialogue and rules. For all this, and in the face of this new scenario, we are also given the opportunity to strengthen strategic ties with those who share this vision and who also share an agenda in the world. With this objective in mind, this report is being presented today here in Parliament: to explain and tell the group of European institutions that, as a result of the new international reality, relations between the European Union and Latin America today are not just a matter of convictions. They are a matter of necessity. That we want to work together and we have to work together between both regions to promote inclusive governance, defend development goals, fight climate change and protect the Paris Agreements, fight for gender equality, impose governance, globalization with rules and share its benefits. An agenda that we share with these actors —the Latin Americans and the Caribbean—, with both regions, and that we do not share with all the major actors on the international scene. It is evident that we have many ties: historical, cultural, human, economic with both regions. But no relationship can be taken for granted, especially also due to the profound changes, the interactions that exist on this continent, in Europe, but which have also occurred in recent years in Latin America. Since 1999 there is an Association Strategic between the Union and the subcontinent, but many times the relationship between the Union and Latin America has been relegated. Today is the time for it to become a reality. And we have tools for it. We have a dense, long list of association agreements under negotiation: we have association agreements in update with Mexico, with Chile, which can boost our relationship; an agreement in negotiation with Mercosur; We also have a recent political dialogue and cooperation agreement with Cuba, which we understand has a regional impact. But we don't just have this list of agreements. We have an institutional agenda at the summits of the European Union-CELAC that, unfortunately - and I will refer to it later - may be clouded by some of the problems in the region, such as Venezuela. Summits that must act with greater strength to coordinate our position in the G-20, the United Nations, the International Monetary Fund or the WTO. We must and must continue to maintain development cooperation with the region. We have to continue working together so that there is greater mobility; protect common security, especially that of some countries in Central America - a threat that also exists in Europe; follow the hopeful progress in Colombia closely, while addressing the very serious problems of Venezuela. The moment is now. It is now when we must boost our relations, continue working together, establish a clear strategy of the Commission for the region, strengthen our ties to raise our voice in defense of shared values ​​and principles.

name: Christos Stylianides
text: on behalf of the Vice-President of the Commission/High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy. – Mr President, since the beginning of this Commission’s mandate we sought to further strengthen relations with Latin America and the Caribbean. Our culture and economic ties date back centuries but we are also getting into a new era. Our economies are more connected than ever. We are partners and allies on the great global issues of our times, from climate change to sustainable development. We share the vision of a more multilateral world, where all continents and all peoples have a say and contribute to global governance. As mentioned in your excellent report, the European Union seeks to reinforce its partnership with Latin America and the Caribbean not only in terms of economic change, but as a partner in social progress and in the defence of common values. In order to do that, we have at our disposal powerful cooperation instruments such as EU-funded programmes and technical or high-level meetings that allow us to foster cooperation and strengthen the ties between both decision-makers and civil societies. Latin America and the Caribbean are now looking for their own way towards regional integration, both on a continental scale and within its sub-regions. For instance, we are deepening our engagement with the Pacific Alliance, in particular on academic exchanges, consular assistance, free movement of citizens or investment policies. In your report you urge the High Representative to ‘look into the possibility of the EU participating as an observer’ in the Pacific Alliance. The EU has already been invited to the high-level meetings of the Pacific Alliance, including the Summit in Cali (27-30 June), as a special guest. We will look into the possibility of becoming an observer as the Pacific Alliance continues to consolidate itself. Let me also mention our relations with Mercosur, which have been galvanised by resuming the negotiation of an Association Agreement. Our goal is to finish the negotiations in the coming months, but beyond the regional and sub-regional organisation, our bilateral relations with almost all countries of the continent are going through a particularly dynamic phase. Let me just mention a few concrete examples. The negotiations to modernise the EU-Mexico Association Agreement are advancing at a good pace. Via meetings, videoconferences and negotiation rounds, the Agreement is taking shape and we aim to conclude negotiations in the coming months. The Council is currently discussing the mandate to negotiate the update of the EU-Chile Association Agreement. This negotiation will allow us to deepen our relations with a close ally with whom we share a rich common agenda, including peace and security. Another partner in defence and security is Colombia, where we have supported the peace agreement from the moment it was signed with a dedicated trust fund. Let me pay tribute to the role the European Parliament has been playing to support an active contribution by the European Union to the peace process in Colombia. The bilateral ceasefire announced by the Government and the ELN on 4 September constitutes a further step forward for peace in Colombia. The European Union, also through the High Representative’s Special Envoy Mr Eamon Gilmore, will continue our work to help the peace process overcome all remaining obstacles. Peace in Colombia was not the only historic event taking place in the region over the past few months. Our political dialogue and cooperation agreement with Cuba constitutes a landmark for the EU’s policy towards the region. In a sign of a new era in Latin America and the Caribbean, we are looking forward to the launch of the provisional application of an agreement that will allow us to strengthen our relations in a wide array of areas, including human rights. Human rights is precisely one of the areas where we cooperate the most with our partners in the region, including in Central America and the Caribbean, where we are also strengthening our support to fight against climate change. The situation in Venezuela makes for a striking exception after such a long list of positive developments. The political violence and the economic crisis risk destabilising not only the country, but the entire region. This crisis encourages us to seek even closer cooperation with all countries in Latin America and the Caribbean to support any attempt for regional mediation between the Venezuela Government and the opposition. Our regions may be geographically distant, but there is so much that we share. We have a direct interest in seeing Latin America and the Caribbean prosper, with peace, development and social justice for all. Our commitment is here to stay. Our friendship is here to stay, and our partnership can only get deeper and stronger in time.

name: Enrique Guerrero Salom
text: Draftsman of the opinion of the Committee on Development. - Mr. President, as this report points out, we must strengthen and modernize our cooperation and our relations with Latin America and the Caribbean, and a good way to do this - if not the best - is to cooperate with them in achieving the sustainable development goals. . The Latin America-Caribbean area has grown in recent years and has lifted millions of people out of poverty, but today 175 million still live below the poverty line, live in exclusion and live in inequality. Measuring our cooperation through a single indicator - gross domestic product - and excluding middle-income countries from it is a bad solution, it is unfair and it is discriminatory. Because GDP is blind to territorial inequalities, it is blind to generational inequalities and does not take into account the specific risk in the face of climate change. A good way to cooperate with them is to support Latin American countries that, together with the United Nations, are proposing a way to restructure sovereign debt in a sustainable and at the same time supportive way.

name: Luis de Grandes Pascual
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. - Mr President, Commissioner, the report that we must evaluate tonight - Mr Juncker, I remind you - is that of the Union's political relations with Latin America. This report follows the one that our colleague Salafranca produced with success and prestige. Today it must be updated in the light of political, social and economic events, as well as geostrategic trends in the region. This report provides an overview of the situation in Latin America and the Caribbean and of relations with the European Union. We sincerely thank the rapporteur for his attitude, his receptivity, the receptivity that he has had with our proposals, which were already reflected in a great, albeit partial, consensus in the vote in the Committee on Foreign Affairs. We hope and fear that in tomorrow's vote we will have some difference, but it will be small; because unity is sharing the great values ​​and we share them without any doubt. We must, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, continue to strengthen institutional links, such as EuroLat and CELAC. The European Union shares with its Latin American partners the importance of principles and values ​​such as democracy, human rights and the rule of law, as well as the importance of credible legal frameworks, essential to maintain political stability and social and economic development. . We have reflected the general positive trend towards lasting democratization in Latin America by holding regular and fair elections. This process of democratization throughout the region has been accompanied by the formal recognition of citizens' rights, such as health care, employment, or education, many of which are now codified in national constitutions. From the European Parliament we commit ourselves to work so that, through EuroLat, common regional positions are found, support to the defenders of human rights, the protection of indigenous communities is strengthened and Latin American governments continue to be encouraged and assisted to achieve a sustainable balance in the exploitation of natural resources, on the one hand, and to protect the environment and the rights of communitieslocal, on the other.We close this year celebrating peace in Colombia.We celebrate the opening of conversations with the ELN.In this sense, we are going to support, symbolically, the rapporteur's amendment - which is better than ours -, without prejudice to the fact that we have to disagree in the analysis and vote on Venezuela, where it is not a question of rejecting but of condemning.Thank you, rapporteur.

name: Ramón Jáuregui Atondo
text: on behalf of the S & amp; D Group. - Mr. President, I would like to begin by asking everyone not to question the report on Latin America by looking at Venezuela or Cuba. I think it is important that Europe has the warm look towards Latin America that Javier López's report proposes to us. I want to start by thanking Javier for producing this report - and the shadow rapporteurs and political groups who have worked with him - so that Europe sets its sights on Latin America in a way that it has not done to date - in my opinion , Unfortunately-. There is a permanent look at Eastern Europe, a look at the Mediterranean, for obvious reasons; but the Atlantic basin is not a border of distance, really, there is not that much space. There is a historical cycle to close, there is an economic, commercial, cultural reality, there are a lot of things to do together in Latin America and Europe. We agree: climate change, said Enrique Guerrero, and I would add the fight against tax havens, for a fair international tax system, for an orderly democracy, for a regulated governance of the world. All this unites Latin America and Europe. There is no better neighbor for Europe than Latin America. There is no better friend for Europe than Latin America. That is the idea behind this message, which this report gives us: the possibility of bringing closer, of strengthening, of making the relationship between Europe and Latin America more solid.

name: Kosma Złotowski
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. - Mr Chairman! Latin America is, on the one hand, one of the fastest-growing regions in the world, and on the other, an area of ​​enormous economic inequality. We must remember this when building good political and economic relations between the European Union and all the countries of this region. I am pleased that this report sees the need to accelerate the ongoing negotiations on updating the Union-Mexico General Agreement. In the face of the crisis in relations between the United States and Mexico, the European Union should seize the opportunity to strengthen this area of ​​its trade policy, especially as Mexicans expect it. The European Union must also increase the political and economic pressure on the government in Venezuela, which through its actions is deepening the internal crisis that has been going on for months. Ladies and Gentlemen, communism has already collapsed once and even talented people like Venezuelans are not able to rebuild it, but unfortunately they are able to ruin their own country, which we obviously do not wish them.

name: Renate Weber
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Mr President, I thank the rapporteur for his report and his good cooperation with the political groups in this House. I personally have always been a vocal advocate in favour of stronger relations between the EU and Latin America, at all levels and on multiple subject. There are many things that we have in common, and the report clearly mentions them as it stresses the need for closer cooperation. I want to emphasise the friendly and supportive approach that the EU has in its relations with Latin America and mention, for example, the financial, humanitarian and expert assistance offered during the fires in Chile recently; the financial and expert support to the peace process in Colombia; the assistance to democratic evolution via EU election observation missions and their follow-up activities. But this also implies that we are concerned when something goes very wrong. We say what we think and we act because we care about those who are victims of unjust actions taken by their government. This is not interference in internal affairs. This is partnership. We as the EU and European citizens accepted very harsh criticism on our failures on the refugee crisis and never said that this was interference. This is the case when he criticised Nicaragua or Venezuela. We cannot simply disregard what happens in a country such as Venezuela and accept the Maduro regime calling the UN Secretary-General a liar. Quite the opposite; we must support his demand for a thorough investigation undertaken by the International Criminal Court. We must put in place sanctions against those who are responsible for the disastrous situation in Venezuela.

name: Javier Couso Permuy
text: on behalf of the GUE / NGL Group. - Mr President, it is a shame that a report whose rapporteur had the will to add and support the spirit of strengthening relations between the EU and Latin America, mutual development and respect, has been completely distorted by the ALDE proposals, PPE and ECR, who have turned it into an overbearing report marked with a vision that has a neocolonial whiff. This text does not place the European Union and Latin America on an equal footing, but rather places the Union in an absurd position of tutelage. It is intended to give lessons in politics, economics and social rights to another continent when we do not even have our own problems resolved, instead of seeking cooperation and exchange among equals. The addition on Venezuela, calling for sanctions, is directly related to the attitude of a president of the European Parliament who, claiming to represent the entirety of this Chamber, oversteps his functions and imposes his vision over the resolutions of this Parliament, while it dares to torpedo the EuroLat-EU-CELAC bilateral dialogue. This report gives wings to that extremist vision of breaking the dialogue between Europe and Latin America and, for this reason, we will vote against.

name: Ernest Urtasun
text: on behalf of the Verts / ALE Group. - Mr President, I would like, first of all, to thank the rapporteur for the good work in putting forward a text that frames a message that is important to me: to see how the European Union and Latin America can strengthen joint cooperation to strengthen multilateralism on a global scale, at a time, of course, when, with the Trump Administration, that is at risk. I also believe that it is important that we reflect - and the report does so in parts - on how we update the cooperation agenda. I want to thank the rapporteur for accepting some of our proposals on climate change, on the fight against violence against women - which he particularly worries us - and on the role that Mesecvi can play in all of this. But I think we really need to update that relationship between Europe and Latin America and, particularly - and my group insisted on this many times - it cannot pivot only on sticking with the type of trade agreements that we have been developing in recent years. And here I believe that it is important to give a much more political dimension to the relationship, and not so much within the framework of this type of agreement which, from our point of view, is not always positive. For example, if we want to fight against tax havens - which I fully agree with what was proposed - we have to see, for example in the Agreement between the European Union and Mexico, how that Agreement is used, for example, for the money laundering. Because it is being used. And that kind of thing we must see together. I will just end by saying that I am sorry that the Venezuelan debate has gotten into this report. He did not play. I think it could have been done elsewhere, and it may have broken some consensus. In any case, I just want to end by thanking the rapporteur Javi López, who I think has done an excellent job.

name: José Ignacio Salafranca Sánchez-Neyra (PPE).
text: - Mr President, I would also like, like other colleagues, first of all - and Mr de Grandes has done so on behalf of our political group - to thank the rapporteur for his permanent readiness for dialogue and his positive and constructive attitude, which has given us allowed to accommodate the amendments that Mr. de Grandes and I have tabled on behalf of our political group. I believe that the rapporteur has rightly pointed out that the European Union, in this unstable world, needs allies who share values ​​and interests to face global challenges, and I believe that, indeed, the Bi-regional Strategic Partnership is still to be built and, obviously, there is still much to do. I am glad that this report goes from words to deeds and does not stop at just rhetorical questions. For this reason, I believe that it is necessary to underline the importance of time management in the association agreements to which the commissioner has referred; in the renewal of the agreements with Mexico and Chile; and the conclusion of the pending subject which is the European Union-Mercosur Association Agreement. I am pleased that this report also asks for Argentina the space that corresponds to it in accordance with its status as a member of the G-20, a prominent member of Mercosur and a relevant actor also on the international scene. Mr. Guerrero, as rapporteur for the Committee on Development, made reference to the need for the countries of Latin America to be able in some way not to be excluded - I mean middle-income countries - from the new concept that the European Union is proposing for development. And, Mr President, I would like to end by saying, since the President of the European Parliament is not here, that he, in his statements, has adhered exactly to the terms approved in the resolutions. I finish as I started, thanking the rapporteur for his disposition, and I think that Mr. Jáuregui is right: this work is a model of how they should be developed the responsibilities that citizens have entrusted to us in our work together.

name: Francisco Assis (S&D).
text: - Mr President, Commissioner, I want to begin by welcoming the author of this report. This report is of the utmost importance, both for its opportunity and for its content and it is unquestionable that it is a report of great quality. This report aims at a fundamental political objective: to give a signal by this European Parliament in relation to what the relations between the European Union and Latin America must be. In fact, we have no closer partners, from the point of view of the identity of values, principles, models of political and economic organization, than most countries that make up Latin America. This does not correspond to any neocolonial vision, far from it. I do not see, in fact, in this report any neocolonialist perspective on the relationship with Latin America. What is there is an enhancement of common values, of values ​​that are values ​​both in Europe and in most Latin American countries, and above all, there is one thing that is important: it is to highlight how Latin America has evolved in recent decades. Several democracies have been consolidated, there has been a process of economic development, millions of people have left poverty, progress is being made towards the consolidation of the rule of law. Many of the crises that some countries are facing are crises of growth and maturation of their democratic processes, such as, for example, the case that I know best, even for obvious reasons, which is the Brazilian case, which is a country which is experiencing difficulties but which corresponds to the consolidation of a democracy associated with the rule of law. That is why I conclude, once again stressing the importance of such a report.

name: Izaskun Bilbao Barandica (ALDE).
text: - Mr President, I would like to congratulate the rapporteur for this report and encourage the Community institutions to take its contents very seriously. The consolidation in this region of the world of shared values ​​on human rights, democracy and social and labor standards is key to improving the quality of life and opportunities for its inhabitants. And to achieve this, we support peace processes such as that of Colombia, including the reintegration of FARC members, or condemning regimes such as Venezuela, denouncing the repression of opponents by the illegitimate Constituent Assembly, and working for a democratic solution. Also signing fair trade agreements that promote sustainable and inclusive development, or holding negotiations with the countries of the Pacific Alliance or Mercosur. These actions, in addition to a contribution to peace, stability and social justice, are a strategic requirement at a time when other ways of doing things are taking positions in the area. And for this reason, the 2030 Agenda for Development and its objectives must be the main instruments for cooperation in all aspects of economic, social and sustainable development.

name: Tania González Peñas (GUE/NGL).
text: - Mr. President, I believe that this report echoes the progress and challenges that the continent has faced in the last decade, and in that sense we welcome the support for the peace process in Colombia and the dialogues with the ELN. However, I believe that it does not resolve one of the great contradictions, which has to do with the unequal effects that the Free Trade Agreements generate on the development of the region. Most of these Free Trade Agreements, instead of opening the doors to beneficial political and commercial relations for both parties, what they do is to build walls with Latin America. They are walls that, in the name of development, continue to increase inequality between the few who benefit from the Free Trade Agreements and the majority who suffer poverty from its effects. Talking about political relations in equity implies promoting the same values ​​that we include in our Treaties and, in that sense, respect for human rights cannot be for the European Union a negotiable democratic surplus within a trade agreement, but rather it must be the central element, the lowest common denominator in our agreements.

name: Elmar Brok (PPE).
text: - Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen! I think Europe has neglected Latin America for too long. This is a region of great economic and political-strategic importance. We didn't pay enough attention to it because we looked too much at Asia. The Americans have now canceled TTIP. This leaves a huge strategic void across the Pacific. We know that the Latin American countries participating in this treaty, but also others, hope that we Europeans will break this vacuum so that this vacuum is not taken over by China. If you talk to those responsible in Brazil, Argentina or other countries, you will know the extent to which Chinese interests precede them. It is for this reason that I really want to ask the Commission to go stronger and faster with its intentions to come to these treaty negotiations with Mercosur and others. It is not only of great importance in terms of trade policy, but also of great global strategic importance, and I would also like to counter our colleagues on the left: This also means that Maduro and others in such countries will not eradicate democracy and the rule of law and that such rich countries are driven into poverty from the point of view of such a misunderstood socialism. This must not lead us to destroy these relationships, but we must be careful and make it clear that these people cannot speak for Latin America. Venezuela is one of the richest countries in the world, but what is operating a regime there with the wrong ideology is a catastrophe for the people in this country and for all of Latin America. We should also make that clear.

name: Isabella De Monte (S&D).
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, there are many places where better political collaboration between the European Union and Latin America is needed. I am pleased that the European consensus on development has been signed as a solid political foundation for strengthening European action in this area. Indeed, it contains an explicit commitment by the Member States and the European institutions to support the Latin American governments through cooperation with local authorities. Serious problems afflict the South American continent, such as corruption and crime. I look forward to greater cooperation between the two continents to reduce poverty which today ensures a constant labor force in drug trafficking areas. Improving job opportunities will promote economic transparency, competitiveness, as well as the security of the population. Finally, I support the implementation of the global European strategy to improve the rule of law, respect for human rights and the environment.

name: Francisco José Millán Mon (PPE).
text: - Mr. president; thanks to Mr López for this report, an important report because the European Union's relations with Latin America are also important. I want to highlight the numerous and deep historical, cultural, economic, human, and also political ties that exist between the two blocks. In addition, Latin America already includes countries such as Mexico and Brazil, recognized as strategic partners by the European Union. The European Union and Latin America must face in a coordinated way the global challenges in an interconnected and complex world. Together we are one third of the membership of the United Nations. Furthermore, we share - I believe - a certain vision of international governance and human rights, and both blocs believe in effective multilateralism. We are, I would say, natural allies. Our relationship must be intensified, taking advantage of the different existing frameworks and forums. As everyone knows, China is increasing its presence in Latin America and, on the other hand, from the new administration in Washington some signals are coming that generate uncertainty or confusion in the subcontinent. In this state of affairs, we Europeans must strengthen our presence in the region. How? It has already been said: ending soon the modernization of the agreements with Mexico and Chile. We must also conclude the long-running European Union-Mercosur negotiations, that pending issue mentioned by my colleague Salafranca and which would create, with other existing agreements, a vast economic and commercial space between the European Union and Latin America. I end by underlining the importance of the Pacific Alliance, and I believe, as stated in the report by Mr. López that we will vote tomorrow, that Mrs. Mogherini and the European External Action Service should study the convenience of the European Union being in this bloc —in the Pacific Alliance - as an observer, something that several member states have already done, including Spain.

name: Carlos Zorrinho (S&D).
text: - Commissioner, in foreign policy, as in almost everything in life, the most urgent is not always the most important. The report we are debating today reinforces the conviction of the importance of relations between the European Union and Latin America, despite the fact that the world is full of conflicts or disputes, effective or potentially more media and more politically appealing. Latin America and the European Union, in addition to a strong identity sharing, also share the fact that they are victims of unregulated globalization. If we want, and I know we want, to recover our global voice and affirm a sustainability and humanism agenda, we need to work together and give clear signs of a strategic alliance. And trade agreements are a privileged vehicle for translating intentions into acts. We have good experiences with the countries of Latin America. For this reason, concluding a trade agreement with Mercosur will be a decisive step towards the geostrategic rebalancing and the consolidation of relations between our peoples.

name: Laima Liucija Andrikienė (PPE).
text: – Mr President, I would like to thank Mr López for his report. It is a good report.  Latin America is one of the fastest-developing regions in the world. It is a region with huge potential. Both the EU and Latin America, as well as countries of the Caribbean region, could benefit much more from cooperation and partnership agreements and trade agreements. In order for this to happen, they have to be modernised. The Latin America and Caribbean region constitutes a strategic partner for the EU – a key partner – when it comes to jointly facing current global challenges, such as peace and security, economic development, climate change an combating tax havens, etc. The long—lasting partnership between the EU and LAC countries is founded on historical, cultural, human and economic ties, which must not be taken for granted. The modernisation of EU-Latin America agreements are necessary as Latin American countries are currently facing the main geopolitical shifts marked by the increased presence of some countries like China, or even Russia, which are seeking to gain strategic influence and a military presence, and to develop economic partnerships in the region.  Mr López, thank you very much for your report. I hope it is adopted.

name: José Inácio Faria (PPE).
text: - Commissioner, the close cultural, linguistic, political and historical ties that unite the European Union with the countries of Latin America make it vital to develop a shared agenda and to strengthen cooperation in defining the Union's major foreign policy priorities. protectionism in the world requires the strengthening of the Union's bilateral and multilateral economic partnerships in the region, which are mutually beneficial but, in addition to the trade part, it is important, in a political context, to strengthen interparliamentary cooperation and to value the continuous promotion of democratic values ​​and human rights, including the defense of the property rights of the indigenous peoples of Brazil over the lands they ancestrally occupy, the fight against climate change and cooperation in the field of research and innovation. The strengthening of cooperation between the two regional blocs therefore plays a pivotal role in the diversification of the economies of both regions and in the promotion of more sustainable, more democratic and more inclusive development, because it is about the European Union's political relations with in Latin America, I end by invoking the heroic martyr people of Venezuela who die at the hands of a bloodthirsty regime and calling on this Parliament to do everything it can to alleviate the suffering of this brother people.

name: Julie Ward (S&D).
text: – Mr President, colleagues, during the summer recess I spent 12 days in Brazilian Amazonia, and during that time I met with politicians, lawyers, academics, students, rural educators, government workers, indigenous people, environmentalists, young people, cultural activists and the media. I visited vast mines which are despoiling the land and polluting the river systems. I flew deep into the forest and saw the burning of trees to make way for cattle. I visited the 400-year-old town that will be destroyed by mega-hydroelectric dams, built not for public benefit but to accelerate industrial processing of minerals to line the pockets of the rich. Whilst I was in Marabá, the mayor of a neighbouring municipality was assassinated – the third such murder in a few weeks. I attended vigils for landless peasants massacred by hired guns. It is quite clear that Brazil is descending into chaos, with a corrupt authoritarian government, totally in hock to the agricultural lobby and the extractive industries. President Temer and his business cronies are, frankly, a danger to the whole of society.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (ECR).
text: - Mr President, EU-Latin America relations must be based on democracy, human rights, the rule of law and equal economic relations. Relations that serve the mutual economic interest of our peoples. On the contrary, experience to date has shown that European multinationals are exploiting the peoples of Latin America, as the Spanish and Portuguese colonialists did in the past. And now the European Union is advancing to the second round, competing with China on Latin American soil for profit. Taking initiatives to reduce poverty and exploitation, however, also requires actions for social growth and job creation, and for this to happen, the public debt of Latin American countries must be restructured. In addition, tax evasion and tax evasion by multinationals must be tackled, anti-corruption measures must be taken, as well as measures to crack down on the drug trade. Only in this way can EU-Latin America relations be strengthened.

name: Beatriz Becerra Basterrechea (ALDE).
text: - Mr President, the political relations between the European Union and Latin America in 2017 clearly needed to be seen in a new light: that of the challenges of the 21st century posed to us by two partners; two partners who are appreciated and needed and who share their "anti" and "pro": anti-impunity, anti-corruption, anti-inequality, anti-exploitation and anti-repression of freedoms; and human rights, modern pro-democracy, sustainable development and free trade. However, for some reason, the extreme left - Mr. Couso - has said that he is going to vote against this report because we have introduced an amendment asking for sanctions for the dictator who has devastated Venezuela and his cronies. I cannot understand it, nor can I understand that another colleague, Mr. Urtasun, said that it was not the time, that Venezuela was not playing now. The United Nations has recognized that the situation in Venezuela is a serious danger to the stability and security of the region. When do we have to talk about Venezuela, then? I want to congratulate Mr. López for his vision, for the ability he has had to include this integrated aspect of our approach to Latin America and, of course, I want to endorse here the full will of this Parliament to rise to the occasion.

name: Stanislav Polčák (PPE).
text: - Mr President, I would like to follow up on my colleague, and I would also like to commend the report drafted by the rapporteur, and I also appreciate his positive approach, which is reflected in that report.However, one cannot certainly turn a blind eye to the problems facing Latin America.Although I appreciate that he has included proposals from my faction, for example, we need to discuss the current issues, which are simply in Brazil and Venezuela, but also in other Latin countries.I am convinced that this very debate must result in some concrete proposals from the parties to the sanctions, the parties to the condemnation of the regime in Venezuela, because people are really dying there.That regime is completely undemocratic and we need to stand unequivocally and loudly on the side we want to support.I don't think we can be toothless.

name: Christos Stylianides
text: on behalf of the Vice-President of the Commission/High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy. – Mr President, firstly I would like to congratulate the rapporteur and of course thank my dear colleagues for this important debate. This debate confirms that we all share a strong commitment to further strengthening our relations with Latin America and the Caribbean. All EU policy instruments are being used to foster and continuously adapt our partnership. It is through dialogue, cooperation and engagement that our common values, goals and challenges will result in a strong partnership with these countries.  The European Union needs to continue reinforcing the areas for dialogue and adapting to regional or sub-regional initiatives. This is why we will keep working on the negotiations of modern and comprehensive association agreements, in particular on strengthening our cooperation and aid, and of course, on our political dialogues with our partners in the region.

name: Javi López
text: speaker. - Mr President, I would like to add a few elements. First of all, I am very grateful for the words of all my colleagues and especially thank you for the open work that has taken place in recent months, the cooperation from the shadow rapporteurs, from all the groups, who have undoubtedly improved the text and who have made the result, for tomorrow, is a better text. I would also like to thank the work and help of the previous rapporteur for this report, Mr Salafranca, who has already been mentioned and with whom we have counted as a whole of Members and as Parliament. Generosity has been mentioned before. I believe that I have tried to work with that spirit — which I have found most of the time; not all of them, I have to say—, above all for one matter: because the more we care about a topic, the more unity it has, the stronger the message. And with that idea I have tried to work, and with that idea I have worked over the last months and I will continue to work in this Parliament, surely with many of the colleagues who are here today. On behalf of all of us who have been working over the last few months, I would like to say and ask the Commission and tell and convey to the High Representative that this work has to serve the Commission, Mrs Mogherini and the European External Action Service as a reference, as a guide, for years to come. And to convey that the report aims for both regions to move from the strong friendship that we have to the alliance, and that we understand that, in a world of change, where we have a lot of instability as a result of our neighborhood, the Atlantic continues to be the greatest source power of the world, and it is a source that we have to use and reinforce in the face of instability in our neighborhood. We will do that and this report tries to contribute to this, to relations with Latin America and the European Union.

name: Președintele. –
text: The debate was closed.The vote will take place on Wednesday, 13 September 2017. (The sitting was suspended for a few minutes.)

name: Președintele. –
text: The next item on the agenda is the brief presentation of Cristian Dan Preda's report on the EU's political relations with India (2017/2025 (INI)) (A8-0242 / 2017).

name: Cristian Dan Preda
text: protractor. - Mr President, many qualifiers have been used to sum up the relationship between the European Union and India: natural, strategic, solid or even based on values. This relationship is all of these at the same time, but above all it is a relationship that has enormous potential, provided that both parties put their partnership high on their agendas. The report I have written and negotiated over the past few months sends a clear message a few weeks before the 14th EU-India summit. The European Parliament fully supports a truly strategic partnership with India, as the full potential of this relationship has not been developed. Indeed, trade between the Union and India should not be limited to trade, although trade obviously has an important role and negotiations around a free trade treaty should be a priority for both. sides. The challenges the two partners face internationally are similar, whether it be regional tensions or global issues such as terrorism, lack of respect for international law, or climate change. For the AFET Committee, the future of the relationship between the European Union and India includes several areas of work, including old ones that need to be revived. It is first of all a matter of working more closely at the global level in favor of effective and regulated multilateralism, of a reform of the United Nations, and of coordinating more often our respective positions in the international. We must then step up our exchanges on the fight against terrorism, in accordance with the declaration made at the last EU-India summit. There is a lot of space for cooperation in the prevention and fight against radicalization. We can also advocate together at the United Nations level, for example, the adoption of the general convention on international terrorism. On the other hand, we can together contribute to conflict reduction and Asia's prosperity, whether through support for regional integration processes, but also through fostering democratic processes in the countries of the region. India and the European Union can also try to take a positive part in the establishment in Afghanistan of a peace and reconciliation process by strengthening their political coordination on questions of military security or development aid. . Likewise, the actions of India and the Union in the field of development, whether in India's Asian neighborhood or in Africa, would have everything to gain from greater coordination so that they are complementary. . We could also strengthen our exchanges in favor of universal disarmament, the non-proliferation of weapons of mass destruction and nuclear security. Objectives to which both the Union and India are committed. Working together for a strict application of the United Nations sanctions against North Korea is a goal to be achieved in this context. I would like to draw attention more generally to the importance of establishing mechanisms for foreign policy consultation between India and the European Union, including on matters on which we have had different perspectives through the past. Whether it is China's offensive policy in the South China Sea, the need for India-Pakistan rapprochement, or even aggressive Russian actions in its neighborhood. So these are some of the possible lines of work, but there are obviously many others, ranging from human rights to maritime safety, including people-to-people exchanges. So there are a lot of bricks with which we could build the relationship between India and the European Union in the months and years to come, and I hope that the summit that will take place on October 6 will open and develop some of these areas.

name: Geoffrey Van Orden (ECR).
text: – Mr President, first of all I would like to congratulate Cristian Dan Preda on an excellent and well-balanced report which I am sure Parliament will approve and which I know will also find approval in India. Having said that, I must express some disappointment that we talk about enhanced relations with India but here we are at nearly 10.45 p.m. in an empty Chamber. The Council is not even present. Is this really the importance that we attach to relations with one of the great countries of the world, a future superpower, its economy growing at over 7% per year, an ambitious middle class of over 200 million people, a country with great skills, a government under Mr Modi that is now addressing some of the great problems of rural poverty, many areas of potential partnership. Our bilateral trade, I have to say, between European countries and India is at disappointingly low levels and there are all these other issues which Cristian Dan Preda has touched on. There is so much more to do. Is it not time that we really paid attention properly to our relations with this great country?

name: Elmar Brok (PPE).
text: - Mr President, Commissioner! I would like to thank Cristian Preda warmly for this report and for placing India at the center of our deliberations. Mr van Orden, the sun is rising in India right now and that is why we are having this debate at this point. But of course you are absolutely right that this India is of central strategic importance for us, economically and politically. We have to see that India has a decisive lead over China: India is already a democracy and does not have to make this political system change, which China will be subject to at some point. This should be a weighty reason for us to work more closely with India here - an India that already has this system advantage and will now also be of greater importance in the economic field. If we strengthen India and have greater cooperation with India, we can strike a certain balance across the Asian region. When I see the idea of ​​China with the Silk Road and many others, I would feel more comfortable to have a strong India with which we have close ties. For this reason we should show this India more appreciation and not just look to Beijing.

name: Neena Gill (S&D).
text: – Mr President, I too want to congratulate Cristian Dan Preda on this report, which I believe is really key in terms of building our relationship with one of the world’s fastest-growing economies and a global power. I believe we share a vision for the future based on shared values, including sustainable development. We face many of the challenges which Cristian has already outlined – climate change, terrorism, protecting the rule of law, managing migration and respect for human rights. But tackling inequality and ensuring our citizens are ready for the technological area is key. These are really issues where we need to join forces and work together. I do regret that relations have been on the back burner for a while in the past, but I believe strongly that this report is a vital step in building a long-term cooperation and partnership and reviving negotiations on the trade and investment deal. I understand there will be a summit in the near future, and it is important that this leads to real concrete actions based on ambitions this Parliament has outlined in your report today. Last but not least, let me underscore that one of the main dimensions of our strategic partnership should be people. That is why we asked to promote exchanges on education, expand Erasmus+ to allow opportunities for students, but also to increase contacts, dialogue and mobility in areas like IT, research and culture. Once again, it was a pleasure, Cristian, to work with you on this. Well done and good collaboration.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (ECR).
text: - Mr President, EU-India relations must serve the mutual interest, far from invasive policies that may remind the people of India of past practices. The signing of a free trade agreement with the world's second most populous country will contribute to the further deindustrialisation of Europe, to the reduction of European wages, to the closure of thousands of European small and medium-sized enterprises, and this is because European multinationals will continue their outsourcing policy. They will operate in the vast Indian market, where starvation wages, child labor, over-exploitation of women, violation of labor rights, safety and health conditions and systematic breach of environmental conditions prevail. EU-India trade relations must depend on the elimination of these illegal practices in India and on the observance and protection of human rights in that country.

name: Stanislav Polčák (PPE).
text: - Mr President, I would also like to thank Mr Pred for presenting this report.I consider it really high quality.At the same time, I agree with Mr Van Orden.There are not even ten of us here, and we are discussing the report on the position of the country, which, thanks to the activities of Mr Módí's government, is moving towards the position of a superpower.That's really a shame.I appreciate the strong value partnership that is given and is the basis of the relationship between the EU and India.I was surprised by the extensive cooperation program that the report describes.At the same time, I would like to support India in cooperating on the security field.My colleague Preda also talked about that.China's assertive policy in the South China Sea really needs a stronger response.We should stand up for the superpower that is democratic.This means both free trade and strategic partnerships.These are the roles that suit the EU-India relationship.

name: Christos Stylianides
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, our discussion takes place shortly before the annual EU-India Summit that will be held in New Delhi in early October. I am happy to say that the report itself, and its assessments and recommendations, correspond to the intentions and activities of the European External Action Service as well as of the Commission. It definitely demonstrates the coherence of the EU policy approach towards India across the board. I would like, of course, to praise the work of the rapporteur, Mr Cristian Preda, who has my most definite congratulations. As the world’s largest democracies, the EU and India are important natural partners and, in the context of the current global uncertainties, we have a particular responsibility to protect and promote the rules-based international order. The EU Global Strategy recognises that there is a direct connection between European prosperity and Asian security, and we plan to boost our security-related cooperation with Asia, and with India in particular.  In fact, at the end of August, we already held the first foreign policy and security consultations in New Delhi, as well as three very productive security dialogues – counter—terrorism, cybersecurity and maritime – agreeing on specific actions for EU-India cooperation in these areas. During her visit to India last April, High Representative Federica Mogherini had the opportunity to discuss EU-India cooperation with the Prime Minister, the Minister of External Affairs and other officials. They agreed to enhance the ‘natural’ EU-India Strategic Partnership, based on common values, principles and interests, particularly the joint commitment to multilateralism. Last week in Bled the High Representative met once again with the Indian Minister of State Mr Akbar, including for discussions on preparations for the EU-India Summit.  We want to make the summit another milestone in the EU-India relationship to further develop our political, economic and sectoral cooperation. The last EU-India Summit instilled a new momentum in the Strategic Partnership. Several political visits to India supported the implementation of the last Summit’s conclusions, including the visits of Commission Vice—President Katainen in November 2016 and Commissioner Vella in October 2016, as well as the High Representative’s visit in April this year.  We have been working on the last summit’s outcomes, particularly the EU-India Clean Energy and Climate Partnership and the EU-India Water Partnership, and on cooperation on research and innovation, launching the EU-India Start-up Network last October. In March 2017, the President of the European Investment Bank opened a regional office in New Delhi, further strengthening the European Union’s presence in India and the wider region. The European Union plays a more and more important role as a partner in India’s ambitious modernisation agenda. We intend to deepen our cooperation in the area of urban development and further strengthen our cooperation on climate change. Both the European Union and India share a commitment to the Paris Agreement and its implementation and will continue to work together to realise its objectives. The European Union is India’s first trading partner and there is significant untapped potential in the EU-India trade and investment relationship. For this reason, the Commission remains engaged with India to seek to agree on the parameters for the resumption of ambitious negotiations on a free trade agreement. Despite numerous efforts, it has not been possible to make progress with India in this domain in time for the summit, but discussions continue. Looking ahead, the report recommends the adoption of a new EU strategy for its relations with India and, again, I can assure you that we have already started working on a strategic review of EU-India relations. The report and today’s discussions represent a valuable contribution to this initiative. Last but not least, allow me to congratulate you also on the positive impact of the visits of several of Parliament’s delegations to India this year and the strengthening of ties with the Indian Parliament. I would like to encourage you to maintain these regular contacts, including at the highest level.

name: Președintele. –
text: The point has been closed.The vote will take place on Wednesday, 13 September 2017. Written declarations (Rule 162)

name: Urmas Paet (ALDE)
text: in writing. - The EU-India partnership must be based on common values ​​such as democracy and respect for human rights. One can not overlook the very important concern for Estonia in relations with India. Namely, 14 Estonian and 6 British ship defenders have been imprisoned in India for almost four years and no progress is seen. The Tamil Nadu court has adjourned the hearing for the last ten months to announce the final verdict. However, while respecting Indian law and the judiciary, it is important that India also respects the right to a trial within a reasonable time. Especially for foreigners who have been waiting for their fate in India for almost 4 years. The unresolved issue of ship protectors must be consistently on the agenda in EU-India relations until the issue is resolved. The next opportunity is the EU-India Human Rights Dialogue and the EU-India Summit. Thus, while EU-India relations are important and promoted in the interests of both parties, it must be borne in mind that the EU has a responsibility to stand up for the interests of its citizens abroad and to ensure that they can return home to their loved ones as soon as possible.

name: Președintele. –
text: The next item on the agenda is the brief presentation of Petras Auštrevičius's report on corruption and human rights in third countries (2017/2028 (INI)) (A8-0246 / 2017).

name: Petras Auštrevičius
text: rapporteur. – Mr President, I am very pleased to present to you the report on corruption and human rights in third countries. Let me start by thanking all my colleagues from the Subcommittee on Human Rights, the Committee on Development and the Committee on International Trade for their input and great cooperation in preparing this report, as well as, in particular, Ana Gomes who was the rapporteur in 2013. The aim of this endeavour was to highlight the link between corruption and human rights, to cover the wide scope of human rights violations and to provide recommendations for EU policies. Corruption is regarded as a complex phenomenon of abuse of entrusted power for personal gain, which poses serious obstacles for the realisation of all human rights. It also distorts democracy and political processes. Therefore, in this report we see an intrinsic need to employ a human rights-based approach to the EU anti-corruption policy. Among other topics, the report highlights business responsibility, investment flows in relation to corruption, the influence of corruption on elections, tax havens, large sporting events and freedom of the media. We continue to insist that the Commission and the External Action Service use all our diplomatic tools so that the European Union takes the lead in the fight against corruption by supporting anti-corruption institutions in third countries, encouraging the sharing of best practices, and negotiating enforceable anti-corruption and anti-money laundering provisions in all future trade agreements that we make. We believe that the European Union can become a credible actor only if we address corruption within our own borders. Thus this report calls for an effective anti—corruption corruption strategy at Member State level too. As far as aid and financing instruments are concerned, we insist that EU-funded projects be permanently monitored and that any budget support be linked with concrete reforms towards transparency and other anti-corruption measures. Having said this, we must admit that the gap between the policy and implementation still exists and here there is a lack of political will to bridge it, as we have learned very well from recent examples. The future of the Guatemalan International Commission against Impunity, which is crucial in its fight against corruption in the country and was also mentioned in my report as a successful example of the EU-funded project, is now unfortunately under threat. In addition, we hear of LuxLeaks, Panama leaks, Russia and Azerbaijan Laundromats and other cases where we realise that corruption stretches far beyond state borders and is in fact having dramatic repercussions on very serious international policy decisions. We therefore call for the highest possible ethical and transparency standards to be upheld in international institutions and national bodies in order to encourage the European Union to have a legal framework in place to deter any type of corruption or fraud. Thus in this report we reiterate our demand to bring the Magnitsky sanctions list against 32 Russian state officials to the Council for its immediate adoption.  Let me finish by quoting John Steinbeck, a Nobel Prize winner from 1962, who said ‘Power does not corrupt. Fear corrupts ... perhaps the fear of a loss of power’. Indeed, I feel as if most of my report was precisely about the fear of the loss of power. I look forward to the debate in this plenary and the smooth adoption of this much-needed report.

name: President. –
text: Thank you very much. Of course if you misuse power, you are afraid afterwards, or you should be.

name: Stanislav Polčák (PPE).
text: - Mr President, I will be very brief. I would like to thank the rapporteur for presenting a very good and long report. In my opinion, it is so extensive that it really affected aspects that I did not even know about corruption. It did not occur to me to think that the requirements that the EU will make can play a very important role in the decision-making process on accession to the EU. I would like to thank the rapporteur for that. I think we should have rules that are really generally applicable to negotiations with third countries. We often provide money to corrupt people in those third countries. This is quite clear in the context of development aid. Or, unfortunately - hopefully inadvertently - we use our money to support illegal trade, nepotism or the trade in illicit goods. I think it is really important to have clear, concise rules that we would enforce in all cases, and there would be no such fundamental exceptions as we sometimes witness here and there.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (ECR).
text: - Mr President, the fight against corruption and human rights abuses in third countries must be the primary choice of our peoples. Land grabbing is unfortunately a daily practice in Africa, Latin America and Asia. Land grabbing by European, American and Chinese multinationals expelling Indigenous people. Corruption in developing countries is a fertilizer for human trafficking and child exploitation. In addition, other human rights violations are on the agenda, not only by third country governments, but also by multinationals, which have mercenaries and private armies to enforce their interests. Finally, the holding of free elections and the observance of democracy will be a demand for several decades, unfortunately, for many developing countries.

name: Christos Stylianides
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, the fight against corruption is one of the Sustainable Development Targets of the 2030 Agenda and is therefore reflected in the New European Consensus on Development adopted in June. The New Consensus will shape the EU’s development cooperation in the years to come. All of the human rights issues that are affected by corruption and highlighted in this report are also addressed by the 2015-2018 EU Action Plan for Democracy and Human Rights, so let me go through the five main issues raised by the report. Firstly, trafficking in persons. The trafficking in men, women and particularly children is a grave violation of human rights. It also constitutes a serious form of organised crime: a fast-growing, highly profitable business that can corrupt the legal order of a state. The EU has developed a comprehensive legal and policy framework to combat trafficking: I will list the EU Strategy towards the Eradication of Trafficking in Human Beings, the EU Directive on Preventing and Combating Trafficking in Human Beings and Protecting Victims, and the designation of the EU Anti-Trafficking Coordinator. This framework has victims at its centre, it is based on the recognition of everyone’s human rights, and it understands the specific needs of women and children. Our priorities in fighting human trafficking are to enhance the law enforcement and judiciary, and to enable them to disrupt criminal networks more efficiently, but it also stresses the need to foster transparency and accountability. I continue because I strongly believe that we have to show our discipline in the principles of this political body. Secondly, Business and Human Rights. The EU Council Conclusions of June 2016 on Business and Human Rights renew the commitment of the EU and its Member States to the UN Guiding Principles on Business and Human Rights and their implementation. Substantial progress has been achieved.
